Aquila visit. Very beautiful scenery, peaceful, great accommodation. The breakfast, lunch and supper buffet was awesome. For a very relaxing holiday away from all things electronic, this is the place to be, but of course the highlight are the game drives!!! An opportunity to see the big 5 so close to Cape Town.

Aquila- you have to go. What an amazing all round experience. Who knew we had such an amazing safari experience right here in Cape Town. Awesome food, fantastic accomodation and helpful and knowledgable staff.Aquila is highly recommended.
Great trip from Cape Town All-In-Experience. Aquilla has all in one. Good lodging, compact safari park, lots of animals, buffet restaurant, very well motivated guides.Good value for money.

Nice experience!. The game reserve is quite big, but you are aware at all times that it is an enclosed area. This is fine as long as you don't expect a "kruger-park" experience. An overnight stay and two gamedrives is enough to see all animals, which is simply awesome, the driver gets really close, perfect to make pictures.The food at the game reserve is good and the rooms are clean and very comfortable. I cannot compare it to other game reserves close to Cape Town but we certainly had a very good time!

Very good one day safari, with great accommodation. My family and I stayed at Aquila in April and we had a great time. The accommodation was perfect for a family of four. We were in a cavernous room with a mezzanine above the bathroom which was perfect for our two young kids.The two game drives that we went on were in a large open-sided 4x4 bus with max. 20 people or so. It is not a large game park, so we weren't particularly surprised to find zebra, cape buffalo, hippo, elephant and giraffe all within about a mile of the lodge gate. Not particularly wild, but it was exactly what we were looking for with two young kids eager to see as much wildlife as possible, and two parents keen to keep the driving to a minimum to avoid a meltdown! The drive into the lion enclosure was a particular highlight.The food in the huge restaurant building was a buffet service, which was fine - though a larger selection of meal options would have been nice.All in all, Aquila was exactly what we had hoped it would be.

Worth the effort. Overall very pleased but don't think you are in the African bush. You are in a large game park with fences keeping the animals in. Bit like Woburn Abbey but bigger and in the natural habitat. Beautiful setting and friendly staff. The room we stayed in was basic but adequate and I loved the outdoor shower. The food was the only disappointing item really. They put on a great display but the meat was very tough. Ok if you are veggie. our lorry driver was excellent and I would recommend this to anyone as a reasonably priced 'taster' to bigger (and much more expensive) reserves further north. Recommend you do the overnight stay to get the best atmosphere as the sun sets.

Trip of a lifetime. We spent a night at Aquila with our two small children. It was one of the most amazing weekends we have ever had with our children enjoy every second. Would love to visit again in the near future
Aquila Game Reserve is worth the visit. Lovely experience for children and foreigners (we had both). Close to Cape Town, malaria-free, conservation-aware, lovely accommodation, good food.

A great initial Safari guaranteed to see lots of animals. Aquila is a great Safari lodge for a first time visitor. The accommodation is lovely and in keeping with the surroundings. You are sure to see a lot of animals and the guides are fun and informative. Plenty of food available, although not fine dining and can be a little samey if you stay more than one night. I've taken 3 friends to Aquila and all have enjoyed it immensely and thought it good value for money.

Beautiful Experience. We unfortunately only stayed over for one night on the "winter special". The accomodation was clean and neat and we really enjoyed the outdoor shower. The game drives were beautiful with us having an opportunity to view most of the big five. The restaurant did not get our request for vegetarian meals we stated when booking so there was a little "problem" at lunch, thereafter we were catered for.

Memorable Safari Experience. I recently visited the Aquila Private Game Reserve with my family. Less than two hours drive from Cape Town it's extremely convenient for visitors to the Western Cape and also has the benefit of being in a malaria free area. We chose an overnight stay with evening and early morning game drives and opted for one of the premier cabins separate from the main lodge. The accommodation was first rate, in a very quaint but superbly comfortable African style. The buffet breakfast and lunch was very good although the dinner we had was pretty disappointing and lacked choice. As it was pretty quiet (mid winter - July) when we were there maybe that was due to a relative lack of guests that evening. The game drives were very good with very knowledgable and patient rangers. We saw a huge amount of wildlife including four of the big five and overall had a great experience. We were a bit disappointed that the lions were in a separate enclosure although it was pretty big. Seeing lions so obviously fenced in took some of the gloss off but, we felt better when we heard about the conservation work going on to save and rehabilitate this beautiful creatures and were pleased to hear that the plan is to release them into the main reserve in the future. If you are not heading to Northern Natal or the Kruger, this is a great option with fantastic wildlife and quaint yet luxurious accommodation.
Prof. Roxy Senior. Our client Prof. Roxy Senior said that he had a good experience at Aquila and would go there when he visits South Africa again.

It was nice. We live in Cape Town and my brother is visiting SA in December for the first time but unfortunately we won't have enough time to include a trip to Kruger. We therefore are scouting out a game reserve which has the big 5 and is close enough to Cape Town. It cost us R1500 pp to stay here (winter special) which included a standard chalet, three meals (all buffet) and two game drives. We arrived at 12.30pm as per the instructions and were given an arrival drink as they said. The arrival drink was a bubbly from De Doorns and I have to say, this was plonk. Here you have visitors from all over the world coming to this amazing reserve, we have over 600 wine producers in SA and you choose a sparkling over Methode Cap Classique (MCC). Please don't judge SA's "sparkling wine" from this one glass. Order a MCC at the next chance you get!! Or go for the sparkling grape juice. The thing that also annoyed me about this, is the package is quite pricy (esp for a local), so you would expect MCC on arrival and not sparkling?!! So next we go to reception, everyone was friendly but nothing OTT. We go through for lunch as we cannot check in until 2pm (as per the schedule). Lunch was buffet, it was a stunning day so we sat outside. With this we had no cutlery but we got some eventually. The main meal was a lamb Potjie (stew) and it was delicious. I ordered a glass of Robertson Chardonnay after the meal and it felts like a good 20 minutes before I got it. Service i therefore felt was not really up to scratch. We checked in to our standard room and that was pretty much correct. The fireplace didn't seem to work as we very quickly had a room full of smoke. We had to run each piece of wood under water to put out the fire. Our bathroom was pretty nice, but i am not a fan of outdoor showers, especially in winter. The bath was lovely though. We then went on the game drive, and this was pretty good. Unlike at the Kruger National Park which can be a bit daunting, especially if it is your first time, this place felt pretty safe and you can watch the animals at a leisurely pace and safe distance. The lions are in a separate section which is cool because you get to see them, but in a way the lions are just living in a big fenced off area. After three hours of driving around we went back to the lodge for dinner, also buffet. This was also nice and there was plenty to choose from. They have a pretty shocking wine list, i would love to suggest an alternative list to showcase SA wine at various price points!! When we got back to our room, they had turned on the lights and the heater and even made a towel in to an elephant (bonus points) which was all very nice. Next morning we unfortunately didn't go to the ARC where you can see the lions, cheetahs and leopards but I imagine that would be a highlight. Buffet breakfast was fine, though i am curious to know what they use for the bacon. Our seats also had bird poop on them and our salt shaker was empty. Small things go a long way and in a four star lodge, i would expect these things to be in order. Overall it was nice, but I am going to continue searching for the ultimate big 5 experience close to Cape Town.

Safari Tour for "Big Five" in Aquila Private Game Reserve. I choose this Reserve because it is close to Cape Town, you have th chance to see all "Big Five" in a single safari, even it is a Private Reserve. The Aquila car come to pick-up you early in the morning an after aproximatly 2 hours you reach the destination. It is a nice place with very skill rangers who tak small group in some special off-road car an make a tour of the Aquila Reserve, in order to see big wild animals like: elephants, rhinos, zebras, hipos, bull, lions end others. In the price of safari it is included also a lunch in very beatiful restaurant. I strongly recommend this experience, specially you haven't enough time and money to do a safari in the Nationals Big Parks and you are visiting Cape Town- South Africa.

Kirstin Charles. Our room was beautiful, just a few things I would like to point out, no matches for us to start our fire, no hairdryer in room, no conditioner (all of which I would of expected from a 4 star establishment) lunch was very much the same as dinner, having said this, the food was delicious. Wonderful guide on game drive but we missed the second game drive as it was at 7am as we had our 2 year old daughter with us so it was too much of a rush.
Great stay. We had a wonderful time in Aquila, with a great accomodation and a nice game in which we saw all animals.
Excellent stay. This is a beautiful place to stay and relax. It was very cold, but from the game drive to the dinner, everything was excellently organised. Thanks!
A night to remember. Who could ask for anything more, great staff, wonderful animals, fabulous food & comfortable accommodation. Have booked another over night stay next month.

SA Lodge. Was initially disappointed to be there while they where shooting a film. But the manager was accommodating and moved us further away from all the noise. Had a great time with the horseback safari and the staff was friendly and very helpful.

Aquila is top!. In every detail a great experience. Wonderful accommodation, good food, friendly staff, a warm water bottle for the cold morning safari and an afternoon drink and biltong during the afternoon safari.

An awsome experience. Thanks to the staff who made us feel special. We were treated to 3 good buffet meals daily. Good opportunity to see and photograph the big 5 (+), up close. Ideal for visitors with limited time.

Super friendly staff. We stayed at Aquila and thoroughly enjoyed our trip not just due to the luxurious resort or wildlife tours, but the friendly staff that are happy to help and assist in any way. And hopefully you are as lucky as we were to have Matthew as your safari guide.

Not as expected. I reserved a two day (overnight) safari with Aquila for my son and I in July 2014. They picked us up at 6:40am as part of a group transfer from Cape Town. We arrived at the reserve at around 9:00am and had breakfast before our first game drive. The game drive is in an open vehicle with around 15 people. The driver stated several times that he hopes to deliver on seeing all the "Big 5", so we were excited about what we would see on the drive. The first part of the drive we seen springbok, zebra, rhino, buffalo, etc. Then we pulled up to a electrified fence and was explained that the lions were separated from those animals because the reserve was only 13 years old. I thought ok maybe that made sense. Then we pulled through the fence and found that the lions were in another fenced in enclosure. Then we went past the lions and seen two giraffe and two elephants in the open field. The cheetah and leopards were across the highway in fenced in enclosures. Needless to say this was not the African Safari we had expected. These animals were being fed by the reserve staff, not surviving in the wild like it had been represented. This is nothing more than a zoo. We have been on more realistic game drives in the U.S. than this one. Being in Africa we expected animals living in the wild and hoping to sneak up on them to see them. The excitement and little bit of danger associated with finding animals in the wild was what attracted us to a safari. We did not come here to see a zoo. Anyway, we arrived back at the check in area and we had had enough. We did not want to waste another 30 hours of our vacation at this place. I asked the lady at the front desk if we could ride back with one of the afternoon transfers that day and she said she would check. After 15 minutes or so she said there was not any room. She said they would not refund our money for the room or rest of our trip. I told her that was fine we just did not want to be there any longer. I said how could we get back and she said I could pay $R2500.00 for a private transfer. I said that's what I wanted. It was not until this time that she asked me why we wanted to leave. I told her it was not what we expected. That was it, no more questions. No one seemed surprised or concerned that we would want to leave. I ended up spending $R7690.00 for one trip aroud a zoo. Beware that their website extremely misrepresents what your experience will be like.

Aquila to improve their standards. Overall trip was disappointing as we stayed for 3 nights, which is too long as there is nothing to do there. We enjoyed sitting in the lounge during the day and at night however it took a long time to receive drinks and the resort has no board games or cards for guests to keep themselves entertained with. It would be lovely if the resort had a pool table and a dart board to keep guests busy. The bonfire was lovely for the 2 nights we requested it be lit, although told on the second night that they weren't going to make a big one...irrespective whether guests ask for a bonfire or not, one should be lit to encourage guests to bring hot drinks and marshmallows and congregate and share wildlife stories. Most staff were polite however we felt that they were not prepared to go above and beyond what is expected of them, this is very sad considering Aquilla is a 4 star resort. Guests felt like they were burdening the staff by asking for another round of drinks. The resort is lovely and so much potential to do better however we were there during off season therefore not everything was available or in use, this is very sad too considering that the northern hemisphere countries have they're summer holidays at this time and visiting SA in the winter is a pleasure and the cooler weather is welcomed. So basically because it's their off season we aren't entitled to those guests that pay full rates during off season.The games drives were enjoyable especially the little picnic set up. Unfortunately Aquila should not advertise themselves as a Game Reserve but rather a Game lodge with tame animals or a conservatory with wild life. The lions are kept in an enclosed area and are very fat, hardly think they can hunt for themselves. Other wildlife come in pairs; 2 elephants, 2 giraffe, 2 buffalo etc. Overall it's a great place for tourists who have never seen wildlife before and it would only be recommended to stay for one night so you feel the full effects and leave satisfied.
overnight safari. meals and accomodation was very good. I would like to recoommend more activities for the little ones.

Excellent stay!. I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at Aquila. The value is fantastic, the food is great, and for the proximity to Cape Town and no hassle, I couldn't ask for more. I would highly recommend doing the horseback safari, as you can go many more places.

An Awesome Experince. This was an absolutely fantastic experience. The game drives were great and there were so many animals to see. The guides on the game drive were extremely enertaining and knowledgeable. The guest houses were absolutely quaint and very private. The grounds themselves were so beautiful and there weren't too many guests when we stayed. The entire staff at Aquila were so sweet and kind. It was a very quiet setting and one was able to relax and hear themselves think. I look forward to going back next year just to have quiet time again.

Great visit and stay. Visited with my husband who is not South African and after reading reports where it was said it was like a zoo, I must admit I was pleasantly surprised. I visited Kruger Park a lot growing up, and there is obviously nothing to compare to Kruger, but for a first time non South African, it is a great start. Accommodation and food is first rate. Quality meals every day. And staff are wonderful too. Definitely worth the drive.

Overall impressive. Only the lady at the reception desk impaired our overall good impression. Cold,impersonal,uninterested - really a pity!All other personal very friendly and attentive. Nice idea with the elephant towels and hot water bottles.Very motivated and engaged rangers.Accommodation and catering services incl. welcome drink excellent.
M Streicher. The food excellent, staff warm and extreemly friendly, guides well in formed and very friendly. A perfect break away.

Good for overseas visitors. The lodge and operations are very good , the food awesome and standard accommodation good in summer but cold in winter unless you know how to use a coal stove. also the hot water supply to the room does not sustain two people in a short time. The game viewing for us was average in that we are spoilt safari exponents , the lions are not free range but are beautiful , two elephants , hippos are great and the leopard is not free range so you do see the big five but not all in natural habitat for good reasons I may add. However once you have done two game drives you have seen it all and so would not recommend a stay of longer than two days.perfect for visitors to Cape Town who have not seen the big five before or experienced say 7 days on open bush lodges.

Awesome Experiance. We were booked in over the weekend (05 & 06 July 2014).I was expecting a less than perfect experience due to it being out of season. Although the price was expensive being a "local" - what we received was totally worth every cent I spent.We were greeted by a staff member on arrival, with welcome drinks and a small induction to the weekends activities. I would like my review to be in two parts namely the staff and then the activities.The staff were beyond amazing, they all had warm smiles and the attitude of family members. No request was too big or too small, they made you feel welcome and really went the extra mile to accommodate us. You don’t need to ask, they actually suggested things like extra firewood for the rooms fireplace, wine glasses and wine for the rooms, hot water bottles, extra blankets and even gloves and scarves (at a minimal cost). They were up early to attend to our needs - everyone was absolutely phenomenal right down from the gardeners to the General Manager - Mr Basson. Thank you to all for your attentiveness and willingness to serve us.The activities were well planned and the game drives were something else, we saw everything and out of past experience - a game drive is only going to be as fun as the other guests and then the ranger. My ranger for the trips was Mike - he went out of his way to make our trip and stay memorable. He did small things for us like allow us great photo ops with the animals (we got out of the truck to get photos of the giraffes in the background and he also broke away from the convoy for us (we were the truck right at the back and the diesel fumes were bad.... so he 'shot left.... problem solved). He was also willing to stop at every single animal we saw for photos and he did not constrict us to a schedule. He absolutely made our trips what they were.The food was also superb, there was never a lacking of anything.... and it was delicious, we could not have asked for better. The beds were comfortable and HUGE... could sleep a family of 4 in one bed easily.Like I said in my introduction, the price was expensive for a single day and being a local.... but, for what we received it was worth every single cent and I am also without a doubt going to go back there again, soon very soon.I would not recommend more than two or three days because you are so busy and active that you need a day or two to recover from the getaway. I also feel the curio shop was a little overpriced but in saying that the proceed

Brilliant Stay At Aquila. Amazing weekend away. Everything was perfect and it ran smoothly. I also love how there are conservation projects to protect, save and help the animals and nature reserve. We saw everything we were hoping to see and the only reason why I gave it 4 stars (would of given 4.5 if it had that option) is because it is very controlled and not as wild as the Kruger Park but on the plus side you are almost guaranteed to see what you wanted to see and get amazing photos. You will also learn a lot about the animals as the game rangers have a wide knowledge of the animals. The food is fantastic so make sure you get there with an empty stomach.

1 Year Wedding Anniversary at Aquila. My wife were celebrating our one year anniversary this year and I decided to surprise her by doing an overnight at Aquila. The game reserve was beyond what we thought it would be and absolutely loved every minute of it! It's not only affordable, but everyone on their team was really amazing. Surprisingly, we also got to go on 3 game drives and all meals were included. I highly, highly, recommend this for anyone visiting Cape Town!- Ryan
Wonderful Time!. Thank you for a truly wonderful experience. We would definitely recommend this experience to any one who is looking for good food, friendly staff, and an authentic safari experience.

Very upsetting. The accommodation was lovely but the whole experience extremely upsetting. The animals are clearly 'caged' and depressed. I have never seen such sad lions in my life and I've been to the bush countless times. A dead baby hippo lying next to it's mother, 2 young elephants forced into a boma overnight. We were told that 2 giraffes died because they starved and didn't adapt to a clearly unadaptable area. NO TREES? We felt this was clearly a sick money making operation (hugely expensive although luckily we didn't pay) geared at tourists who want to see the big 5. I can completely understand a rehabilitation park or sanctuary for animals with no where else to go - but the fact that these animal were paid for and most from the Kruger Park up near Mpumalanga - which is a completely different terrain - it just broke out hearts. Keep your lovely accommodation and gear it to something else. But put your big 5 back where they belong... in the real bush. Unfortunately we will never come back or suggest anyone else do the same. It has scarred us.

MID WEEK TRIP. Our stay with Aquila was very pleasant. The rooms were lovely and clean and all staff very friendly. One thing sadly was that the children's recreation area was closed due to renovations therefore they couldn't have the full experience.
Peace. Our trip was a treat for family members and we thoroughly enjoyed our stay from the welcome drinks, the great staff, the great food and of course the animals! Thanks so much.

Sisters Birthday weekend. Overall visit was wonderful however, some small attentions to detail need to be addressed. The room was not properly cleared from the first nights stay. Used glasses and other crockery were not removed the next day. The hot chocolate sachets were not replaced. The bar service a little slow when busy and i felt a second person on duty would be beneficial. The Sauvignon Blanc wine ran out and I could not buy wine by the glass and had to end up buying a bottle each time. The system had not updated by the time of checkout and I had to be stopped on driving away to pay more money after settling my bill. Otherwise the food was excellent, did not go hungry once over the weekend and game drives were wonderful and informative. Thank you also for returning my camera.

What an experiance. We were booked in over the weekend (05 & 06 July 2014).I was expecting a less than perfect experience due to it being out of season. Although the price was expensive being a "local" - what we received was totally worth every cent I spent.We were greeted by a staff member on arrival, with welcome drinks and a small induction to the weekends activities. I would like my review to be in two parts namely the staff and then the activities.The staff were beyond amazing, they all had warm smiles and the attitude of family members. No request was too big or too small, they made you feel welcome and really went the extra mile to accommodate us. You don’t need to ask, they actually suggested things like extra firewood for the rooms fireplace, wine glasses and wine for the rooms, hot water bottles, extra blankets and even gloves and scarves (at a minimal cost). They were up early to attend to our needs - everyone was absolutely phenomenal right down from the gardeners to the General Manager - Mr Basson. Thank you to all for your attentiveness and willingness to serve us.The activities were well planned and the game drives were something else, we saw everything and out of past experience - a game drive is only going to be as fun as the other guests and then the ranger. My ranger for the trips was Mike - he went out of his way to make our trip and stay memorable. He did small things for us like allow us great photo ops with the animals (we got out of the truck to get photos of the giraffes in the background and he also broke away from the convoy for us (we were the truck right at the back and the diesel fumes were bad.... so he 'shot left.... problem solved). He was also willing to stop at every single animal we saw for photos and he did not constrict us to a schedule. He absolutely made our trips what they were.The food was also superb, there was never a lacking of anything.... and it was delicious, we could not have asked for better. The beds were comfortable and HUGE... could sleep a family of 4 in one bed easily.Like I said in my introduction, the price was expensive for a single day and being a local.... but, for what we received it was worth every single cent and I am also without a doubt going to go back there again, soon very soon.I would not recommend more than two or three days because you are so busy and active that you need a day or two to recover from the getaway. I also feel the curio shop was a little overpriced but in saying that the proceeds from that shop supplement the anti-poaching campaign "saving private rhino" and once you see these animals in the bush you realise it is a drop in the ocean and worth it.....I would also like to say thank you to every single person whom had a hand to play in serving us the weekend - you all show passion for the job at hand and it all contributed to an unforgettable stay.I have some amazing pictures and even the sub-zero temperatures contributed to our amazing experience.

Excellent stay...almost everything well provided for . The rangers are very informative and friendly. Food excellent.. Had a 2 night stay..very much enjoyed it. A very accessible and well-managed wildlife experience. It is a contained park.. but the upside is that you can see a lot of game in a 2 hour ride and get very close to the game. compared with unpredictable much longer drives at kruger and sometimes having to be content with a fleeting glimpse of an animal hundreds of meters away.The food was outstanding and the buffet staff very friendly and knowledgable when asked about ingredients. With both people in our party who have grown up visiting game reserves in southern africa, as well as europeans experiencing a reserve for the first time, I can truly say there is something for everyone. I can also say the value is excellent ( we live in Cape town and are not visitors with pounds or dollars).

Disappointing Overnight. We stayed at the lodge overnight during a business trip. The weather was absolutely freezing and all I wanted was a hot shower to warm up after a very icy evening. Yet after we got to the rooms we discovered that only outdoor showers were available. The water pressure was poor and the rooms interior design felt very dated and cheap. Overall, a very poor representation of a game reserve experience. Much better places elsewhere.

Game for anything!. A very early start for a long drive from Somerset West was, on the whole, well worth it.We were greeted with champagne (not really a good idea at 9.30am) and told to make our way to breakfast which was included in the price. A huge self serve breakfast was waiting in the light, spacious dining room over looking the pool. All the usual culprits, bacon, sausage, eggs etc but also a great range of fresh fruit salads, cold meats and breads, which really set you up for the day..twelve of us set off in the truck, and within minutes on the track, we came across our first jaw dropping view - we were constantly hearing whoops of joy rom fellow truck sharers, every time another wild animal decided to entertain us. Whilst we all knew deep down that this was a fenced reserve - it was so huge (miles and miles and miles) that it felt completely natural. Animals that we had only ever seen in the confines of a zoo in the uk..And they all came to greet us that day - giraffes, hippos, elephants, rhinos, lion, tigers...An hour and a half in we stoped for a break - and the champagne (or soft drink ) came out again, which by then was very welcome - unfortunately, it also meant that a few needed the loo - so remember, this trip is at least two hours long!!After a couple of long, dusty, bumpy albeit enjoyable hours in a plank seated truck - we arrived back at base where yet another huge buffet lunch awaited us, with multiple choices and puddings galore!!A great day out!
Great Family Stay. Great food, excellent rooms and enjoyed the game drives. Guides are very knowledgeable. will go back.

Aquila Private Game Reserve. Aquila Private Game Reserve was fantastic and thoroughly enjoyed by all who went to visit. The animals are well kept, food was delicious and staff very friendly. Stunning breakaway!

Aquila Private Game Reserve. I was impressed by the efficiency of the staff, the quality of the accommodation and the amazing food. We had no water for 2days, but our discomfort was kept to the minimum! We saw the Big 5 and enjoyed the friendliness and knowledge of the tour guides/rangers.

2 days to remember. An excellently run establishment. Marco was an excellent guide on the game drives. Lovely to see the care given to the animals and how close we could get in the trucks.Would love to go again.

I expected more! . I'd not recommended this safari tour, specially if is your first time doing it. Looks like a zoo where you can go through. There is a cheetah in a cage, 2 elephants, 2 giraffes, 2 lions and 4 sambas, a couple of zebras and 3 rhino. We didn't see hippo, but they have there. Do not expect to see any animal hunting or the guide holding a gun as in a Discovery Channel documentary. The staff are good and helpful, and the food is not too bad. However, If you are decided to go, be prepared for the wind (is really cold up there), so don't forget a sweater and something to cover your face against the cold wind. They provided blanket on the game vehicle.

Overnight at Aquila. What a great place to go to to relax and enjoy the surroundings! Accommodation was very good - loved the oversized bed and open fireplace in the room. The food was very good - plenty of choice. The staff were most pleasant. The rangers were great - learned a lot! What let our stay down was the unfortunate fact we had no running water and were unable to bath or shower. Circumstances beyond anyone's control. We would thoroughly recommend Aquila.
Fun. Really enjoyed our stay.The fireplace chimney needs a good clean though as we were smoked out of our room, but still we had fun.

Have to rate poor (No Hot or Cold Water in room). We stayed (17Jun14). Would like to rate Aquila higher but we had some fundamental issues.Aquila game reserve seems to be a managed game reserve. We flew overnight from UK & self drove to the park. Desperate after 2 days of travel for a shower we were disappointed to have no water (hot or cold in the room). A bucket of water was provided for flushing the toilet & 5 litre bottles of drinking water were provided by the sinks for hand/teeth brushing. The bucket was sufficient for 2 flushes of the toilet.We returned from the Game Drive to find the water issue still remained (toilet had been cleaned). We went for dinner & were provided with keys to another room should we want to have water! Unfortunately we we're just too tired & with a pre-dawn start for game drive & the prospect of moving cots/baby equipment/luggage we just crashed out. In the morning the situation was the same, returning from the game drive & after breakfast we had cold running water.I mentioned the above to the General Manager, no compensation was forthcoming, he mentioned an ongoing problem with 'Water Security' issues that they were trying to resolve. We booked a Family Room at their 'Winter Special' overnight rate, it included Buffet Lunch/Dinner/Breakfast & welcome drinks. From memory the cost of accomodation was approx 1,900ZAR p/p a total of just over £200uk/U$300, this seemed very poor when taken in context of the discomfort of lack of water, notwithstanding the offer of a separate place to shower.Had we not had the water issues or had been offered some concession towards our inconvenience I would not hesitate to rate Aquila very highly & good value for money at that price.The staff were very Courteous, the lodge looks fantastic & is being improved, the room/bed was very comfortable. The Game Drive was interesting within the context of a managed Game Park & on the afternoon 'Safari' we were provided with canapés & sparkling wine.The buffet food was hearty & tasty but I wouldn't say outstanding ( good by rest of the world standards but given the outstanding food in South Africa I'd say in comparison it was OK/Good, certainly not disappointing), dining is in a large hall with an open fire.Middle of winter wrap up warm, especially for the morning Safari!Despite our disappointment & lack of compensation, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend Aquila, be aware of their admitted 'Water Security' issues. Not all rooms were affected during our stay.
Awesome!. Beautiful resort, luxury accommodation, great food, nice friendly staff. Amazing experience!!!! We loved it!

will come again. whilst the weather was not on our side the service from all the staff was top notch.. If we may make a suggestion the amount of food on the plates on our evening was far to much so a fair amount was returned to the kitchen .We appreciate that there were not many people eating so a buffet was not the ideal way but smaller portions would have been enough for us .
Mr. Venske. The visit was really amazing. The cherry on the top was the lovely dinner on Thursday evening served in our room. Really a wonderful touch. thank you to all that made the trip special.

Amazing but beware of cabin 11. What an amazing place. Great staff, food and overall experience! So amazing to see the animals in their natural habitat!!The only complaint I had was being put in a room with no heating (number 11) - the remote control was missing. However we were moved to a much nicer room.Thank you Aquila!

Nice Local Safari!. My friend and I stayed overnight for a safari and it was great! Our ranger, Tyler was amazing. Very friendly and incredibly knowledgable. We had very poor weather, but the staff had blankets, hot water bladders, and ponchos to keep us warm and dry. The food was tasty and the accommodations were lovely (and HOT which was great on a cold winter night).

Enjoyable visit. We had a good experience at Aquila: the friendly staff, comfortable rooms with good heating, an excellent guide. One is practically guaranteed to get close to at least four of the Big Five. It's not a true safari as the lions are in a very large enclosure, but to see many hippos with calves, out of the water, was fantastic. Breakfast was great. The other meals offered plentiful amounts of average food - good puddings though.

Up close and personal safari. Aquila was a great lodge to get close to plenty of African wildlife. We had a great stay with friends and the size of the reserve means you're guaranteed to see plenty of the animals even if you're there for one day.The food was fantastic as were the facilities. The staff were charming and the safari guides very knowledgeable and engaging.

well-meant. In a situation like this where you are a captive group like the animals driven around a relatively small circuit the experience is critically determined by which ranger you get - what stories they tell, how much knowledge they have, the quality of discussion possible. Just looking at the animals in the absence of information is not only disappointing, it makes you feel exploitative, like a zoo, when this new form of animal reserve, a function of wealthy tourist interest, may be the only way these creatures will survive in future. Top quality ranger knowledge and communication skills are key - unless you just want mindless photos. We almost cried when we we put on the 'wrong' truck with a silent, non-fluent ranger, who could not answer our questions and who did not understand our interests, and named the animals and their genders plus a few facts about pounds of food and gestation periods and that was it: we could see the other truck's engaging speaker, who had so much to say. Lost a night's sleep over this - our one time only, big expense, maybe never in Africa again. Either give everyone experienced rangers, or figure out how to spread the good communicators/knowledgeable ones (Timothy) around, or find some way to allow tourists to self-select - those interested in knowing a lot, from those interested in the (luxurious) surroundings - food and pool - and photos.

excellent. Very happy with the Game Ranger "Tim" friendly and very knowledgeable.Loved the Hot water bottles in the beds and the rolled up towels when coming back from the game drive.Food was excellent.Very impressed and will definately visit again.
What a treat. Awesome game drive and stay at Aquila. They really know how to pull out all the stops. Very impressed.
A break from city life. Pleasant staff. Nice distance from Cape Town. Knowledgeable rangers. But small reserve. Lions kept in a fenced enclosure. Lovely accommodation. Great food.

Delightful Game Drive. My wife and I stayed on May 16 for one night in the chalet. You must get a chalet on the mountain side, it was beautiful and came with a bottle of wine. The food was good, breakfast the best as was the service. The driver picked us up at out Cape Town hotel and it was a pleasant 2 hour drive. We saw all the animals with the exception of lions. The guide was professional and friendly. Over all it was very good, should have stayed 2 nights though.

Good food but not really a safari. We went for a day safari from Cape Town. Despite booking late it was easy to book and the driver collected us exactly when he said he would. The breakfast was great, good choice and tasty. Lunch was similarly good though drinks had to be paid for. As for the "game drive" - it was good fun but hardly a "game drive" as the reserve lacks the numbers of animals we have seen before. All the animals looked content and the reserve well cared for, but after finishing the drive we felt we had seen all there was to offer. We did debate staying a night, but are glad we didn't.

Great staff make a difference. We recently visited Aquila Private Game Reserve for a one night weekend stay. We stayed in one of the cabins above the river/stream and had a perfect view of the hippos in the river, almost below the cabin. Our cabin was an interesting mix of rustic stone and restrained luxury. We brought our own shampoos and soaps but decided to use the biodegradable ones provided as suggested on the information sheet - these were of really good quality and compared favourably to the salon shampoo I use at home. A well-placed fireplace in the room kept it warm and cosy on a cold evening; the in-room wine, hot chocolate, coffee and tea was a treat after dinner and before the morning game drive. From the moment we arrived we were greeted and dealt with in a really friendly and professional manner. The buffet meals at the restaurant were all delicious and service at the restaurant matched the service we experienced throughout our stay, from the lady serving welcome drinks, to the reception, the barlady, porters, and especially our lovely guide, Michael. Aquila is not the Kruger, but it is under 2 hours from Cape Town in a lovely part of the world, and we were able to experience rhino, lions, elephants, hippo, and several other animals up close and that was a great experience, especially for our children (age 10 and 15). I would love to return in summer to sit outside and take advantage of the patio and pool area.

Waste of Time and Money! Stay away!. I am not one to typically write reviews, but my family and I were so troubled by our recent experience at Aquila that I felt compelled to prevent potential visitors from the same terrible experience.  We arrived from Cape Town to Aquila for the day trip safari. Main problem: There were barely any animals to see. Two elephants, some springbok and some hippos. That was it for our safari ride!! When we arrived to the area of the lions, we didn't even see one! All you can see is vast dry landscape. You honestly will benefit from going to the zoo instead. Our entire jeep group including my family was angered. I have never seen such trickery and false advertisement. Bottom line: There are no great safaris near Cape Town. I have been to Sun City early this year where the Pilensburg National Reserve is located. That place was great. I have also been to the Hwange Safari in Zimbabwe; great as well. There is no substitute for natural reserves versus these artificial game reserves.

Chantal. Big 5 experience, 2 hours from Cape Town. Loved the animals, they look content. Dress warmly for the game drives, especially in winter months, scarf and gloves will help. You are given blankets and ponchos if it rains. Aquila is okay for a day trip but better as a one night stay over as you can get in 2 game drives.Staff were very good, food was excellent and our game drive guide was excellent with a good sense of humour and respect for the animals.

Day Trip for a Big Group, location and scenery was awesome. We went to Aquila Private Game reserve on May 2014 for a day tour. We were a really big group of more than 150 people. The location was really really great. It was awesome specially for us coming from a tropical country. The staffs and the drivers were very accommodating and kind. We had the game drive tour for about 1.5 to 2 hours I think. Since we are a big group, waiting time was also included in the drive time. The tour guide/driver assigned to our group was knowledgeable on the things he discussed about the major animals we saw. I just wished that he also threw in some information on little creature we saw during the drive. Most of the details discussed would be for the big animals (and of course the big 5) that we saw. Information that we would likely see through google search or NatGeo, but the thrill is you get to hear those facts while seeing them and getting close to these creatures a possible. It would have been better or maybe the best if we've seen more animals, whether it be big or small.The facilities they have are great. I also liked the food. The garden, the pool and whole place in general is awesome. I think it was breathtaking. The people are okay too. Kids would definitely enjoy this place, specially those who lives in an urban place. A safe way to see wild animals as close as possible. I just don't know what the lodges is like since we didn't stayed there' over night.

"taste" of safari. Just 2.5 hours from Cape Town, Aquila is easily accessible for Cape Townians and tourists alike. I highly recommend staying one night in one of the small cottages onsite as your stay will include a morning and evening game drive which are well worth it. Day visitors enjoy the midday game drive but it tends to be hotter and more crowded at that time. I have visited for a day trip and stayed a night on a separate occasion end I really enjoyed the late afternoon game drive on my second visit. Meals are included in the price - day visitors get a lunch and ever night stay gets a lunch on arrival, dinner and then breakfast the next day. We saw all of the big 5, though the leopard was in a cage as she had been rehabilitated from a hunting lodge and could no longer live in the wild. The reserve is large and though you know that you are in an enclosed area - the cottages and main lodge are separated from the animals by a fence - it is not as small as some of the other private reserves.Our cottage felt very luxurious, with an outdoor shower and a huge, comfortable bed. After dinner we were greeted by a towel shaped into an elephant on our bed, which was a really nice touch. There is a pool onsite and I wish we had arrived earlier for our lunch to have time for a swim before our 3pm game drive. A convenient way to see some animals while staying close to Cape Town!
Fantastic experience. Great place, very good organization and friendly and helpful staff. The game drives are perfect and well organized

Excellent. We had a great time, the accommodation was excellent and the food very good considering the numbers you are catering for. The staff were friendly and hepful as were all of the animals that we saw. We saw more than we expected. I wasn't too keen to see the big cats in such small enclosures, that was sad. The room was lovely and we thought the outdoor shower great fun. Thank you for a lovely expereince that I would strongly recommend.

Wonderful Wildlife Experience. We loved our overnight experience at Aquila ! Warm hospitality, hearty food, cosy accommodation and passionate staff. The tour guide Tim, was fantastic! He was so knowledgable and shared funny stories about the wildlife on our 2 game drives. Great little gem in the Karoo if you want to see the Big 5!Karoo if you want to experience the Big 5
Amazing time!. Great time. The guides knew their stuff, we saw all animals and learnt a lot too. Accom was also fab.

Fantastic visit to Aquila. Fully enjoyed our overnight stay at Aquila. For a week before the visit we could not keep the levels of excitement from the kids who thoroughly enjoyed the trip.The game drives were great and we saw lots of animals. One funny part - as we were watching the rhinos in the water, we did not see the Cape Buffalo approaching the truck and had to make a hasty retreat when the Ranger realized that the buffalo was almost upon us. The food and the accommodation was first class. We had the Family bungalow and the kids loved their sleeping quarters in the loft. Well done Aquila - a really great overnight trip - wish I could afford it more often.

Did not get $'s worth!. I did the horseback safari and was extremely disappointed. First off Online it say's 1 1/2 hour long and you can walk or ride at the riders discretion. There were four of us in a group and they only allowed us to walk. No galloping at all. Also we only rode for 50min. Two of our group had driven 4 hours round trip, and were extremely disappointed. I was as well. The breakfast and lunch buffet was nice. On the safari ride, we did not see any lions. If you come to Africa specifically looking forward to a safari, I would look elsewhere. This is more of a rehabilitation place. To see the cheetah (1) you had to get out of the jeep and walk along look through the chain fence. We did see 2 elephants, Ostrich, Springbok, 2 Rhino, 1 giraffe, and the eyeballs of two Hippo that were underwater. From Cape Town it took four hours roundtrip. A lot of travel time and cost for this place. The lodge/pool was very nice. seemed like good accommodation's.

A very convenient "game reserve" experience. Aquila was and experience way beyond my expectations. It is a very tranquil spot where they are trying to reintroduce animals which were indigenous a long time ago. The set up is very well organised and makes for a memorable experience. The guide we had was very informative of all the animals on the reserve and it was interesting to hear details of these wonderful creatures. It maybe a little artificial since the animals are effectively in captivity and they have to be fed but the reserve is very large and the animals roam around so it is not at like a zoo. There is some accommodation which had we known we probably would haved stayed given the tranquil nature of the surrounds. It is a wonderful experience for all ages and the champagne at 8:30am following a long drive from Capetown was a nice way to start the day! Very good food here also so come hungry and you can also relax by the pool after the safari.

It's a tad tired. this was my second visit to Aquila and once again I felt let down by the service and the food. this time we arrived for lunch and the food was good but I had to go and ask at a desk where a bunch of staff were chatting if we could order some wine. Dinner was awful, poor selection and when we arrived around 8pm the mussels starter had run out. A visitor from Belgium told me she had been at 7.30pm and they had already run out then. I went to the back where the staff were standing doing nothing and asked for the dish to be replenished. this was done willingly and a few minutes later the lady came out with a bowl of mussels and stirred them into the sauce of the serving bowl on the table. We took some and so did the Belgian lady only to find they were STILL FROZEN. Our game ranger Mike was also a let-down, he didnt give proper photo opportunities and rushed us back at the end of the drive because he had spent too long at the drinks stop chatting to some young guests. the accommodation was good and the breakfast also good as was lunch, dinner a disaster and the buffet area looks like it could use a good scrubbing of the walls and maybe a coat of paint.
50th birthday trip!. Not bad reserve but animals seemed drugged and not alot of animals roaming around. Birds eating the food at buffet table at breakfast! Personally would not go on that tour again!

A sanitised Safari Park. As previously commented this is not an authentic safari experience, having said that it is a way to see large animals in the 'wild' and an enjoyable experience all the same. Guides were very informative and took us as close to the animals as you could get, so some great photo opportunities.Very early start from Cape Town but Aquila provided a great breakfast to start the tour and a similarly great lunch to finish the tour, well worth the visit just to see the rescued cheetahs and leopard.
Aquila. very nice food, helpful staff, nice guide.Beautifull area.Thank you Chelsea for this opportunity.Ciao!

What a treat in the Karoo. We looked at a few game reserves but decided on Aquila. Everybody says they have this and that but when it comes to delivering Aquila is Epic... From the friendly staff to great food the 2 day stay was truly homely and so so memorable...with truly personable game drives that brought us into arms reach of the BIG 5.... epic stay we will be back

Enjoyable, But Don't Go With High Expectations. I visited Aquila in early April for a day trip on horseback. I had a very enjoyable day but for anyone thinking about visiting you should have your expectations in line as this is not an ‘authentic’ wild life experience. If you are looking for that type of trip you need to visit a different area of South Africa. If, however, you simply want to see some of the Big 5 near Cape Town in a semi-wilderness type environment Aquila would be a great place to do it. I’m an avid horseperson so taking the horseback safari option was a no brainer for me. Even if you’re not an experienced rider at home I’d recommend considering it. Being free from the roads the trucks use allows you to see more of the reserve and to wander closer to the animals. It’s also a less intrusive way to view them. I was surprised how close we were able to get to the zebras and other grazers without spooking or seeming to bother them.The guide was a quirky and chatty fellow and I really did enjoy riding with him. On the downside I found in my follow up research that several of the animal facts and tidbits he provided weren’t entirely accurate. So if you want a somewhat educational day trip this may not be the place for it. Remember to take the teachings ‘with a grain of salt’. I took the shuttle transfer from Cape Town and in retrospect I would have planned it differently. The shuttle picked me up at 6am and after a couple more pickups we were on the road by 6:30am and arrived at 8:30am. The ride didn’t leave until 10:30am so I had a couple of hours to kill. The rides are about 2.5 hours long (although the day I visited we happened to stay out a little longer) and the shuttle didn’t leave Aquila to return to Cape Town until 3pm. It would have been better to rent a car for the day and self-drive. The reserve is easily accessible, the roads are good and car rentals are cheap. The shuttle transfer was more expensive than a car and GPS rental would have been so if you’re confident driving in South Africa save the wasted time and drive yourself.

Big 5 near Cape Town. We booked this short safari as an introduction for my 3 daughters and we weren't disappointed. We stayed overnight at the Game Reserve so we didn't have to rush off after the game drive. Upon arrival we were greeted with a glass of sparkling wine, the children with sparkling grape juice, and then directed into the reception. As we were overnighting, our check in was after lunch. All meals included in the package price, drinks were extras. Lunch was buffet style, so all you could eat, freshly prepared and plentiful. After lunch we checked-in and our lodge was brilliant, it even had a fully working log fire. Our first game drive was in the afternoon and our guide was knowledgeable and friendly. On returning to the lodge, we were greeted by about 8 hippos in the poll opposite, separated from the lodge by a fence. Dinner was again buffet style.We were up early the next morning for another game drive, with the same guide and just as good as the previous evening. We saw the big 5 over the two game drives. Returning to the lodge we had breakfast and checked out to return to Cape Town.Overall a great two days the place is child friendly and a great intro into game safari's. Aquila is running a very good service and great value for money, recommended.

Once in a lifetime experience!. If there is one thing that should be on EVERYONES bucket list, it should be seeing the BIG 5! And the best place to see it would be Aquila Private Game Reserve. The rooms are comfortable and the food in wonderful. The experience is child friendly and the staff are very friendly. The tour guides are passionate about what they do and were very knowledgeable. To see the magnificent creatures and so close to Cape Town is a dream come true.
We will come back. The food was excellent, animals were there too, the accomadation was perfect! We will have a good memory of our stay

Wonderfull + Good staff. The trip to Aquilla from cape town is a nice one, in about two hours you drive into the mountains and see the rough lands.The cottage is great and the safari too of course . The park is not humangous but very easy to see all animals. in two hours in the park with a great guide and a sparkling wine stop in the safari park we we happy. good food, nice pool.

Good if it is your first time. Children loved it but don't be fooled this is not a safari experience. Range of animals disappointing and knowable guide kept telling us that more would arriving in 3 months but that seems hard to believe. 2 Cheetahs and only 1 leopard in separate cages and might as well be in a zoo. Lions were a highlight but again in separate enclosure and over weight. Overall the service and food was great. Children loved the buffet. However the animal experience was disappointing but we have experienced Kruger in the past and this is no replacement for that.

4 Kids 2 Adults from UK staying in Cape Town for 12 days. The Good Top score for me and the kids! Aquila is a private game reserve and our first experience of this type. Highly recommended for a family excursion....and not bank breaking at all. Basically we appeared to be virtually guaranteed to see the 'Big 5'. In any event the 3-4 hours or so provided us close up views and photo opportunities with Rhinio, Hippo, Elephant, Lion, Cheetah and Zebra. There were others including the Springbok. Combined with an upbeat driver who truly loved his job.The late lunch that followed was 'man size'. Great staff from initial phone enquiry to gift shop on departure. The BadA long long drive from 7am; 2 1/2 hours rather than 1 1/2 from Constantia, Cape Town, that we were told. Probably because we are not local and drove slow?. Not a bad drive assuming you have driven a hire car in foreign countries before.The UglyThe Osritch....what can I say? ..a perfect experience that left me with no reservations on any front whatsoever!

Excellent experience. Superb experience - It is not a safari, but in order to see big 5 so close to capetown, I can't recommend this Reserve enough. Champagne on arrival, beautiful accommodation, Buffet meals. All included. Exchange rate (17 rand to £) made drinks affordable. Had 5 people in one challet and it was not a squeeze! Animals are well care for in large area, and service was superb

Dreamy. Wonderful people,excellent place, unbelievable view,great safari,unforgettable experience! I stayed two days and done afternoon and morning safari.....just a magical feeling!!!!i would go again so I could do the safari by horse!!!!!!the standard room that I stayed in was unbelievable!!!!

room for improvement. we stayed in the family cottage number 38. When we arrived the toilet downstairs had not been flushed and contained human feces. The underside of the toilet seat and the bidet were dirty. We did not use the bidet during our visit.On the first safari in the afternoon we were unlucky to be allocated to a truck containing a number of american families with young children. I love kids but these were so noisy and their parents so oblivious to the concerns of others that we could hear nothinbg of the commentary from your driver. We asked the driver to speak up but his response was come and sit closer to me (we were a party of 5).The next morning, we specifically asked to be separated from the americans and your manager made sure we were on another bus. the driver and guide was much better than the previous day and was knowledgeable about the animals and spoke up engaging us with eye contact which the previous driver had been unable to do.My daughter got engaged whilst we were there so I ordered a bottle of South African sparkling at over R300. Unfortunately, this was 2008 and had lost most of its sparkle, so after dinner I complained and was given a bottle of house red wine. Sparkling wines must not be stored for extended periods and certainly not 6 years!!!I would never go on your safari again unless you segregate parties with young children from adults. They naturally get excited and noisy and if not disciplined by their parents (as in the case of the americans) just spoil the learning process for us adults.The food in the restaurant was good and the choice above average, but the ease of access for wild birds poses a serious health risk as they were free to feed at the food for human consumption. As a resort, this was a top priced attraction. It simply did not match up to the price paid and I would not recommend it to a friend

Touristic but ok. We had a great stay at Aquila although for a game reserve it is a bit too touristic. Compared with other game reserves it seems that this is a big zoo. The animals are prepared to show up at certain spots - easy to catch them while they are getting their food. For the hundrets of tourists with limited time this might be great, but for people who want to see the animals in a more natural envoirement it's pretty boring. The chalets, the restaurants, pool and the staff are great.

Game for adventure?. Our overnight “safari” at Aquila Private Game Reserve was not quite what we expected, although we are glad we did it. We saw all the “regular suspects”, i.e. lion, Cape buffalo, elephants, rhinos, hippos, plus various others including springbok (springing!!), gnu, antelope, ostrich, giraffe and zebra. However our evening game drive was cold and wet (we were huddled in blankets and ponchos that were provided). The morning game drive was worse – wetter and colder! After a night of heavy rain we woke in the dark to no power in the cabins (a regular occurrence judging by the candles and oil lamp provided). The drive was less than 2 hours as there was not much else to see and we were all anxious to get back to the (excellent) breakfast! Our guide called it “the worst game drive ever”… However, what about the place? Well, Aquila is like a safari park, such as may be found in the US or Europe, on steroids. Of course, what not everyone realizes is that all game reserves are managed, to a greater or lesser extent (somewhat greater in the case of Aquila). Aquila covers a large area of the Karoo and is reasonably green with low bushes and a few trees. It is quite hilly. The animals are wild, but used to humans as they are fed from a truck (of course I would not have wanted to be as close as we were to a rhino that was not used to humans!) The lions are in a large fenced area, so they do not eat the other exhibits (except when an antelope jumps in by mistake)… The lodge is quite nice. We were in the cheapest cabins which were a little basic but with a quite nice bathroom (large tub and outdoor shower for those that like such things). However not all participants were fully prepared for the experience, perhaps taking the “luxury” description of the lodge a little too literally. Our cabin was about 200 yards from the dining room and lounge buildings (both very nice buildings). One lady broke a heel on the semi-paved walkways (don’t bring heels to a safari) and not everyone thought to bring flashlights (we always travel with a flashlight). Our neighbor couldn’t find the matches, and his light source (read, “cell phone”) died as he was getting dressed. He was lost when we found him trying to find reception. The food was very good and plentiful (buffet style). There were some local dishes, Staff were friendly but there was not much management in evidence (i.e. an apology for the lack of power overnight would have been a nice touch). While coffee was available before the morning game drive, there was no one with it to tell us whether the drive was going ahead, until the trucks arrived. Bottom line – do it but don’t expect too much and you will be pleasantly surprised (and maybe it won’t rain…)

Overnight Safari. Visited here whilst in Cape Town for a wedding and wanted to get the safari experience without travelling as far as Kruger. This is a private reserve based 2 hrs drive north from Cape Town in the Karoo desert.We arrived midday for a buffet lunch then checked into our cottage which was very comfortable with Queensize bed, ensuite with corner bath and outside shower! The evening safari started around 4.30 and lasted 3 hrs including a glass of bubbly at sunset. Saw all the usual suspects and in a very wild habitat. The guide was very friendly and informative. Came back for buffet dinner. Lovely food with lots of South African specialities. Much more than we could eat.The following morning we were up early for the sunrise safari starting with coffee and a snack. Although many of the animals in the reserve are not in their natural habitat they seem to be thriving and wander freely over approx. 27 KM. the only exception may be the giraffe who has lost its companions recently and doesn't seem to do well due to the lack of trees.There is a separate centre for some cheetahs and a leopard who are rescued and seen more institutionalised. It was autumn / winter when we visited and early mornings and evenings are quite cold so warm clothes needed- cameras are a must!After the trip it's back for buffet breakfast and check out by 11am, but you can stay and use the facilities- outdoor pools, sun beds, bar etc for as long as you like. We stayed until mid afternoon and were lucky to be able to watch elephants and water buffalo from the poolside.In all a very enjoyable experience, well organised, very helpful polite staff and high standard of facilities. It's not Sabi Sabi or Kruger but you are pretty much guaranteed to see some wildlife so would highly reccommend if you want a taster or are short on time.

Saw what we went for. We stayed in one of the private lodges which with the fireplace gave a very intimate feel to the evening. Obviously not all the animals are native to the exact area however they seemed to manage the needs of the animals with care. It was a good opportunity to see the big 5 and more. Knowing it is a reserve and you wanted to see the animals in a somewhat real natural environment then this will satisfy. The food was buffet style but fine.

Aquilla Review. Accommodation is very comfortable and I just loved the outside shower. The main buildings are beautiful and well maintained - the staff were always exceptionally polite and helpful - well done on the staff training. The food was of exceptional quality - just way too much - I'm afraid we both over ate !The morning game drive was good but the incident with the Rhino charge could have ended in disaster with the 2 vehicles almost colliding in their effort to get away from the Rhino. The afternoon game drive wasgreat and very well presented and the snacks and drinks at the end was a treat. All in all the stay was great and we will be back in the future
Excellent. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at Aquila. congratulations to your staff who were very helpful, always with a smile and ready to be of service.

Great Safari experience for a first timer in Africa. I went on the day safari at Aquila Private game safari. It was a wonderful experience for me as a first time visitor to Africa. I would say this is the best possible way to see the big 5, and extremely convenient for visitors who come to Cape Town and cannot spare time to do a proper safari say something like in Kruger.
Safari. Aqulia Game Reserve met and excceded expectations.. the chicken at lunch was amazing! great was to see the wildlife of Africa.

A good option if you need something close to Cape Town. This is a good option if you have either never been on larger game reserves or only have limited time and want to see the animals in a natural habitat. Our driver was informative and 2 drives would be all I would recommend in a reserve this size. We didn't stay and just did the day trip (morning safari) which was great for my brother as he had never been on a game drive. We did get to see a hippo out of the water which was great. Would be good to see more herds of antelope. The lions do look quite over fed as they are not hunting for themselves. Overall a good experience and helpful people.

On Safari. Great accommodation in one of the cabins, lovely view we could see Elephants from our veranda, friendly helpful staff, we had two safari trips and got to see lots of animals, a great place to visit really enjoyed our stay.

A big zoo. Advertised as a wildlife game reserve, it is actually a big zoo where animals are parked in. Not difficult under the circumstances to "spot" the big 5. It also is a mass tourist catering machine... very far from the real experience. The hotel in itself is ok, simple, nothing more or less. All in all very expensive for what it is

Great experience. We visited Aquila because it was close to Cape Town, the rooms were comfortable and clean, food plentiful and good. The game drives were great for those who have never seen game before, visitors from other countries who want to see them in nature. The guide/driver was informative, friendly and helpful. I would recommend it to those who can't make the trip to the bigger game parks up north. Good for children too.

$$$$ windlers! Horrible waste of time and $$$$!. I hardly ever write reviews, but, three weeks after my trip, I feel obligated to share my impressions to help save others money. For over $$$200USD, you get a great meal, but is that really why you are going? Unless you are up in age and/or your physical movements are inhibited, or you have money to burn for no reason, think twice, then think again, and stay away!!! If you do go, this what you will see at this fake zoo: several leopards houses behind a chain link fence; two elephants; two rhinos; about five hippos; maybe a few zebras; one giraffe because his partner died and, I'm told they've been saying forever that they replace him; one bull; and about five lions, perhaps most exciting part of the Jeep tour because you ride into cage. You won't see or do much more. You will see miles of empty dry land, while the guy prays that you might spot something else for the benefit of his reputation. Speaking with several tourists afterwards, we shared the same belief that this was a rip off!

Wild animal...wow.... Actually I arrange the trip to Aquila is not for a REAL safari experience...which had been mentioned in other review, this is vastly different from the safari you will see in the National Geography Channel... Actually, Aquila has a beautiful scenery and environment, unique cottage, and have a chance for a close contact with wild animals. I had a great vacation at Aquila, stay in the cottage under the sky full of stars, tasty lunch and dinner...and of course, nice experience of game drive...you will have an opportunity to have close view with the animals, which is near to Cape town...a good recommendation for those who dun have too much time to fly to Kruger and for those who just want to have a weekend relax vacation...but if you are seeking for a real and wonderful African safari experience...hmm...you have another choice...

2 day trip with family. We went to Aquila knowing that this was going to be a 'manufactured' safari experience but with two children aged 5 and 9, we didn't want to do the 'real thing' where we would have to wait hours to see an animal. This wax therefore perfect, and enjoyable for the adults too! Two days was perfect, any longer would have been too long.

HIghly recommend for those with short stay in South Africa!. Literally planned a last minute trip to South Africa for a short, first time visit and a safari was high on our list. Luckily, Aquila was recommended by a few friends and we decided o do an overnight so we could catch both an afternoon and morning safari. The good...- The staff were prompt in responding to reservation queries and were very kind and accomodating during our stay. - Our ranger, Alvin! He was very engaging and informative during our safaris and you could tell he loves what he does!- The safari. Hippos, rhinos, zebras, lions, giraffe (yes, only one for now), buffalo, elephants...We saw everything we wanted to within one short afternoon/early evening. The mehhh...- The standard accomodations were decent and the restaurant is only open during select timings.- Wifi connection was spotty but I didn't go out there to check my emails so I was able to survive without internet for a night.In the end, I would definitely recommend for an overnight stay for those who don't have the time to explore bigger reserves.

The Best week end get away. Aquila is a fantastic game reserve within an hour and a half from CT. The set up is beautiful with lovely scenery, the staff are very welcoming and knowledgeable, the accommodation is modern traditional with all the bells and whistles and the food just too divine. Young children are catered for and it's a wonderful family week end get away.
amazing. This was the most incredible experience for us, kids had an unforgettable time. Beyond words how amazing absolutely everything was! We will be back!

One of the highlights of our stay!. Our stay with Aquila Reserve was an unforgettable experience. We have seen the Big 5 and lots of other animals. Very good safari guide. The Standaard Room where we stayed was so nice. The meals were very good. They do everything to make you feel as comfy as possible. It was our first safari ever which made it very special but if you have already done lots of safaris this might not be the place to be.

A peek into wild africa. Nature experience. Close to animals, although not as wild as you might think.We saw the big five, had a spendid safari on arrival day.Nice cabins.A little touristic, with little room for any special requests.Very good safari guide.Buffet food for lunch, dinner and breakfast. Not a big experience.Slow and unmotivated service in the restaurant.OK for 24 hours. A quick way to see game and get a peek into "wild" africa.

A Safari retreat. Aquila is a beautiful place in the Karoo national park. It has beautiful facilities and it is quite pleasant to get away and be in touch with nature. Close to some good vineyards and just about an 1:30 minutes from Cape Town. If you are looking for a good experience of South Africa wild life this is not the place to be, since the safari seems to be in its infancy, there are not too many animals but it looks that it could only get better in time. However if you are in Cape Town, Aquila is the closest place to see wild animals.Our room overlooks the amazing landscape of the reserve and while showering or taking a bath you maybe able to see ostriches, buffalos and even rhinos.Great place to get away with family, partner or friends. Food is very good and so is the service quality. This is almost a constant wherever you go in this beautiful country.

Take a combo safari. I took a day trip to Aquila after a two day conference in Cape Town. Absolutely worth it!Bear in mind that Aquila isn't like the very large African wild life preservation areas (like Kruger National Park). At the same time, it is large enough and as the animals are in a more restricted area, you will have a better chance to see more of them during just one day.Me and my colleague were picked up from our hotel in Cape Town early in the morning and returned there at appr. 5 pm. (We were informed that the pick up time from the was 5:30 a.m., but the minibus arrived only after 6 a.m.) A breakfast and a 2,5/3 hour game drive on a lorry during the morning were very nice. We saw lots of different large animals - hippos, austriches, rhinos, antilopes, zebras, a giraffe, elephants, lions, buffalos... The driver/guide was friendly and had some interesting nice-to-know facts about all the animals we saw. However, the best part of the trip was the quadbike tour we had after the lunch. We were just my colleague, myself and the guide, and we were lucky to see some of the large animals much closer than during the morning ride. The quadbike was easy and really fun to drive, although I had absolutely no previous experience of it. A one day visit to Aquila is not a full scale African safari, but absolutely worth the one day trip from Cape Town!
A ripoff. Really not worth the money. Condition of the lions is terrible. Very much like a zoo, rather than a private reserve.

Escape and adventure. Nice stay, very professional staff, charming location, the room was clean and comfortable. The Safari was very interesting, full of explanations and it surprised us, even if we were there only to show some animals to our little girl.Sadly we couldn't show her the giraffes.

An overnight stay. The short trip we had in Aquila was very rewarding. Even though we ae familar with Kruger National Park it was a good experience with the animals and the game drives were great. We were happy to see the lions in such a large and natural enclosure. The (standard) accommodation was well appointed and quaint. I look forward to seeing a giraffe to accomany the singular one we saw.It is expensive I think for a South African, it would be good to find a creative way to allow return visits from SA citizens on a weeka Rand!.
The big Five. Good accomodation, hospitality & views. Limited amount of wildlife makes > 2-day trip not worthwhile

Well Worth the Visit. A visit to Aquila is well worth the 2 hour drive from Cape Town. Our chalet was comfortable and well-equipped and the premises as a whole are clean and very well maintained. Staff are friendly and helpful and our ranger was knowledgeable and professional. Game viewing was excellent, even exceeding the viewing possible at larger reserves. The only slight improvement we would suggest is that smaller vehicles for game drives would assist with easier viewing and photography. Facilities overall are very good, meals are hearty & plentiful but cannot be described as fine dining. The wine list is poor & lacks a good selection. We would certainly recommend this venue to friends and overseas visitors and would be happy to return for another visit in the future.

Great stay.... Took longer the get there than expected (it was more like 2.5+hrs, from the suburbs) but it was an easy way to see game without extra flights, or a longer trip (which probably would have also made it a lot more expensive) - ours was a brief holiday with 2 young children (aged 2 and 4). There aren't a huge amount of animals, and the enclosures aren't massive so it's guaranteed to see the animals which was what we needed with our children - we knew it wouldn't be like visiting a park in the Kruger...Food was great, plenty of it, and I thought to a pretty good standard (we had lamb in the evening which couldn't have been better) and we and our girls were well looked after (dinner is at 7, our children normally eat at 5-5.30ish, but they were given a snack box when we arrived back from the drive to keep them going) and there was water in the fridge in our room when we arrived there as well as a glass of champagne or sparkling grape juice whilst checking in. The restaurant manager was brilliant with our children too.The accommodation was fine, we had a luxury family chalet which was plenty big enough and did the job for 4 adults, 2 kids.
