We visited the Aquila some years ago and it was quiet private with only 20-30 visitors and a small restaurant and for the size still adequate but already too few animals etc.The new main buildings are very impressive, and caters at least for 200 people but the breakfast was below average and I had better coffee in economy class on an airplane! Lunch was poor but we did not drive 2 hours from Cape Town to eat a gruesome buffet.. or swim in freezing 18C pool!Overall there where at least 5x as many visitors than animals on show!The guide, being very sweet but did not know a thing ( exept the breading cycle) about the 5 kinds of animals on show! It's a shame that they did not add one extra animal over the last 6 years!!If you want to see more game go to fairy glen ( and its 80 km closer to CT)This was definitely our last time at Aquila!

Very nice for overnight stay. We stayed for 2 nights at the end of our Cape Town vacation. It is ideal for families as the safaris are well orchestrated so guest can see all the game the reserve has to offer. The accommodations are more than adequate. We stayed in one of 5 chalets which were rugged with outdoor appeal but luxurious with al fresco shower and hot tub, stone walls, thatch high ceilings, log beams and four poster bed. Had the feel of being in a cabin, but with luxury linens and conveniences. Loved the lodge at sop here. The staff were very accommodating to special requests wnd minor issues, especially the guest relations manager Linette who went out her way to ensure we had an exceptional stay for a special birthday celebration. When our horse safari was shortened because of rain, we were surprised a private one was offered then scheduled for us the next morning before our departure. When I say the staff went above and beyond with South Africa hospitality, I say it with honesty and gratitude for a memorable stay. Well worth the trip. Not a wild safari, but satisfies the curiosity and yearning to see the big 5!

Wow!!!. From the moment we arrived with a glass of champagne, everything was very good. Aquila buildings were all thatched roofs which added to the WOW factor. Our accomadation was lovely with an outside shower which was very unusual. Food was plentiful at all times. Eggs fried while you waited. Safari was good even though we were not on a large area. Tyler our ranger was very passionate about everything and very knowledgable. Half way point for champagne in the bush!!!

NOT - I repeat - NOT a Safari. Having been on a "Proper" safari, I was wasn't expecting much and I wasn't dissapointed. If you're in the market for a safari during your stay in the Western Cape, you'll probably be dissapointed too - you'll see as many animals (probably more) at places like Whipsnade, Longleat, Busch Gardens etc - this is by no stretch of the imagintion a safari as it claims.First the good.The actual resort isn't bad - nice restaurant building, bar / lounge area, pool etc. Breakfast buffet not bad either.The bad.The accomodation - dirty / dusty with nasty sewage smells.The "safari" and game drive. driving around a boring landscape with a few animals dotted about. When I did a real safari at the Selous game reserve, they gad to clear the runway of deer, giraffe & zebras before we could land! Here, there were 2 elephants, 4 rhino, (2 rhino had been shot by poachers.. what type of reserve is this if it doesn't protect its animals???) 1 giraffe (no trees in the park, so adult giraffe have to be taken away as they can't feed from the ground). Most sad (in africa of all places) was the lions in an elecrified pen looking bored, over fed and not living as they should in the wild. The rehabilitation centre was really depressing - all electrified pens - a lone leopard in one, 3 lions in another and 2 cheetah in a third. This is NOT a safari where you see these animals in their native environment. the only positive aspect was because the animals are used to people, they don't run off whe you approach, as they would in the wild.The Ugly.The food - absolutely dire (apart from breakfast) The same stuff was served up for dinner and lunch. Boring selection of tasteless muck. I could really relate to the people I watched circling the buffet over and over hoping something appetising might have appeared since the last tour.The restaurant, despite being nicely fitted out, is like eating in an aviary - with lots of birds flying in and around the tables. If you manage to find a seat without bird mess on it, should you leave your table for any reason, birds would swoop down onto the tables and eat the food! There were also mice running around the tables, hiding under the central stands of the tables.The lazy, disinterested staff made no attempt to remove the birds or stop the birds eating peoples food. I fact, the only time I saw any sign of life from the staff was when I left my table to get some coffee whereupon I was chased after as they thought I was leaving without paying for a bottle of water I ordered (Water is more expensive than beer in this place.... bring your own!)To summarize, If a safari is on your backet list - this should not be it. Go to one of the proper reserves like Selous, Serengeti, Kruger etc etc and see the real thing in all its magnificence and you'll be amazed by the variety and abundance of wildlife.This place is just a tourist trap. Poor value for money and a long way to go to see very little. Not recommended.

Negative reviewers are sadly lost in space. This was great and worth the cheap money.. After reading some reviews here i had mixed feelings of what to expect. Well, after the day trip i took i was pleasantly surprised. Id like to start off by commenting on the negative responses ive read from other reviewers. These people have no idea what the difference between a safari and game reserve is. To start , a safari trip will run you about 1200.00 US dollars per day. On top of that, you'd have to travel a day to get there. This is game reserve where alot of the animals were born on thea premises. Some of the animals have been killed by poachers. Lets not forget, this reserve is 800 acres large, this not a zoo.As far as the lions being caged is just not true. They are however confined to a huge parcel of land and terrain to free roam within a fenced area. The reason they arent released completely yet is because of bordering property owners are still working out details. This is a fairly new reserve it takes time to fill it. Especially if there breeding within the reserve. The cages across from the reserve with cougars are rescued animals that were doomed if not saved. This is a funded project to save animals and i commend Aquila for there rescue efforts.  Id recommend this to anyone who cant afford to see the big 5 in the true wild. This is the next best thing and much safer. I saw the same animals and very close. They were all very healthy and happy. The zebras were plentiful and amazing. The rhinos were very active and playful.

Zoo Experience, not safari. It was of course wonderful to see animals up so close but it wasn't what you'd call a safari but a drive through zoo. The service and explanations from the tour guide were great but one was left to wonder when he told us that three quaters of their girraffes had died on their premises. Why they had decided to breed animals in an environment that was not all adapted to the animals was a mystery and another reason this place is a zoo rather than a safari. It was an expensive visit and we opted to drive ourselves there, for those arriving in the morning on a one day visit do take advantage of thebuffet breakfast being served. The ticket only mentions refreshments on arrival and lunch, but apparently you are welcome to breakfast.The tour although has nice touches like stopping in the middle to stretch your legs, gaze at the animals and have a glass of sparkling wine. So you know they do try.

Day trip experience review. I visited Aquila Game Reserve with my wife for a day trip on December the 27th 2012 and we had a fantastic experience.For those who are considering paying the extra to be picked up from Cape Town I’d highly recommend doing the drive yourself, it’s a very simply route effectively on one road the whole way there and can easily be completed in two hours. The directions provided on the website are concise and all that you need, no Sat Nav required.Based on some of the reviews here I feel that people need to go to Aquila with the realistic expectations. Aqula Game Reserve is just that, a private game reserve. If you are expecting/want a safari trip through the untamed outback then this is not for you.If you wish to see the big 5 (& far more besides) in an environment that is as close as possible to natural then you should certainly give Aquila a try. The pricing is reasonable, the guide that we had was highly knowledgeable about all of the animals in the park and the tour itself lasted for just over two hours.Aquila is a managed park, the area is large, the animals are not penned in and are free to roam wherever they wish. Due to strategically placed watering holes they tend to congregate in certain areas which the drivers know well and take their guests to.For the price of a day trip you will receive a buffet breakfast upon arrival, a two hour driven tour and a buffet lunch upon your return (two meals also included in the afternoon session). I felt that the food was not of the highest quality, edible certainly, but none the less quite a disappointment considering the rest of the service provided.Overall this was a great experience for us, the whole park is well run and the staff were very friendly, go with the right expectations and we feel that you will enjoy your visit, 4 stars.

False advertising - this is not a game reserve but a zoo!. My daughter has just left Aquila yesterday and was so disappointed! She saved money to go back to South Africa and take a friend to show her how amazing Cape Town is and take her on a safari. Aquila included 4 game drives in the 2 night package - well they did not bother to go on the last two drives. They were so shocked by being driven to see animals in cages and the only other animals were 2 elephants, 2 buffalo, 1 giraffe - this is not a safari!!! Shocking - they should not be able to advertise game drives and safaris - real safaris in South Africa are amazing - this is nothing like the real thing!!

Poor Poor and Poor waste of Money. The Bus Picked us up on time, the overall theme for the game reserve is a con, more like Noahs Ark, waiting for the Animals to arrive, 2 lions, 1 Giraffe, a couple of Rhinos 3 Elephants does not make a game reserve, it was expensive by SA standards, including refreshments, if you wanted a drink with your meal you had to pay for it, at 2350.00 Rand per person for a day trip is expensive, be prepared to be disappointed, if you have children, you would be better off taking them to Boulders Beach, there are a lot more Penguins there to see, Would I recommend it NO NO and NO, Big 5 game reserve _ laughable, BIg 5 in my mind is more then 5 animals, they should be had up under the trade discription act if there is one in SA, would like my money Back as I feel it is a very expensive CON.

Nice Zoo, but not a real Game Reserve. I did a day safari trip to Aquila Game Reserve and was already warned by the reports in Tripadvisor etc. that it is not like an usual Safari in a Game Reserve but more like a Zoo – and this is reality: yes you see 2 elephants, 2 rhinos, some buffalos and impalas/springboks. But the lions, leopards, cheetahs are all in cages so it is really like a Zoo in a nice surrounding.The food at the restaurant is of bad quality and the service as well is bad if not inexistent.Overall an alternative for someone who never did a Safari before, for others a hit and miss – otherwise you will be disappointed.

Didn't know what to expect, but were impressed. My father and I went there and had no pre conceived expectations good or bad. When we arrived we were greeted with champagne or juice. We then were happy to see our accommodations. It was very relaxed. A little chilly though so I recommend bringing a jacket and hat. We then did a couple jeep tours and were thrilled with the animals and the closeness at which we were able to get. Overall the tour, service, accommodations, and overall feel was great! It is the closest thing to a safari if you are in Cape Town. The next closest place is Kruger national park.

Very cool West cape safari via jeep, horse, and Atv close to Capetown. Enjoyed my two days there. The guides took us to every inch of the reserve seeing everything. The traditional African food was good in home style pots. The cabin was rustic but fitting for the experience. Sat in the lodge each morning and watched the elephants playing in the water. Also lodge pool was refreshing after a hot day in the bush. Not as big as Kruger and not as many animals either but I would go back in a second. Easy drive from Capetown. Good value.

Very poor. The amount of R1400 per person I thought was an absolute rip off and scam, when you concider what you got for your money. The breakfast was very ordinary and the lunch was sub-standard with bits of meat floating in a fatty watery stew, when we went on the game drive, our game driver was below adequate, hardly knowing what he was talking about, I thought the fact that most of the big five cats and crocodiles were in cages disgusting, they did not look in good shape and I would not recomend Aquila to anyone. It was a rather expensive zoo as opposed to a game park!!!! Perhaps if you spent the obvious profit you make on a daily basis to educating your staff and rangers properly and looking after your animals better it would have been a different scenario

Wonderful safari in the Western Cape. Not many people recommended Aquila when we asked in Cape Town but our thought is not to miss a Private Safari in Aquila. We arrived late so we missed the lunch and the evening game drive. To our surprise, the head Ranger offered a private safari tour the next morning at 6:30 versus heading out with the group morning safari. It turned out to be the highlight of our trip (We had already visited Cape Town, Table Mountain, Camps Bay Beach, Winelands, Cape of Good Hope Drive, Boulders Beach, and Chapmans Peak Drive.) We had Timothy as our guide and he took us for a 2 hour adventure in the game reserve which was perfect! We did not have to spend 4 DAYS to see the big 5 plus no yellow fever shot needed or malaria tablets. Timothy was so knowledgeable and made our private safari an experience to remember. He also took us to the Conservatory to pet the leopard-what a treat! Thank you Aquila and thank you Timothy!

Excellent Substitute For A Safari. My friend and I just returned from a five full days on our first trip to Africa. This day trip was an excellent, doable substitute for a true safari. We drove ourselves in a rented car for the very beautiful drive on a freeway comparable to most of our US interstates. Schedule was leave Cape Town 7:15 am, check-in 9:15 am, included breakfast and walk around lodge then meet at truck in parking lot for 10:15 am departure with guide. Ride in open truck around game reserve until noon then included lunch with drinks not included. Return drive to Cape Town at 1:00 pm.Guide was knowledgeable and patient and entire group got into the experience. Don’t forget the sunscreen even though there is canvas cover over seating. Game reserve is in herd building phase but has adequate if not overwhelming numbers of South Africa’s wildlife. More than a zoo but less than a safari – and no mosquitoes (malaria) which is a definite positive.

Two Days at Aquila. We recently spent two nights and two days at Aquila as part of a tour of the western Cape. While it is not a wild game safari where you spend days looking for the animals in the wild, it is indeed a great wildlife experience. Our guide for the first safari was not that great. But we asked to head ranger about going to the rescue center across the road and she was very surprised that we had not been there. After that we were put with Daniel, who was absolutely amazing in his knowledge of the animals and their behavior. In the second drive we saw four of the big five. While we had seen the lions at the watering hole in the morning, in the afternoon they were moving up into the hills where they hunt at night. Daniel was very agressive in getting us as close as possible to them. Likewise, he was very good and getting the elephants close to us and telling us a lot about their habits. The next morning he took us to the rescue center. We were actually able to pet the cheetahs there. As a cat love, it was a great thrill. So no, we did not see herds of animals stampeding across the plains, but we got up close and personal with most of them. It makes for great photos. The hotel is "rustic chic" if there is such a term. The entire facility is very environmentally friendly and all power is solar power, so recommend taking a shower at the end of the day when the sun has provided lots of hot water. Otherwise, it might be a quick cold shower in the morning. It was very cold when we were there so a cold outdoor shower is a fast shower. The food was mediocre in the dining room. The breakfast was good but lunch and dinner seemed to be repetitive. I, too, would suggest an a la carte menu for overnight guests. All in all, our first trip to South Africa was great and Aquila and the animals were a highlight for me. They do need to improve the selection in the gift shop.

Ok as a taster. Lovely drive through the mountains from Cape Town. Buffet breakfast and lunch good our little waitress very helpful. The two pools looked inviting and the lounge bar very colonial and comfortable. The shop did not have a great selection but the accommodations looked ok from the outside. This is NOT a proper safari and UK visitors will know what I mean by Longleat meets Wild at Heart. My 15 year old Grandaughter loved it and on the plus side you were able to see all the animals unlike a true safari which of course by its very nature is truly hit and miss. Yes the viewing was very contrived and I am not sure I liked the small pens or the poor lonely giraffe with her 'who am I' look. It was good to see elephants, springbok, eland, rhinos, zebra and even little giraffe up close and the obligatory champagne was most welcome. Our guide/driver was fairly knowledgable but we were a little concerned about the flat tyre especially in the Lion's enclosure - we survived. If you are looking for true back to nature then this place is not for you. If you just want to see animals in a semI natural habitat and you don't have much time then why not!

A most memorable stay and a good value. It's most certainly one of the best compromise to experience the wildlife between Kruger Park and a private reserve. The setting is spectacular, and the staff is very nice and helpful.The bungalows are somewhat rustic, there's not much light in the bathrooms but all in all they remain comfortable.The all you can eat buffet is abounding with a vast array of good food. Yet showing little variation. Should you stay longer than 2 days, you'll get the same choice over and over.The safari in itself will disappoint those who already are seasoned safari goers, as they may describe Aquila like a zoo. I beg to differ as it's still very spred out, and a perfect initiation to the profanes who have less time to go in the wild. Kruger Park for instance is so huge that you need to stay at least 3 days. It takes between 5 and 6 hours by car from Joburg. Unlike Aquila that's less than 2 hours from Cape Town, and where you can enjoy a wonderful sample of the wildlife.That's why I think it doesn't really compare but offers the best of a private reserve.

A magical family time. We really enjoyed our time at Aquila. The accommodation was rustic, but fun. We travelled in October so it was cold, but the resort had fires burning in the restaurant and lounges, and the rangers came to light one in our room just before bedtime. The safari was well run and very informative. Our guide, Abriel was friendly, chatty and very knowledgabe about all the animals we saw and patiently answered all of our 7 year olds questions..We saw elephants, rhino, buffalo, rhino, zebra, springbok, giraffe, eland and hippos. The previous reviewers criticism that some animals were caged is ill informed as this is the seperate consevation centre and the leopard, cheetah and lions here have been rescued and cannot be returned to the wild as couldn't fend for themselves .All in all a great experience, enhanced by a beautiful South African backdrop and some very friendly hosts.

Beautiful animals, not really wild though. Against all promises from various sides, the wild cats (lions, leopards and cheetahs) were caged. Not only were they caged, but the cages are almost smaller than in my hometown zoo. The tour through the actual reserve was rather touristy. We drove for an hour (and saw elephants, buffalos, rhinos, zebras and other animals) and then stopped in the middle of nowhere in order to have a glass of champagne?! The other people probably enjoyed it, but I thought it was extremly annoying to spend 30 min of a 2.5 h tour with drinking champagne. I just wanted to see the wild and the animals, but everything was mainly about breakfast, lunch and the mentioned champagne. Very disappointing to me at least.

Nice for day trip, ok for overnight. We had an overnight stay, which included breakfast, lunch & supper, an afternoon game drive & morning horseback safari. The staff were friendly throughout our stay and always willing to assist. We had an excellent guide on our game drive. Due to the smallish nature of the reserve, we got to see the animals quite close which was great, but to counter that you always seem to have the lodge in sight, so you don't get that true safari feeling. The horseback safari was also a very good experience, although we didn't get much feedback from the guides this time & you cover the same area as the game drive, only less of it. The accomodation was average and looks like it needed a bit of freshening up. The food in the restuarant was nothing special, but being a buffet, there was a good enough variety.

Pathetic and Disorganised. I will mostly certainly NOT recommend Aquila Private Game Reserve to anyone, let alone tourists!My first visit to this establishment was in 2009 - the experience was a rather pleasant one - I had booked a day trip (Game Drive / Safari) for 3 people which included breakfast, game drive & lunch. My guests were impressed with every facet of the package (maybe except for lazy, sleepy Lions) & left in high spirits & enriched by their experience.I was treated very well not having joined in for the safari - gee I wanted to bring out friends, family & business partners to witness & experience what i had & suggested overnighting for an even better experience.Fast forward to 2012 - many people worth there salt in the tourism industry had warned me off Aquila with a mixture of personal experiences & anecdotes why I should not take tourists there. I was told it was a rip-off, service was poor & the place was disorganised. I countered that my experience had been a good one & would not believe it. I took some tourists to Inverdoorn in February this year for an overnight safari & told them the next day, upon being asked which establishment I would have chosen, without hesitation I said Aquila even though the service & experience at Inverdoorn had been a good one.Well - my perceptions & long-held view was knocked for a six today. DISORGANISED, RUDE, CONTEMPTIOUS & UNPROFESSIONAL (manager shouting a staff in front of clients just does not do it for me) are the words that come to mind. I could not believe how bad it was or had become -obviously aggressive marketing is probably the reason for folk wanting to experience Aquila. I will not be returning or promoting this place for the foreseeable future to any clients, family or friends as it is a rip off...

family fun. A not to distant scenic drive from CPT. Reception, game rangers and staff are very helpful and polite. Halaal food was available at the restaurant for all meals, incl hot breakfast. It was too cold for swimnning but there was enough other activities to keep us busy. Spacious suites, fresh crisp linen, with Lovely oversized bed which allowed all my kids to snuggle up in bed with the bedroom fire killing the chill in the room. There was sufficient heaters, even in the bathroom which made the frosty nights pleasant and comfortable. It is a holiday destination I would recommend for family holidays. I recommend that you take a warm winter cap, gloves, jackets and neck scarf with on the game drive, especially the evening drive that start when temps are higher and ends when temps drop very low. I however wish there would be more activity suited for the 10-15 year category.

A worthy day trip. If you enter with appropriate expectations, this can be a good day trip. If you're looking for wild game roaming the bush of Africa, this isn't the best place. From what I can ascertain, there aren't many of those places left. If you find such a safari, it is unlikely that you will see all the animals you want; it will be more expensive and it will be much more remote, not just a couple of hours from a major city like Cape Town. I went to Aquila because I had one day to get out of town during a hectic three week working tour of South Africa. I couldn't go back to the US without some photos and a chance to see the countryside. It was a nice day, bouncing around and looking at animals who are living more or less in the wild but are used to people. They feed the animals just before the tour so they know where to find them. They are busy eating so they stand still for pictures. They are wild enough that they act out - like the elephant who went to beat up the rhinos who got too close. But they were tame enough that we could get pretty close and we weren't terrified by any attacks by wild animals. The welcome was standard but warm enough. Our driver clowned a little and made us laugh in an endearing way. We took a break for a glass of wine mid-trip (but no bathrooms after you leave the lodge). Though the site seems to say that lunch is part of the deal, it isn't. I got a nice buffet breakfast for no extra charge but paid for lunch. The price was reasonable, just unexpected.

Disappointed and overrated. It's obvious our experience isn't the same as most as we recently spent a night at this much publicised Game Reserve. We are frequent travellers and welcomed the opportunity to compare Aquila with other private game reserves we've visited. Welcome was great but reception staff not entirely professional. We had to make our own way to Chalet 19 which was not signboarded as there was no-one available to guide us there. Chalet was shabby and in need of a revamp, no chair available in the room, dirty kettle, spare duvets smelly and soiled, tissue box only had 2 tissues, great having wood in fireplace plus candles but no matches. Buffet dishes, whilst traditionally African and well presented, were mainly without flavour. Fortunately, our game rangers, game drive and horseback safari were fantastic. Glad we've been but won't be back.

Great guide, beautiful surroundings, weather sensitive. We opted for a day safari arriving with our own transportation. The premises was gorgeous. I remember thinking it would have been nice to spend the night in one of their bungalows. Service outstanding. They had a little playground for kids and a swimming pool we intended to make use of after the safari, unfortunately the weather was coldish and damp. It was a bit disappointing (though reassuring since we had a 3 year old with is)that the animals were so used to the vehicles. I had this expectation that a safari would be exciting, but it felt like we were driven around a zoo leaving little, if any, feeling of wilderness. Our guide Sam was outstanding. Sharing information, getting the group to actively participate with his wit. I was a bit surprised to find the (few) encaged animals to be in confounded space when seemingly there was a vast emptiness surrounding that area.

An incredible experience. As a private reserve I was happily surprised to see much more animals than I had expected. We only had a shrt time in SA so a big safari was out of the question but this experience definitely satisfied my curiosity. It was my highlight of SA

Great introduction to wildlife with quality accommodation. Firstly do be be aware your are not going on safari in the Kruger! Aquila is a private game reserve catering for visitors who want to experience a taste of wildlife close at hand, easily and comfortably. This was my first visit to SA, I was limited for time but eager to see the Big Five, plus other wildlife, close to Cape Town (malaria free), while enjoying quality accommodation and 1st class service - and Aquila did not disappoint! The facilities are superb, we stayed in a lovely chalet where we could hear lions at night, the restaurant and meals were great - plus we could watch 10 different species from our table. The lodge, lounge and pool areas were lovely and all staff were helpful and friendly - plus it was great value as we went in low season. A great introduction to wildlife - with comfort and hospitality! Do bring your binoculars - you see lots of wildlife close up on the game drive, but it was amazing what we could watch simply sitting eating our meals!

Get a Private Chalet if you can.... We came here with a Groupon (as did others) and it was a real treat. We stayed in the Orion chalet which is a bit cold in the winter considering half the building is made of stone. A ranger will light a fire for you in the evening (if you ask) and there are several radiant heaters to help with the chill. There were also extra blankets and I slept cozily. There is a tub in the bathroom with a shower extension as well as an outdoor shower. Don't let the middle of winter deter you from using the outdoor shower. Other guests encouraged me to give it a try and I'm glad I did for a memorable experience. The buffet had a wide array of food options and you certainly won't go hungry. Drinks are not included (except coffee, tea and juice at breakfast). While we were here we went out on three jeep tours and once on horseback. The rangers are knowledgeable (try to get Daniel if you can) and they do their best to make sure you see a wide array of animals. Yes, it's a game reserve and not a "real" safari but it was still enjoyable and I saw lots of animals in the open. Don't skip the horseback ride or the rehab center where I got to pet a cheetah.

Wonderful Location, OK Accommodation.. We travelled to Aquila Private Game Reserve whilst on holiday in South Africa. We stayed for 2 nights here. It is a wonderful drive from Cape Town through breath taking countryside. It takes about 2/3 hours. We arrived and saw what we were expecting. A typical, African style hut building (modern) which looked fantastic in front of the mountains and country. We checked in and walked through the resort to our 'villa'. The room was small, but for two people was fine. It was hygienic and there were beverages on the desk next to some matches and a wood fire, should we choose to light it. The beds were comfortable, and with the silent surroundings, the quality of sleep was fantastic. The bathroom was surprisingly modern. The toilet was clean, and there was a large indoor bathtub or an outdoor shower with 4 walls and no roof. There was buffalo right outside our door, but behind a fence which was always a surprise when we left in the morning. Breakfast and dinner is all included and is a buffet. the dining room is lovely, typically African but modern. Air conditioning and glass windows. The food is mediocre. Not fantastic and we found that some food is left for a while before being taken away and new food put out.The Safari was great, however I would strongly advise you wrap up warm. Extra clothing is provided but it can become extremely cold. Also, use the toilet before you leave! We saw all the animals I wanted to see including Lions, Rhinos, Hippos, Zebras, Gazelles and many more. There's always great photo opportunities. It was a great experience I would certainly stay again if ever in this part of the world.

Pleasant Day Trip. I was in Cape town for a conference and decided to do the full-day safari at Aquila reserve--about two hours outside of Cape Town. We traveled by bus to Aquila. The lodge we arrived at was delightful. The staff greeted us with glasses of sparkling wine or juice. After checking in, we were given breakfast. Teh dining room was graced with large fireplaces with fires--a much needed treat on a cold morning. wewent on a game drive and saw a variety of animals in the wild and heard tragic stories of rhinos inthe reseve poached for their horn.  I was a little disappointed to realize the "full day" ended at 2:00 pm. Our guide wanted us to be ready to return to Cape Town around 2;30 pm. so we could be back in Cape town between 4:40-5:00 pm. I have visited several animal reserves over the past few years, so I know that each one has its own flavor. One should be wary of comparing one reserve to another--each is it's own experience. I enjoyed Aquila and what it had to offer--plenty of animals, interesting scenery. All-in-all visiting Aquila was a very pleasant day trip.

Better than a zoo. I was surprised to read the positive reviews here,, as our experience was average enoughWe enjoyed our trip to Aquila, it was magical to see the animals up close, and definitely better than any zoo.However there are some things to be aware of...-the accommodation is quite basic, and it was very cold when we were there (my son pointed out that it was the winter though!), and didn't feel very clean. There were mice pellets on the floor, not ideal as we had a toddler- the food was adequate, but not excellent. Breakfast was ok, dinner was fine, but lunch not great. All buffet style food, cold and lots of flies- The bar wasn't very clean, and a mouse ran across the floor in front of our table- there wasn't much for kids to do when not on the game drives. The website advertised kids quad bikes, but they didn't exist, and the children play room wasn't well maintained or equipped, which was a pityThe game drives were great, provided you don't mind the fact that the game are fenced in. It didn't bother us, it was still lovely to see them roaming around. The evening felt more authentic than the morning one, which felt a little staged since the animals had just been fed. However the morning drive was quite magical, to be in a beautiful setting at sunriseWe did enjoy the game experience, but a day trip would have been a better option for us, as we didn't find the accommodation to be of a great standard.If Aquila had a little face life and improved the facilities, it would be great, As it stands i couldn't recommend it as a hotel. -

Aquila Game Reserve South Africa. The Aquila tour starts in Cape Town and after a journey of about 2 hours you arrive at the reserve, the group i travelled with were met with either glasses of sparkling wine or juice, after this pleasant relaxing time we were invited in to partake of breakfastwhich was very filling, we then departed on our 'safari', we saw all the animals we had expected tp see, Elephants, Rhino,Hippo, Giraffe ,Lion' Gnu as well as eland, springboks and many types of birds, half way through the tour we went into a small glade where we were met by other staff with more sparkling wine or soft drink, I thought this was a very civilised way to conduct a safari, after a couple of hours we went back to the main buildings where we we served a sumptuous lunch. After a suitable interval for some relaxation we were driven back to Cape Town and delivered to our hotels. I thoroughly recommend this tour for those whose budget does not run to Kruger or one of the very big game parks. As a guide I would say that 8.5 out of 10 was warranted.

One of my best experiences in Cape Town. I'm in Cape Town for work and don't have time to go to Kruger or any of the "big safaris," so this was a great way of at least getting a taste of it in one day. One of my best experiences in Cape Town!I was picked up at my hotel at 7 a.m. (thankfully I was the last person picked up, so I didn't have to be in the car while they collected the other six people from hotel to hotel). The driver (Haymi) was very friendly and professional, knew lots of interesting and fun facts all the way to the reserve. Once there, we had 20 minutes for breakfast, not particularly great but I wasn't there to eat. Getting into the safari vehicle was a bit messy. Basically, just pick whichever car you want. Two tips:1. They have big and smaller cars, the smaller ones are more comfortable and you're much more likely to seat in the window sides and get better pictures.2. You can also seat with the driver, which is great for pictures and to ask questions.The driver (Daniel) was very nice and really made an effort to make sure we got to see all "Big Five," plus giraffe, zebras, etc. The elephants were high in the mountain for a while, but he kept an eye and we ended up seeing them walk by our car. He drove for quite a bit to find the buffalos and we eventually ran into a couple of them. We followed the rhinos for a bit and it was great to see them run. We also saw lots interesting things (the lions mating, the buffalos butting heads over the food, one rhino taking a gigantic leak, the zebras militarily following their leader in a line, etc.).Lunch was not great either, sort of cold, dessert was great. Drinks are NOT included in the package, so you have to pay for your coke, water, tea, etc.Overall, definitely worth the money.

How to lose a staggering amount of money in no time.. We went to Aquila for a Safari. We were picked up at the hotel and had to get up at 6 a.m. in the morning, With our excitement it was natural to do so, however, once we learned that more people from other hotels had to be picked up yet, the mood went down. Other people were late and we arrived 3 hours later in an uncomfortable bus to the safari area of Ceres. It was bitterly cold and the Aquila safari staff would happily invite us to buy a jacket. For the money spent, I better didn't freeze, so ok. We then learned that the ostrich farm was under construction and would not be included anymore. The compensation we had to ask for ourselves was an independent trip to a farm far away on another day, what a ridiculous voucher offer! We didnt want to spill our good hopes and fair mood, so we had the free breakfast on site. Before we arrived, they already started cleaning up and rushing us to get on the safari wagon. Many people were on the wagon, so it didnt seem to have a personal touch. We saw 4 of the Big 5, but everything was rather disappointing because the animals were so far away. We had far better seeings and views on other trips in zoos, or even in the wild for free. The Aquila safari was not wild, so even the animals looked like animals from the zoo, but just very far away. The lunch was ok, but we had to rush back already, 3 more hours on the bus back to Cape Town. What a wast of money! We paid 4000 Rand, an amount you could do so many more nice things for in and around Cape Town! I would rather spend the money on things like the Peninsula drive, winelands, the aquarium and great lunches and dinners.

Wonderful experience. I work at a guest house and went on a day safari to get first hand experience of the reserve in order to be able to promote it to my own guests. We had an absolutely wonderful day. The breakfast and lunch were PLENTIFUL and tasted great. We had a three hour game drive and enjoyed it so much. There are not many of each animal but the viewing is of a high quality. All the animals were very close to the vehicle and the guide even had to reverse when one of the elephants tried to touch the vehicle!! I will definitely recommend Aquila to anyone.

Excellent experience!. I did a day-trip safari today and LOVED it! It is for you if:-- you are a four-star hotel kind of person-- want a taste of safari, but not sure you're down for the 10-day hard core version-- would be thrilled to see elephants, zebras, lions, and other animals up close without cages.Food was plentiful and great (breakfast and lunch included), liquor was very inexpensive (compared to USA), environment top-notch, service ultra friendly.They will pick you up from and bring you back to Cape Town. My pickup was at 7:30 am with return around 5:30pm. Really a fabulous day I had today!

Day Safari. I am very impressed with the service we received at Aquila. My 16 year old daughter and friend went on a 3 hour game drive and saw "the big five". We chose the self drive option, a game drive which included a light breakfast and lunch. The guide was great, the food of excellent quality and on the day we saw all the animals! We even saw lions mating.The only drawback was the price, as locals we found it a tad expensive.

Excellent Game Reserve. We booked a luxury family lodge to accommodate the size of our group. It wasn't luxurious but most definitely adequate and clean. Extremely comfy beds and bed linen. Worthy of 4 stars. The food had a very homemade feel about it which fitted in with the surroundings, nothing fancy but good quality, all seemed very hygienic. We stayed for one night which included 2 safaris, both were amazing. We couldn't believe how close we got too the animals. On the morning drive we actually woke up a pride of lions who came down from there mountain rock ledge and stretched and yawned yards away from our jeep. We loved sitting on the sun loungers by the pool and watched herds of zebra and various other wildlife. On the morning we left 2 elephants entertained us for about an hour as we sat around the pool. I'd highly reccomend at visit to Aquila.

A must visit!. If you do not visit this Game Reserve while in the Western Cape, you have not seen anything. I am a dual citizen of South Africa and Canada. Last month, my good friends from Toronto and I went to Cape Town and visited the Reserve. I have travelled almost all the places in the world that I ever want to see, and have never experienced something this beautiful. The way the guide related to, and loves the wildlife is something to behold. The patience of the first guide who was trying to teach us to use the quadbikes for our first part of the tour. The accomodation was nothing short of spectacular and the food..... oh my word, the food. It was too lovely and the service matched the food. Thanks guys, you made this South African very proud. We will be back. All the five stars in the Caribbean, Europe, Africa and North America can learn something from your team. Angela Schuller.

Birthday gift day safari. I booked a day safari at Aquila private game reserve for my husband & I as a recent birthday gift from me to him. The weather was overcast. Our guide on the safari vehicle was excellent - proficient in English (even though it was not his first language), very knowledgeable and passionate about wild animals. He answered all questions and knew his subject well. When it started to rain, a special delivery of rainjackets were brought to us all in the reserve, on quadbikes (nice touch). Pity we didnt get to see buffalo & leopard. Few animals species on the reserve. Great interaction with elephant. After the game driver the restaurant was very busy - we has to wait a long time for a waiter to take our drinks order & I had to eventually call for assistance. Great selection of delicious, good quality food & fabulous red wine.

Once in a lifetime family experience.. We just returned from a family trip to South Africa and it was awesome. One of the highlights of our vacation was most definitely a few days spent at Aquila Private Game Reserve. It was an easy and enjoyable drive about 2 hours outside of Cape Town. We are a family of 4 including an 8 year old daughter and a 3 year old son. Straight from the get go upon arrival the service was friendly and inviting. The staff was everywhere and made our trip wonderful and easy with the kids, something we feel is critical when we have our kids with us. We started with a swim in the resort pool which makes you feel as though you are swimming in the wilderness. The food was buffet style and of a very high calibre, and there was a huge selection, appetisers, entrées and dessert. Breakfast was the real treat though, every breakfast indulgence you can imagine. Nothing beats fried eggs on home-made toast and boerewors while looking out on the African sunset! We enjoyed a number of game drives where we saw the big 5 which simply put, blew my kids minds. We got to track elephants and see them behave in their natural habitat. We got up close as is allowed to Rhino’s which were incredible. In addition to the big 5 we saw a big variety of other animals, some quite exotic like the Blue Wildebeest. The safari drive did not feel canned at all and the ranger that escorted us definitely knew what she was doing. My family and I would highly recommend Aquila Private Game Reserve to everyone, and we will certainly return in the future. Brett Sandler, Vancouver Canada.

A great way to see the big five. Just 2 hours away from one of the most beautiful cities in the world, Cape Town. The rooms on the hillside are perfect for a romantic weekend with the actual bathroom built into the rock face and a fireplace in the rooms.Stunning views and complete privacy from neighbouring chalets. We went on two safari's. One being the vehicle, which was okay but the next morning we went on the horseback safari which was what blew us away! No experience needed! Staff are very friendly and helpful.The food is absolutely amazing! It's a buffet for every mealtime, so no restrictions on how much you want to eat. We went in the winter months and it does get cold. But if you do go in the summer, there is a stunning swimming pool and play area for the kids. Definitely worth the money.

Great Family Weekend. Stayed at Aquila with my family and we really enjoyed it! This was actually already the third game reserve I have visited and it was the nicest one. We were welcomed very warmly and the public areas as well as the cottage we had were nice and clean.The buffet was big and delicious, unfortunately they had almost the same food on both days (we spent two nights there) which was a bit boring. Our guide was nice and knowledged. The game drives were interesting and we saw all the animals we wanted to (except for the leopard). We even went on a trip with the quad bikes in the game reserve which felt intense, being so close to the animals and it was a lot of fun. If you are looking for a game reserve near Cape Town I would definitely go there.

South African's First Safari trip. Me and a friend had booked a trip to Aquila , as even though we both south Africans we actually have never yet been on a safari before.So we decided now was the time , on arrival at the gate we already felt so welcome and got handed a warm refreshing towel (which was such a thoughtful gesture after our almost 2 hour ride to the reserve) and of course welcoming bubbly on arrival too.We were then escorted to the cigar lounge area were we enjoyed a small continental breakfast of croissants , muffins , tea , coffee and juices before the start of our game drive. Our game drive lasted almost approximately 3 hours and it was just fantastic! We had the best ranger ever: Winston, he explained every detail of the reserve to us as well as supplied us with some interesting facts and general knowledge of the animals in the reserve. I think we came the perfect time of the year as all the animals were out we saw giraffes , Zebras , buffalo , lions , hippos , elephants and many more. After our magnificent game drive we enjoyed a wonderful buffet lunch ( a truly African cuisine) in there amazing animal themed restaurant absolutely mind blowing. This is when we decided that we could not only come for the day we had to experience this wonderful reserve in all it has to offer and decided to spend the night there.We got a fantastic room ( the honey moon cabin) wow what a room! Had that perfect cabin feel, with a wood fire light for us , bath and Jacuzzi and a very comfortable bed and not to forget to mention the incredible view of the reserve. We proceeded to have our evening game drive (which was just as fantastic as the morning drive as we got to see the animals we never really saw up close we got to have that experience. After our drive we were treated to a wonderful buffet dinner laid out by the staff, there was so much food I can’t even begin to type it all out! An all in all wonderful experience, I want to personally thank all the staff and management team at Aquila you really made us feel really welcome and provided excellent guest service! We will most indefinitely be back!

Great family getaway. If you look at your experience at this beautiful place as game reserve and not a huge national park (like the Kruger) you are in for a fantastic experience. The staff were very helpful and friendly and the accommodation was superb! (we were in the honeymoon chalet) There is something magical about sitting in the jacuzzi overlooking the game reserve that takes your breath away! You are likely to see most of the big 5, because of the reserve's size, but having said that, seeing the lions feed was jaw dropping and an experience we will never forget, we have been to the Kruger national park and have not experienced anything like that before! We had our 2 year old son with us and he loved every second of it, there is even a huge kids playground and putt putt area to keep them entertained. Thanks Aquila for an unforgettable stay.

ROBBED AT AQUILA. My wife and i stayed at Aquila for one night on 19 April 2012 and had a great time, but as we were to leave the following morning after the game drive and subsequent breakfast she discovered that her credit card and some cash were missing from her handbag which was left in our LOCKED cottage as we assumed that we would be safe from crime at this luxury lodge.There was no signs of forced entry and it was mutually accepted that a key was used to gain entry to our cottage.In spite of living in South Africa my wife has never been the victim of crime and was visibly upset.The police was called and i had to postpone a meeting in Cape Town as she had to submit a statement and after this travelled to Worcester (a nearby town) to have her other cards inspected for fingerprints by a forensic office as these were shuffled by the criminal who was obviously only in search of her credit card.Aquila management were reluctant to disclose how many of these incidents have happened in the past, but it is obvious that this was not an isolated incident as the police confirmed other cases.In spite of the inconvenience and trauma to my wife, Aquila management has made no attempt whatsoever to contact us to even offer an apology or update us on the investigation.Please let this be a warning to all that even Aquila Private "Luxury" Game Reserve cannot guarantee that you will not become a victim of crime, and if you do, they will show no compassion.

Cool experience. My wife and I stayed at Aquila for one night as part of our 10th anniversary trip to Cape Town. We were upgraged to a luxury chalet which we greatly appreciated that was absolutely beautiful. The game drives we went on were very cool. We saw several different animals and were able to get very close to elephants and lions. The people commenting about it being more of an amusement park or a zoo...it's a game preserve, it isn't Kruger. As far as I am aware this is about as close as you'll get to seeing wildlife in their natural environments anywhere near Cape Town. We had a great time here. I would highly recommend doing the overnight stay, the sunset was beautiful and the view of the stars after dark was amazing.

Disappointing. After a 6.30 pickup the supposedly 2hr trip took 4 hrs after other pick ups. We weren't shown to breakfast as we arrived late and we were rushed through so had to ask if we could have the breakfast. Spent 3 hours in park that was average and nothing like we were expecting. Lunch was very good. Then 3hrs drive back

Not what we were expecting - disappointed. It was my first trip to S.A. to visit my husbands family. We were based in Cape Town, and wanted to fit in a two day trip a game reserve on our trip. We had small children in our party and so needed to pick a malaria free zone. Aquila from all the information provided, seemed like the best choice.Turned out not to be so much of a game reserve, more a like a large zoo, with some accomodation and a swimming pool.PositivesGreat as a day trip from Cape Town, if you have small children and want to show them some animals without spending a lot of time driving round looking for them.Guaranteed to see the big fiveIts a nice drive from Cape TownAccomodation wasn't too bad - clean and reasonably comfortable.NegativesLions - trapped in a smallish area, seemed to be overfed (food is provided for them, they aren't wild)Drivers have very basic knowledge of animals, but not the detailed level of knowledgeyou'd expect from a guide in a game reserve. As it is in the desert the game reserve probably can't sustain a vast number of animals (hence extra grass is fed to them daily), but still only having a handful of each animal was a bit odd. I was expecting to see vast plains full of herds of elephants/giraffe/wildebeast etc, not just one or two. Didn't feel the 'magic' everyone talks about, when they speak about being out in a game reserve.As the animals were fed, they stayed around the feeding areas, in fact on the three drives we did, we didn't even have to look hard for the animals, they were pretty much in the same place each time. Take the fun out of looking for wild animals. I suspect most of these have been in capitvity most of thier lifes.Food - wasn't great - the same food on offer for both lunch and dinner. If you are visiting the reserve for a day trip, then the food probably wouldn't be too bad, but as we were there for two nights it was very disppointing.Didn't like to see the cheetah and leopards in such small cages in the rescue centre across the road. Difficult to know what the story was about this place, as there was no information/education to explain why they were there.Unclean swimming pools - need more attention, only one was fully functional.Things they could do to improve:Offer an al a carte menu option for guests staying overnightOffer the option for guests to cook a bbq outside thier own accomodationImprove the educational element of the place/employ experts to assist the drivers. If this is targeted at day trippers from Cape Town, and families, have educational information for the kids about the animals, so they can learn on the trip.I would only recommend going here as a day trip - but don't expect anything more than a large expensive zoo.

Great for kids and seeing wild animals up close in their natural environment. We had a 2 year old and 5 month old baby in tow and Aquila was the only reserve we found allowing small kids on game drives. The 2 year old loved it so it was well worth doing it. It does feel like a big zoo but the guides are wonderful and informative and it being malaria free and near cape town made it our only choice. Food is pretty poor though.

Improvent at Aquila as experience during stay on 25 February 2012. “Don't waste your money - badly run and altogether a disappointing visit”With reference to the review heading for one of the reviews I am also disppointed that another bad experience were had.Me and my wife visited the reserve last year October and were also very disappointed. As a result of my complaint we were offered a free night. This offer was taken up on 25 February 2012. We have noticed a fast improvement at the reserve. The new manager seems to be a hands on guy and striving to improve the service and facilities.We had an excellent stay.

Bit of a drive.. but well worth a visit!. My husband and I visited on our honeymoon. We booked onto an afternoon game drive..although it took us 2.5 hours from Cape Town it was a lovely afternoon out! We had an amazing buffet on arrival, whilst sat out looking at the reserve.. georgeous! and then set off on our game drive.. With a group of about seven others we saw four out of the big five.. the guide was fabulous and really accomodating! well worth a visit! Our friends also visited and they did the quad biking adventure- they had an awesome time!

Not a Safari, but nice place to stay for a night... Looked at Aquila before traveling to SA on honeymoon and did not book.. After two nights in Stellenbosch & three in Capetown we headed to Worcester to see a friend for the night, he suggested we check it out and booked us a night there which included food and a couple of game drives.. Misses really wanted to do it, so the next day we arrived bright & early.. Drink on arrival, checked in (no room till after lunch) and hit the pool, had a lovely time, swimming reading in the beautiful setting with beautiful weather, got chatting with others had a ok lunch, checked into room, back to pool.. Game drive at 17:00,, if I'd driven there just to do the game drive, disappointing, place just a little to barren, animals our at least not in a cage and staff just a little to uninterested.. Back for ok dinner, lit a fire had a few drinks with some nice people, midnight dip in the pool... Up for early morning game drive... More of the same followed by ok breakfast...In all if I'd just gone for the 'game drive' ummm wouldn't be happy, fortunately the other guests and the setting made it a nice one night excursion during our trip..

Not as advertised,awful service and over priced. The leaflet and website is not at all what the place is like..the rooms are awful,lunch was disgusting,and there were not half the animals there they said. We turned up when they said,waited the whole day and had to pay extra to not be crammed in a bus with 25 other people. We were meant to stay the night and ended up leaving and still had to pay £600 just for a buffet lunch and safari.Not 4 star,and not recommended at all!

Great estate, but not excited by the game drive. I found the estate very nice, with friendly staff, a nice pool, and charming accommodation (from the looks of it). Also, the tour on the ostrich farm was quite nice. The game drive, however, was not that interesting. I suppose there are limits to how amazing it can be when what you really wish to see is those animals out in the wild, and we did get to see the big 5 as well as zebras, springbok, cheetas, and such. So if you find yourself in Cape Town and you don't have time for a proper safari, then this is a decent option. If you are not desperate to see lions and elephants, then save it for another time when you can see them in their right habitat.

barely worth zoo admission!. I planned to take my friend to a game drive as we only had an extra day in Cape Town and no time to go to the Kruger Park. I asked the concierge at the hotel and he recommended Aquila as it was the best variety of wildlife and not as he said, "Noah's Ark" (2 of each animal). We drove ourselves out the two hours from Cape Town and the drive is beautiful. We saved nearly $100 per person in doing so. On arrival, they met us with drinks and pastries. At 10:15 the drive was to commence, but there was NO organization and it was nearly a free for all to the vehicles. Our driver was nice, respectful, and courteous, however not engaging or had little to say. I sat in the front and was able to ask questions, but few if any of the answers were shared with the 20 other people in our group. As for the drive and "safari", I have been spoiled by safari in the Kruger Park and private reserves, so I did not expect it to be anything equal. This was embarrassing though. They have 2 teenage male elephants, 3 young giraffes which you couldnt get close to as they were penned away, and 5 cape buffalo that they actually pushed near the road so the guests could take pictures of them. From there they have assorted springbok, élan, zebra and ostrich. They have 4 white rhinos which are very impressive, however, as they were poached last year, it appears they have a 24 guard watching their every move. Lastly, their 7 lions are in what I would call a small pen enclosure. The guide said there was wild game for them to hunt in there, but no one believed him.Overall, it was a poor experience and I would NOT recommend for anyone. The price is exorbitant for the experience which is nothing more than a large, underpopulated zoo. I commend them for their efforts and maybe in 5-10 years they will have a worthwhile adventure. As for now, I left very disappointed and tired from 4 hours of driving.

Aquila Game Reserve. I booked this excursion, after my daughter recommended this trip going last year with friends. Although this is a nice way to see some animals, other than in a zoo..this is not a real safari experience. My daughter commented on the guide, who seemed to drive very fast and she didn't think it was run as well as her prior experience. Don't expect to see any giraffe's, as they no longer have them. Although it is close to Capetown, I wouldn't do this trip again and I can only give this a lukewarm review.

Excellent family stay at Aquila Private Game Reserve. I visited Aquila for 2 days with my wife, 2 young children (6 and 3 years old) and my father. Our 2 chalets were luxurious and very special. It was quite an experience having a bath surrounded by mountain rock.Long after our stay, we were still fantasizing over the food...especially the deserts.My 6 year old son chose to go quadbiking, where we followed a game ranger on his quadbike (just outside the main animal enclosure) and were lucky to spot buffalo right by the gate. The other enticing option for children was the pony ride (which we did not do - next time). There is also a large play area for children and my kids had a ball. We thoroughly enjoyed the jeep safari rides, though it was a bit scary getting so close to the lions (luckily they were busy feasting on the remains of some animal).All of us, adults and children, had a fantastic time and I would highly recommend a visit to Aquila, especially for families.

Don't waste your money - badly run and altogether a disappointing visit. I would not recommend a visit to Aquila as from arrival to departure it was a big disappointment. There does not appear to be a sufficient number of staff to take care of the number of guests and when you do manage to locate a member of staff, they are bored and disinterested and clearly have no concept of customer service. Check in: Disorganised & disinterested staff, no efficiency and do not make you feel welcome. Don't even recall a welcoming smile. Oh and the reception toilets are a good indication of the quality and cleanliness of the the rest of the premises. Do not expect to have your case taken to your chalet, you must drag your own luggage all the way from the car, through other guests who are sitting around the pool, all the way to your chalet and finally up the steps to the chalet door. Now I'm not lazy and am not adverse to carrying my own luggage, but really?! In a four star establishment I expect someone else to do it for me.Food: Meal times are a communal canteen style affair, with unappealing looking offerings in steel catering trays. The quality and taste of the food was poor so don't arrive hungry! It is self service and due to the vast numbers of day trippers it is quite a scrum to get to the food. Also, they appear not to restrict numbers, so don't be too surprised if you cannot get a table. As lunch was so dreadful I was not really looking forward to dinner - it was equally poor. Broadly the same sort of food on offer and again self service. The evening meal experience for my fiance and me lasted all of 20 minutes (that includes the walk to the cafeteria and serving ourselves) - we basically wanted to get some fuel inside us and get out of there. I glanced around at the other diners and not one looked like they were having a good time. We congratulated ourselves on having the foresight to bring biltong and a couple of bottles of wine with us, which we enjoyed back at our chalet.Chalet: We stayed in one of the supposed Premier Chalets, I dread to think what the Standard ones are like! Certainly does not warrant 4 stars. The chalet we stayed in was cheaply knocked together, cramped and the bedding was not quite as white as you would expect it to be! Ranger: I will call him a driver as he demonstrated none of the qualities that a true game ranger posseses. This one was clearly bored and disinterested and did not appear to be able to offer any knowledge about the animals or the surrounding landscape.I did have to smile to myself at the opening lines from our driver. Something about the animals being free roaming and wild so there really is only a 50% chance of seeing anything. What a load of rubbish, these animals are like farm animals. Hay is put out in a clearing so naturally the grazing animals migrate to that spot. There are two man made water holes, so you're probably going to spot the hippo in one of the two. The lions (very bored looking lions) are in a separate relatively small enclosure so are not too tricky to locate. In order to fill up the duration of the drive, expect to spend a ridiculous amount of time staring at springbok and ostrich.On returning to the base at the end of the drive, the driver somewhat unenthusiastically asked did everyone enjoy that......I've seen people looking more animated in a doctors waiting room.We decided to give the 6am game drive a miss as we weren't going to see anything different to the previous evening's drive. We also skipped breakfast as we couldn't face the whole unpleasant dining experience again. If Aquila genuinely is a rehabilitation centre then it does not surprise me that there is a relatively small quantity of game. However, I question whether Aquila truly is a rehabilition centre as I would have expected the ranger/driver to be able to talk about how a particular lion of rhino came to be at Aquila, where they were rescued from etc.......Now, Aquila's slogan is 'Real safari, real close to Cape Town'. This is not a safari and should never be advertised as one, It is, at best an animal farm. In summary, the management is dreadful and I don't see any evidence of the money they're taking being re-invested back into the place. I believe their ethos is pack 'em in, take their money. This establishment is not about repeat business! Don't go, you will feel ripped off and disappointed, rather save your money and put it towards a proper safari where the staff actually care about your enjoyment and comfort.Once you have eaten in the cafeteria and been on your game drive there really is nothing to do. So, if you're not big on conversation then advise taking a good book to read.A few positives: The girl serving at the poolside bar was very cheery and I did manage to locate a member of staff and borrow a corkscrew for the aforementioned bottles of wine. The scenery on the drive from Cape Town to Aquila is stunning.

Nothing about Aquila would entice me back - Colin Taylor RSA. Spent 2 nights at Aquila, wouldn't return or recommend the place to anyone, foreign or local.. I notice that most comment come from day visitors so our dissapointment has to do with the accommodation, competing for meals and service with day visitors, who appear to be the market Aquila is targeting, the game viewing, quite frankly go to a zoo. For the price charged, a bitter dissapointment. I have filled in the comment form which was sent to both GM and owner of Aquila, both feel its unnecessary to reply, hence my posting these comments

Wonderful place but the health and safety leaves a lot to be desired. Although the horse riding says no experience required, both of my daughters we thrown from their horses in the middle of the reserve. One bruised, the other broke two bones and was airlifted to hospital. Guide appeared to have no walkie talkie or mobile, very poor first aid experience and pathetic first aid kit. Be very careful should you decide on the horse riding. The quad bike experience was superb.

Nice, if a bit Tame Game Experience. Ok, so if you are going here, you shouldn't be expecting a true safari. That said, there is a nice variety and proximity to animals that you don't get in a zoo or game park. If you are in Cape Town and don't want to do an overnight safari, then this place is as close as you will get.The team at Aquila were very nice and accommodating. The guide was very knowledgeable. The food was great and a nice way to end our day.I wouldn't do this type of activity again, but for a starter and with limited time. It did the trick.

Great safari experience for families. We went to Cape Town to visit family and wanted to take our 9year old twins on safari. We decided to go to Aquila since it was close by and reasonably priced. We had a great time. Our girls absolutely loved the experience. We got to see all of the animals up close, the guides were very knowledgeable and the food and accommodations were great. I would highly recommend Aquila to anyone wanting to experience a safari in relative comfort.

Awful accommodation and customer service. The safari part was amazing and so was our driver. It was the customer service from the managers that was terrible and from the restaurant staff - often having to look for them to ask for a drink. Questions we asked were palmed off to other people and we were never given the answer. The room was very basic with no air con and an extremely noisy fan. Electric cables were hanging out by the bath, cigarette butts were left in the outside shower from the last guests. This was a tourist conveyor belt - dropped off in the morning before the room is ready and out early the next morning with pick up in the afternoon - there are no changing rooms/showers around the pool. It wasn't clear whether you have lunch on arrival or when you leave the next afternoon as you are only allowed one. There was no advertising or communication of other facilities. Guest relations were minimal. Once they have taken your money they just leave you to your own devices - apart from the safari.

Gimmicky reserve with semi-professional game rangers. The reserve itself was okay, in this day and age I understand that a place like Aquila supplies tourists with quick access of seeing animals that are not in a zoo environment, living together... BUT for me this reserve was too gimmicky. The game drive at Aquila was not ethentic, and it literally took 20 seconds for the game driver to see an animal, stop and explain something about it. The game ranger must've had a bad day, but this is no excuse. He was simply shocking and for me that was the killer blow. The food and accommodation was okay, but the central component of a reserve is surely the game drive and the animals. For me these were a let down!!!

Superb half-day out - wish I could have stayed for longer. A great half-day out, starting with relaxed, quality breakfast in the welcome lodge.The staff were very helpful and knowledgeable, and the buildings and facilities were very high quality. I booked this when out in Cape Town visiting a friend, and invited him along too as recompense for putting me up for a few days. Despite already having visited a number of these sort of semi-wild game reserves, he too found it very enjoyable.The time spent in the safari trucks was fruitful: we saw everything apart from the lions, who unhelpfully chose to stay well out of sight. The elephants were impressive and we were quite close (ca. 5m) to them on a few occasions: sufficiently so that the driver had to reverse out of the wayto avoid the truck being pushed back down the track!We were also fortunate to see a recently-born baby rhino, which was cute and endearing - even to two 40 year old blokes! Zebra were ten-a-penny and antelope too.After a decent stint touring round, we stopped for a refreshing glass of sparkling wine - a very nice touch as the temperature rose - and to stretch our legs in a safe part of the reserve. We then headed to the other side of the road to view some rehabilitation enclosures where we did see lion, warthogs and a beautiful leopard.All-in-all, a thoroughly enjoyable few hours out. I would love to return with my girlfriend and spend a night or two in the nice-looking safari lodges.

AN ABSOLUTE MUST DO, TIME AND TIME AGAIN !!. I have been fortunate enough to visit Aquila Private Game Reserve before but it just gets better and better each time. Just an hour and a half drive from Cape Town, this is a must do for everyone who lives in or visits Cape Town. The reserve is surrounded by the most beautiful scenery and hosted with friendly and knowledgeable staff. The food is equivalent to that served in great restaurants and the accommodation, although traditional, is certainly very luxurious. We had the opportunity to get really close up to most of the Big 5 (this was the highlight of my foreign friends whole holiday and they cant stop talking about it days later)!! A big thank you to all at Aquila for making my visit so memorable, I will certainly be back again ;) You are one of Cape Towns' top wonders.

Fantastic, well worth it!!. My family and I have been to Aquila a couple of times already and always leave feeling relaxed, refereshed and taken care of. I was suprised to read some of the other reviews on this site..... if I had read those reviews before my first trip I might not have visited this great reserve.We have stayed in the rondavel accomodation and recently (as an anniversary suprise) we stayed in the honeymoon chalet. The view from that chalet is amazing but (being a woman :) ) it was the bathroom that made the chalet. The natural rock has been left in the room and surrounds the bath! The four poster bed was another highlight. My daughter loved the tame peacock which roams the reception area and had a ball hand feeding the ostriches at the ostrich ranch down the road.We went on a horseback safari and were pleasantly suprised. Neither of us are great horse riders so we were a little apprehensive but the horses were well behaved and made us look like pro's :)I enjoy the fact that the reserve functions as a wild game reserve and a rehabilitation centre where animals are kept in enclosures with the aim of releasing back onto the reserve once they are ready. The food at Aquila was great with everything from potjies and baboeties to lamb, chicken and fish. Even my fussy 2 year old happily munched away. My favourite was their sticky toffee pudding!We will definitely be back there soon.

Worth a visit but much room for improvement. There are some great things about the reserve - fantastic location if you are coming from Cape Town, at the far edge of the Hex River Valley - picturesque drive there, very enjoyable visit to the Ostrich farm (part of Aquila) , knowledgeable game keepers throughout and very friendly staff. The accommodation was basic but very comfortable. The reserve does feel confined but to be fair, the western cape is is not really the area of huge game reserves. On the negative side, lovely pool (visibly) but absolutely freezing. Why not heated? There is an abundance of solar energy around. Food was a let down, reason being was that the plates weren't warmed, food wasn't warmed, chicken was uncooked and the lighting in the restaurant was poor. Variety of food was good. Annoyed at no drinks price list at dinner.

Nice Safari in the Karoo highlands. We really enjoyed the safari here. Aquila is a responsible game reserve, the animals are well treated and except for those rescued and places in rehabilitation program, are not kept in cages, as suggested in previous reviews. In fact the space they can move is so big that we couldn't even see all the animals. We saw Lyons, elephants, hippopotamus, rhinoceros, zebras, gnus and ostriches. In the rehabilitation centre we saw a tiger, but we missed the cheetah, again because it wasn’t kept in a cage, but in a large fences space. The food is indeed basic, but we didn’t come for the food. This is not a Kenyan safari, but nevertheless we loved it and the price wasn’t too expensive. We booked it through Cape Point Route travel agent and we paid less then booking it with Aquila itself.

Worst experience ever. To whom it may concernMy wife and I had a booking at Aquila Game Reserve for the 8th and 9th November 2011 to celebrate our honeymoon. I had seen Aqulia advertised in the SA Express flight Magazine. The advert expressed an extravagant 4 star Game Reserve in the outskirts of the Western Cape. The advert looked very appealing and attractive which caught our eye as four star is what we were set out for on our honeymoon. Unfortunately 4 star is far from the experience we received at Aquila Game Reserve. On arrival at reception the welcoming was disappointing. We were told to arrive at 13:30 for 14:00 for welcoming drinks which were not offered. On booking into the “4 Star” unit we were informed that our room was not ready and that we should go on a horse ride first. On arriving at the horse arena, we had to wait unattended not knowing where to go or what to do. We had to approach reception to find out where to go and what to do. On mounting a horse we were told that this is there third 2 hour trip for the day and that they horses were way too tired to actually walk anywhere. According to the guide this is there normal daily routine doing three trips tiring the horses. My wife found the trip nerve racking as her horse felt like it wanted to collapse before we even left the resort area. The tour guide had to walk my horse out of the resort area into the wild before it actually followed the other horses way behind. It was clear he was way too tired for a third trip. The guide asked my wife what language she spoke then ignored her and spoke Afrikaans the whole way which I find disrespectful.On arriving at our room just after 4pm, which we had to wait for because it was not clean, we walked into a room which looked 2 star. The walls were filthy, there was toilet paper lying over the bath along side a dead fly and the outside shower had looked like it had not been cleaned in days. This is the room we had to wait for because it was not ready. When you pay top dollar for a 4 star room you at least expect the room to be cleanly painted and smelling fresh. Not walk into a room looking worse than shack. The following day at midday when arriving at the quad bike arena for our booking, we were left stranded once again. On walking into reception there was no booking reflected on their records for our so called booking we made when arriving. The person booking us in just laughed and had no signs of any apology when pointing to him as the one signing us in and making the booking. After a 20minute we were brought two old quad bikes and not the new red Honda bikes they used the day before. These bikes did not even idle and had to be held at an angle to ride straight. That afternoon at about 1pm when arriving back at our room, our unit had not even been cleaned as yet. For a so called 4 star rating, this is so not accepted.
