We had sat in the bar lounge but left this areas too due to the couches smelling like moth balls. We decided not to stay the second night and book out of Aquila losing a lot of money as the experience we received from Aquila is not what expected when you look at the extravagant adverts. After chatting to other guests it was clear that their experience was the same as ours. When I arrived at reception to book out a day early I was not even asked why. Clearly a no care attitude from the staff and MANAGEMENT as to date I have not received a call from Aquila.I have stayed in several Game Reserves over the years as i am a keen wild life person, this is clear the most expensive and most definitely the worst resort and experience I have had in my entire life. The wild life seen in the reserve in minimal and appears to be more of an exotic zoo with lions in a enclosed area rather the roaming the entire reserve which is why visitors are guaranteed sightings. One disappointment to the other leads us to this letter.RegardsPaul & Karen Smith[--]

NOT worth your money! False Advertising!. I did the day tour from Capetown. The brochure stated they had the BIG five PLUS baboons, giraffes, cheetahs etc etc. I selected this tour because I had the tourist office call a day before to check if they had all animals as advertised and they said YES. So imagine my disappointment when we get there and I ask where are the giraffes? and I am told 'the vegetation doesnt allow them to have giraffes." Then why advertise that you do?? That was my issue, if you dont have the animals, dont say you do!! I was so upset. I really wanted to see giraffes. And there were no cheetahs as well! The lions were caged, more of a zoo than a reserve. This tour is not the cheapest so I expect to get my money's worth. I sure didnt.There was another company that had all the animals and you can even walk with the giraffes-go with them. Aquila is recommended by most tourist offices but dont fall into the trap that I did, spend your money elsewhere.

Private Game Reserve 2 hours from Cape Town. I visited the Private Game Reserve with 18 clients from the USA. Aquila Game Reserve is in a malaria free area 2 hours drive from Cape Town city centre. On a arrival we had a buffet breakfast, followed by a 3 hour game drive. The game drive was very educational and the game ranger was highly experienced. The big 5 and many other species of buck can be viewed at the game reserve. We had a wonderful buffet lunch. The game reserve caters for vegetarians and Halaal meals. After lunch everybody relaxed around the swimming pool and enjoyed the afternoon. A cigar lounge and bar is available. We returned via the scenic Cape Winelands for wine tasting and visiting the prison in Paarl where Nelson Mandela spent his last few years before being released. I highly recommend this Private Game Reseve for day and overnight visits. The game reserve has a 4 star grading.

This is a Zoo, for animals and people. I can't believe the good reviews here! The accommodation is basic, the food (buffet) is poor for South African standards and the "wildlife" is not wild, but kept in caged enclosures. All of this for luxury prices! The Lions enclosure is tiny and this is really NOT how I wanted to see the big five. No, I haven't had much experience of other safaris, just one day visit to Pilanesberg and a few days in a private reserve in Kwa Zulu Nathal. But I have had plenty of disappointing visits to hotels where the guests are treated like sheep and the whole experience is like a holiday camp. This place is one of those, with very good marketing, making it seem like a safari. DO NOT BE FOOLED, THIS IS A ZOO CASHING IN ON THE SAFARI CUSTOMER WHO DOESN'T LOOK AT THE FENCES. I've been on better safaris in Whipsnade Wild Animal park near Luton.

Value for money, good with cildren, malaria free. we have travelled in october 2011 to aquila for a overnight stay. we have had a beautiful safari in the late afternoon, a quite good dinner experience ( buffett), which was stunning in quality and variety (not a five star resort! but for the money very good value!!). Side costs are moderate, stuff friendly, food well prepared and with a high hygienic standard. the aquila is child friendly, has a extra child area, and a mini golf place, which our son loved.the appartments are efficient, not luxury , but compared to other safari resorts, upper standard. we recommend the family suites, airconditioned and beautifully placed , nice interior. the other condos are a standard in quality, no views! the safari was nice , altrhough it is not the "real" Krüger Park, but for kids , and specially malarias free, it is worth going there. Pool area is ok, water was too cold to swim, you might see some animals near to the outside area, nothing special (ostriches and buffel) but ok.the horseback safari is a must, but not allowed to smaller children, which nobody told us before arrival, that was the only negativ experience we have had at this place. reading other reviews it must be added, that it is indeed not a real safari resort, but a nice experience, and we didn t understand the mentioned "bad quality" of food, dinner and breakfast outstranding in variety, better than a lot of "five" star places we have travelled before. PS it is possible to negotiate prices on staying minmum by 20 % !!

Honeymoon in Paradise. As part of our honeymoon we had the delightful pleasure of visiting and staying at Aquila.From arrival to departure we could not fault a thing.Our complimentary upgrade to the Honeymoon Lodge absolutely took our breath away. Thank you Aquila for the most magical stay.

Not 4 Star luxury. Certainly not the "4 star luxury" tha Aquila claim. More like 2.5 star at a push.Don't expect anything even remotely in the mould of Kruger, Pilansberg etc - it's just not that kind of place, given the size.Positives - Nice setting for swimming pool, bar, lounge & restaurant with great views. Friendly staffNegatives - Not value for money. Accommodation - only a handful of decent accommodation units. The majority are quite basic and mostly in need of some maintenance. Food - the biggest disappointment of all. Buffet style with very limited choice. Virtually exactly the same choice for lunch and dinner. Hot dishes, of which there are only 2, were hardly warm. very hot

Absolutely awesome, nothing can beat a weekend stay here. First all, on arrival, you are welcomes by a ranger who escorts you to reception where you receive either champagne or orange juice. There the weekends itinerary gets explained to you, depending what package you booked. The ranger then carries your bags when he escorts you to your chalet. We were booked into chalets that were built into the rocks, the outside shower just took my breathe away, too cold to use though but would be great in summer. The whole interior just says wow. Clean and comfy and at night while sipping drinks on the balcony one can actually see game coming right up to the fence. The staff are all very friendly and helpful. The game rides are amazing as well. I got to see Lions close up, even crocs and hippos. Will definitely recommend this to anyone.

Great, private reserve!. First thing to state, is that Aquila is a small private reserve, and cannot be compared to the likes of Kruger. The resort is beautiful and I would recommend staying overnight in order to experience all that Aquila has to offer. The private cottages over looking the reserve are exceptional especially the outdoor showers!I stayed there in 2009 as part of a work conference and I found the staff to be extremely pleasant and accommodating. We got to see all the animals between the evening and dawn safaris, and I felt that the guides were knowledgeable and entertaining. As has been previously stated the food is average but as we had been in Franshoek the previous 4 nights, this wasn't an issue.

Unbeatable Safari experience if you have limited time. I have been to many of the best safari lodges in Africa, so my expectations are very high. I was pleasantly surprised by the experience at Aquila. We got to see all the animals we wanted to see, in a very short space of time. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable, and the rooms were spacious, comfortable and well appointed. On the less positive side, it felt a little busier than I would have liked, and the food was not great. It's a small park, so a stay of more than 2 nights would likely be too long.

Giving a Little Back. I stayed at Aquila Game Reserve a while ago back in 2009. The room was not ideal for two person as it was a 8 sleeper, yet my girlfriend and I had the most amazing stay!The part we enjoyed the most would like been the enclosure they have set up for animals that we part of canned shooting projects. I think we need more establishments like this; not just talking about the problem, actually making a difference - Aquila is actually making a difference!If I had the opportunity to visit Aquila once more I would be EXTREMELY KEEN!

Fantastic game viewing close to CT!. Stayed at Aquila overnight during a very cold wintery night. It was a lovely place to visit we loved being there. The guides and satff were so helpful with our 2.5 year old daughter and she got loads out of staying here and seeing the animals - plus with baby sitting facilities we could enjoy a leisurely dinner. I would definately recommend Aquila to anyone in the Cape area. Also all game reserves and nat. parks have conservation management involved. Yes we did see alot of game the first drive and second none at all (how do you hide elephnats?!!?. Therefore to state this is contrived is unfair to Aquila. There social and sustainability programme is a good start too and therefore would say go here - Plus it must be even more awesome in the summer!

RUBBISH - A REAL LET DOWN AT A HIGH PRICE. Aquila was recommended by the tour advisor at our hotel. Had we known before we went what we know after taking the trip we would never have visited Aquila. pitty we did not check it out on TRIP ADVISOR.I could go into repeating what others have said regarding what a let down this place is when it comes to a SAFARI. Being a plain speaking UK Yorkshire person, I WOULD ADVISE ANYONE wanting, to see WILD animals on a Safari setting to AVOID THIS AT ALL COSTS. ITS A RIP OFF FOR VALUE & ANIMALS.

Great Introduction to SA Game Reserves. We were only in SA for 10 days and based in Cape Town so weren't able to get to any of the big reserves. After much research we decided to give Aquila a try and spent 2 days and 1 night there. Although clearly a small reserve we loved the experience and our guide on our twilight and sunrise safaris was knowledgable, funny and created a great experience. The accommodation was great - we had a private cottage overlooking the reserve - and I spent an hour on our first day with a glass of wine in the bath watching the elephants roam around. I would definitely stay the night as it seemed that the day trippers didn't get nearly the same experience. My only complaint would be that the food was average at best but we went there for the animal experience not the cuisine. If you understand that this is not kruger and is a fairly new small reserve then you will love every minute of it - there is even a beautiful pool looking out over the wildlife area.

A great first time safari experience!. Have just got back from a trip to the Western Cape, which included an overnight stay at Aquila Game Reserve.In a party of 6, we stayed in 3 non air-conditioned lodges. Which was fine in their April weather. The rooms were clean and comfortable, with a shower, bath and outdoor space at the front overlooking the game park.Included was 2 game drives, afternoon/evening and morning and on both we saw plenty of wildlife (hippo, rhino, elephant, giraffe, lions, wilder beast etc.) and our guide was very knowledgable and friendly.All food was included in the form of a buffet; lunch, dinner and breakfast. The food was delicious and hot, I and all members of our party had no complaints. Aquila catered for everyones needs.Like any private game reserve in South Africa, the animals live in the wild, but are looked after. We chose Aquila for a number of reasons;- it employs staff from the nearby Touwsriver, decreasing the unemployed within the town.- it runs entirely on solar power and can further run up to 600 nearby homes if the funding for infrastructure can be found.- rescues and treats poorly/poached animals, such as crocodiles, leopards and warthogs to enable their release back to Aquila or another suitable reserve.I and my party were not disappointed with Aquila, despite mixed reviews. The one thing I would say, if you can, spend the time on an overnight stay, rather than a tour from cape town. You will find it a more relaxed and enjoyable experience than the day tours, as they seemed to get crowded.Hope people enjoy it as much as we did.

AMAZING. During my trip to South Africa, I was fortunate enough to visit Aquila for 1 night. I'll make this short n' sweet:Highlights:- the food, pool, location and rooms - very nicely done, just what you need with a touch of sophistication- the ANIMALS = breathtaking, when the elephant walked straight toward our jeep and came within touching distance, i honestly could have cried from the beauty of it- we were able to see all of the animals, even the giraffe that we searched high n' low fori woke up early on day 2 because i thought i heard lions roaring...so i ran outside and no word of a lie, they were! the rescued animals located across the road must have been having breakfast....a moment i will never forget.if you get the chance, GO!

Aquila march 2011. WE had a fantastic time at Aquila, the staff was amazing, the food was delicious, they even et me use their personal computer o check my email. our first safari out we saw every animal. Lio, buffalo, elephants, elons, wilderbeast, zebras. We would go back there. we spent 2 nights in the luxury chalet. Very clean... For a 1st time safari it was great.. ollen was our ranger and he is amazing. My daughter went horseback riding and quad riding thru the safari, she really got an up close look at the animals

Well worth the visit - if its your first time !!. I also looked at the varied reviews before booking this day trip from Cape Town. And also was not sure if I should book or not , considering its not that cheap. But if you have limited time in Cape Town and you are not going anywere near a real game reserve in Northern Africa THEN GO. Yes it is like the biggest Zoo in the world , but I loved every minute of the day. We got up and close to all the animials, we got free sparkling wine on arrival and also at morning tea , the included buffet lunch was excellent . We had a great friendly driver/guide - whom many people tipped when completed. Now that we are home in Australia and I look back at the photos taken - I am so glad I done this day trip.
GreatTime. Top staff and service...quality experience. Thanks to all.Howard C. (New York)

Amazing experience. This was too wonderful . I booked for them to fetch me and take me there, in the morning this very friendly man arrived at my hotel on time and drove me to the reserve. It was only 2 hours away we arrived and had a really tasty and fresh breakfast. Then onto the game drive. If I had to use one word to describe it would be WOW. I saw the big 5 and others within 90 min the place is clean , well maintained and I found the staff very well trained. The day was finished off with a great traditional lunch. Thanks for a great day

definitely worth a visit. We really enjoyed the experience in Aquila. We were there 2 years ago and were disappointed. This time we had a very good guide; Daniel. He was most helpful and informative. We saw the lions, which were roaming free in a separate area of approx 400 hectares. The game drive lasted 3 hours and we saw lots of animals, including White Rhino, Zebra, Giraffe, Wildebeest, Elephant, Springbok,Ostrich,and BuffaloWe had breakfast and lunch, the food was excellent and there was a good variety There have been many changes since our last visit, all to the good, a new swimming pool, new restaurant, rest rooms etc. It is not Kruger but it does give people visiting Cape Town a flavour of a real "Safari"

Tranquil oasis in the Karoo. Our visit to Aquila was nothing short of amazing, from the minute we arrived and were greeted with a glass of bubbly and a friendly smile. We walked through the front doors and our first site was one of the large sparkling blue pool and pool bar – I was impressed. I would have paid just to lie there the whole day!! But my family reminded me why we were there – to see the animals. The game drive was great, the guide very knowledgeable and the animals looked in their element (and so were our kids) The lunch buffet offered a wonderful variety of salads, starters and main courses with lots of fresh produce. There is a newly built kids centre with games and colouring in books as well as putt-putt which really helped the kids burn off some steam before our trip back to Cape Town. What impressed me and my family the most was while the service was not 5 star (I would give it a 4) to think that one person was able to provide employment and training to the local towns people who were previously unemployed and living off the government. After reading all about the social upliftment and local feeding schemes, I felt proud to have supported Aquila. We will definitely be back and advise it to all our friends.

An amazing place to view the wildlife of South Africa. We had a great time at Aquila game reserve and the kids learnt allot about the wildlife. The staff were friendly and the food was great.wish we could spend more time.

Total waste of money. Having looked at the previous complementary reviews I find it difficult to think of anything positive!! My wife and I have just returned from our holidays and had a fantastic time in Capetwown where we spent 11 days. This tour cost us 1950 rand each and the people on our tour comprised of 4 Americans, 2 from Switzerland and us 2 from the UK. It was so bad we all decided to cut short our tour and left early. As we had left early we asked our guide if we could pop in to stellenbosch on the way back to Capetown, no chance. As previous comments suggest you would find more animals in a zoo and another surprise for would be customers lunch is included but you have to pay for drinks!

Canned Hunting - By Camera. Probably the worst establishment I have stayed at. The food was pathetic, if I wanted to eat like the homeless of Africa, I'd go to a soup kitchen. Can't rate the service because the wasn't any. Stay away!!! If you have to see the Big 5, go somewhere else

Not worth wasting a day or 2 of your holiday on this!. Don't stay more than 2 nights, but preferably only 1. Don't expect a real safari. Its a bit like groundhog day. The animals dont move far from the water which is right by the lodge and the various big cats are in various sizes of cage - some not so big. Only stay in a premier luxury lodge. They let us upgrade for free. The other rooms are just nasty. The food is average. However, the staff are friendly and helpful. The horseback safari was a fun alternative.

Aquila game reserve - a petting zoo. When I visited Aquila I realized one thing, the main attraction is viewing animals in small camps and cages similar to a zoo. They have a project called “Rescue Animal Projects” and is just an excuse to turn it into a petting zoo. Is this supposed to be an african experience for tourists, than I do not know what to say.

Rude,. Our time at Aquila was not as enjoyable as we were expecting. We started the day with a lot of complications with transportation, which we thought they were providing. We had to instead pay a taxi driver we had met earlier in the week to drive us there. We arrived to the reserve at 12:45 after rushing to make sure we were there for the 1PM ostrich farm tour. We were told when we were checking in that we were too late and we could not go to the farm. They also said we would not be compensated for this because it was "complimentary". We showed how they had provided it on our itinerary and explained all the earlier complications we had, but they dismissed us in a fairly rude fashion. It was obvious this place is run like a machine and that a lot of the reception staff wants nothing to do with being helpful. We asked the owner, Hans, for help and he too was snobby and dismissive. The only time he was nice to us was when he thought we were going to purchase an expensive item in the gift store. You are only allowed three meals during your stay (beverages are not included), so make sure you bring snacks for the afternoon you are leaving. The animals on the reserve are of course amazing, but it definitely feels like a glorified zoo. The only positive experience we had was with our tour guides, Colen and Andrew. They were smart, well informed, and personable. We went on the horseback ride with Andrew, which was especially pleasurable. If you go, definitely try to go a ride with them. They were both fabulous and the rest of the staff should take cues from them.

For a first Safari taster - It was Fantastic. We spent 2 days here on our South African holiday. 3 of us in our party of 4 had never been to South Africa before or been on a Safari, so were excited by these 2 days. We had a really lovely time at Aquila and saw some amazing animals close up. If you have been on Safari before at one of the big reserves in South Africa then I would not recommend Aquila, it is tiny in comaprison. But if you are new to Safari and want to try it, this place is perfect. The accomodation and food was also excellent.

Glorified Zoo. I completely agree with Welshtraveller01 in the comments!We saw:2 rhinos2 elephants3 hippos2 lions 0 giraffes2 BuffaloAnd the a leopard caged up on the other side of the road with another 2 crocodiles!Just be prepared to see 1 or 2 of each animal! You would see more in a decent zoo at a tenth of the cost!Food weren't bad though!

For a taste of African wildlife...this is a great stop.. Our kids had come from North America for a brief visit at Xmas, and in a limited time...Aquila was a terrific place to take them to see animals, without going to a zoo. We were warmly greeted, and shown to our accomodations, which were very clean and faced out onto the veld.Lunch was a bit of a frenzy, with many groups meeting at one point over the buffet tables, but the food was tasty and the selection varied.We enjoyed the pool and some quiet time to watch some animals roaming, and then went on a game drive with Timothy. He was very enthusiastic and very knowledgeable. He had some terrific stories. We chose to sit at the back of the raised vehicle and were very pleased to have had some great close looks at all that we had seen. We had a nice sundowners on the veld.Supper was less of a stampede, and the food was very good, and there was lots of it.We had a family game of putt putt and spent the evening watching the animals near our cabins.In the morning, lions roaring woke us up and we headed out on another drive with Timothy. It was interesting to see all the animals we had, in a different part of their daily life.We had the most exhilarating time when a buff took exception to our vehicle and charged. Timothy did some fancy driving, and was at all times concerned for everyone's well being. We were all fine and definitely awake!We had a very nice stay...and the kids had a great primer to African wildlife.

An incredible Safari experience for the entire family!!!. An incredible Safari experience for the entire Family! In December of 2010 we took an amazing family trip to Cape Town, South Africa. Before departing on our flight from Canada to Cape Town we decided to enquire about booking a Safari adventure for our family. We spoke to the good people at Jenman Safaris in Cape Town, South Africa. As we were going with two fairly young children they suggested that Aquila would be an ideal place for a safari. We were told it catered more to a family experience! We booked a two day safari drive with a one night stay. The staff at Jenman's were very informative and service was excellent! The 130 Km drive to Aquila from Cape Town was a great visual experience. The landscape changes from fantastic views of the mountains to acres and acres of vineyards as you get closer to Touwsriver. It was a spectacular drive! Once we arrived at Aquila we were greeted with smiles and a glass of champagne for the adults and some sparkling fruit juice for the kids. The rooms were very clean and spacious. The thatched roofs really added to the charm. The Kids loved the upstairs loft and claimed it as their own. Before our evening safari drive we were treated to some excellent food at the buffet. The food was all very fresh with a good selection. It was tasty too! After our meal we got a chance to relax and unwind around the pool for a bit.In the early evening we gathered near the Aquila entrance for our Safari drive. We met our driver as well as the other families that we would travel with us in the vehicle. Romeo would be our driver for the evening as well as the second drive in the morning. After meeting everyone we all scrambled into the vehicle and set off. Once you enter the reserve it is only a matter of minutes before you see some live animals. Our driver and guide Romeo really took his time approaching the animals You don't want to startle a buffalo or a rhino. We found out that they can be very aggressive especially when cornered,. Romeo explained each animal we spotted in great detail. He talked about their habitat, diet, Life cycle and so on,. I believe that the animal info our guide provided really added to all our safari experience. Romeo not only told us about the animal itself but also included a lot of info on their life in the wild and specific details about each endangered animal and it's struggle to survive. The info on the breeding programs that Aquila are working on was also great to hear. The conversations were very open and allowed for everyone's questions large or small. Romeo even took the time to even answer the kids questions fully. It was really incredible how close we were able to get to each animal. I had not expected this and was in total awe of all the animals we got to see. Some great Kodak moments for sure! We all loved the drives and the chance to spot the animals over the two day Safari. Please note that it's not just the big 5(Buffalo, Lion, Rhino, Elephant & Leopard) you get to see. Aquila has several other animal species on the reserve. We really enjoyed watching the Hippos, Giraffes, Wildebeest, Zebras and other animals. It was funny how much a kick the kids got out of the small mongoose that we spotted darting in and out near the hippos. Aquila gave our family a safari memories for a lifetime. When we got back home to Canada our safari trip was the number 1 topic of conversation with family and friends. If you are in the Cape Town area I highly recommend the Aquila Game Reserve for a fun family time! Thank you to Romeo and all the staff at Aquila. It was a great adventure. Also thank you to Jenman Safaris for suggesting and booking our fun trip!

dont go - a rip off. I booked here expecting it to be a fairly tame reserve. When we arrived it was clear it was going to be a really bad experience.The bar area was filthy, no-one cleared up outside the restaurant and the dining arrangements were a canteen style help yourself to food - we padi over £500 for one night with two small children and felt like it was a total rip off. The reserve is a glorified safari park. They only have a few animals, 2 giraffe, a few hippo, four rhino and only two elephant, the cheeta, leapoard and lions are in caged enclosures and if you think this is a safari you are so far wrong. No-one seemed interested in cared about ttheir job. It seemed to be all about making money but the owner could make so much more if they bothered to employ more staff to keep the place tidy, go round asking if you want a rink, improved the food and other elements.It could be quite good if it had the right management. Our highlight was the drive through the mountains and hex valley to get there which was amazing. Sadly, these poor aninmals dont have much of a life. It is not much better than a Zoo. Be warned!

Ordinary - Woolworths of Game Parks. Its a difficult review to write to criticise one's attempts to put together a ethically sound idea of presenting Africa at its best however i left empty hearted today having travelled across the world with my daughter (5) and husband (Indonesian - first time to Africa ) whom were promised the delights of African hospitality through my own experiences at Kruger and Zimbabwe- the treasure being near the Big 5 at the end. They were hot and bored. Yes, we saw and had the 90 second pause per 'Big Animal', a glass of nasty champagne at 9am and a hurried through a lunch service of over 100 people - queues, buffet style, however i was looking forward to more. Not because i had pre-paid the equivalent of 550 usd for us in October (we left after lunch as there is a 2 hour break before transport to an Ostrich Farm - if you dont have a villa there (very very expensive and not flash) you are left laying around.....or because we had travelled/driven the distance. But we were excited and i was simply let down by a barren graveyard of dirt and dust with these poor pre purchased animals on exhibition from a tired old van but friendly guide doing his job. I do understand if one has not explored Africa and its the one off it could pass as a good safari. Its not. Do your homework and get your money's worth hence return with the elation of Africa and what it has to offer in real terms - a lifetime experience. Do your homework first. There are plenty with heart and soul on offer....dont come all this way and go home very lacklustre.

Worth a visit for a first Safari experience.. We have just done the overnight stay package at Aquila, this package included transfers from our Cape Town hotel to and from the Aquila Reserve, 2 game drives (1 early evening, 1 early morning), Lunch on arrival, Dinner in the Evening and Breakfast the next morning. We stayed in the top level accommodation, the Honeymoon Suite cottage number 9, this detached cottage was on a high level which gave great views of the reserve, but not suitable for people with walking or fitness difficulties. The cottage had a great four poster bed, a bathroom with bath with great view out to the reserve and an outside private jacquzzi and shower, all with excellent privacy surroundings. The Game Drives were good with very knowledgeable, experienced and professional Rangers, we saw all the Big 5 and more, however, the numbers of each animal type is limited, so if you are expecting similarties to Kruger or Sabi Sabi you are going to be disappointed, but for a first safari adventure Aquila gives you a great initiation to the safari experience. The food was adequate, all buffet style though and certainly not a high class dining environment and no Al a Carte options, there is no post dinner entertainment either, early to bed early to rise for your 6am game drive! Finally, I would recommend that the Management try and arrange earlier transfers back to Cape Town, currently if you are on the overnight stay the first transer back to Cape Town leaves at about 1pm this means that you are hanging around after your morning game drive, which finishes at about 830am, if they had a 1030am transfer back to Cape Town this would be perfect, the 1pm transfers means you have lost a half day opportunity for sightseeing etc in Cape Town, surely the management can arrange this earler transfer on a regular basis and then a second and third transfer at 1pm and 2pm for those few people that want to spend a little more time in Aquila. All in all an enjoyable experience, not one we would need to do again, as our thoughts are "been there, done that", but for first timers on a safari its probably a "must do" whilst in Cape Town or the surrounding area.

A must-see !!. i stayed at the Aquila game reserve last week...what a fantastic place! It was even better than i expected - and saw the big 5 and then some. Everything was perfect from start to finish...got picked up from my guesthouse, and enjoyed the drive and wonderful scenery on the way. On arrival was greeted with a glass of bubbly, a very warm welcome from all staff and then had the most sumptious breakfast...what a buffet! was shown to my chalet, which was really luxurious (the beds are soo comfy, there's airconditioning and a log fire for all weather eventualities). My first game drive was at 5pm, so after unpacking laid by the fantastic pool and got some sun, then another amazing buffet at lunchtime!The game drive was excellent - our driver CJ and ranger Tim were just great...could answer all our questions and clearly love the job they do - they could tell us all about any ot the animals, and made the trip so much fun! We even stopped for a while and had a snack and sparkling wine which was great. Got back in time for shower and another buffet for dinner! Second game drive was at 6am, great to watch the sun rise and appreciate the amazing views - wow.I would recommend this to anyone,,,,such friendly and accomodating staff, the food really has to be seen to be believed (i am a fussy vegetarian, so great praise indeed :-)It was really well organised, and the lodge and grounds are quite beautiful. There were people of all age groups from tiny kids to pensioners, and there is something for everyone.All i can say is ...don't miss it!
Reservation: Poo Service. Unbelievable, you make a booking and they cancel it.

Fully recommend to anyone visiting a game park for the first time. I was apprehensive about booking my stay after reading some of the views and so was pleasantly surprised by the quality offered at Aquila. From the moment I arrived to the moment I left I thoroughly enjoyed the visit. Accommodation was great, food was delicious, the staff were friendly, helpful and knowledgable. It was incredible seeing all the animals in person. This is not a zoo as some reviewers claim. However it was my first experience at a game reserve, perhaps if you have been to some of the bigger ones you would consider 4,500 hectares too small to be interesting. However for people who have never been to a game reserve and want to go somewhere close to Cape Town I highly recommend that you do the overnight stay at Aquila. It was an amazing and memorable experience for me.

Disgusting Zoo!!! WHAT A SHAM TO CALL IT A NATURE RESERVE!!!!. On our recent visit to Aquila Private Game Reserve in the Western Cape, we were shocked to observe the following;During our mealtimes we saw rats running all over the Bar and Restaurant as well as birds flying into the restaurant soiling on the food, tables and chairs that we as guests have to eat on. This is completely unacceptable. In my opinion this is NOT a 4 star Lodge as they would like to advertise.There also seems to be an unbearable stinge coming from the Kitchen and that could only be from poor Hygiene levels and disgusting rubbish bins which in turns explains the huge fly problem that there is. We also noticed the flies sitting on the Buffet and a cheese display that was already sweating and not even being put on an ice-tray or being covered with a fly net. Not to mention the dirty black pots and miniature Cole stoves that they use to keep the food warm! Just outside the dining room there are facilities for Ladies and Gents of which the latter can’t be flushed due to a water problem. How hygienic is this practice having toilets outside a dining area and with NO water..??? I happened to enter into the Kitchen one afternoon before Game Drive, for I was looking for a member of staff to assist us, and there I was horrified to say the least..!! Staff smoking inside the kitchen entrance, raw cut up chicken being defrosted in water as well as frozen fish lying on the dirty table tops with flies all over it!! Dirty pots and stove that the staffs are cooking on. Other meats lying in a rubbish bin to de-frost. None of the kitchen staff even had the correct uniforms on, cutlery in crates standing on the floor next to the over full rubbish bins and a sink filled with disgusting dirty water and piles of dirty plates stacked on top of each other not being washed. My wife and I however refrained from eating there fearing for our health, until we left the next afternoon. As far as my knowledge serves me correct a Game lodge or reserve is a place where the animals are free in the wild. At Aquila lodge the elephants are kept in boma’s in the evenings with the elephant herders. The cheetah’s are kept on the opposite side of the road in a “project” though they don’t have the freedom or space to run as Cheetah are naturally meant to. The leopard and 2 lions are also kept there in an enclosed area. The Rhino are on the reserve with general game, while the other 3 lions are on a separate section of the property. The 4 hippo are in a small dam. The buffalo roam the lodge freely as they are “hand reed”. Every single morning the buffalo are roaming around the front of the rooms & are herded away from the guest area then again in the evenings the buffalo are around the rooms. The fencing is pushed over every single day. The Ostrich also roam about the lodge freely not even noticing people walking past them. All these animals are feed via Lucerne, That is NOT how game lodges are. One evening as a game drive came back the tracker then passed the guests & went onto the reserve to go feed the animals the Lucerne and right behind the tracker was a herd of 15 buck following the tracker as they know that it’s feeding time. These animals do not belong naturally in the Karoo, & I feel this is total cruelty to them.Outside our room we ALSO noticed a disgusting smell from the sewerage, which can only be from overfilled sewerage system and now it’s spilling out onto the lawns etc. apart from our room that wasn’t even properly cleaned daily and the 3 Buffalo’s wandering around the rooms. Isn’t this risky to have such dangerous animals in such close proximity of people..?? Is it really necessary to have Cheetah and lions in cages and then calling it a rehab centre..???? Surely the owner and or management can see to it that the Lodge is being kept clean, tidy and presentable or is this enough for them to shamelessly keep making the money that they do..? We will never visit the Reserve again, nor will we encourage anyone else to go there.

Can't wait to go back!. The only regret I have about my trip to Aquila is the fact that I only booked for one night and not longer. From the moment you arrive you are treated like royalty. The lodge is absolutely beautiful and the staff go out of their way to make your stay enjoyable. The rooms were fantastic. Loved the outdoor shower. Two game drives were included in the package. The game ranger was very knowledgeable and I saw the big five as well as plenty of other animals. Aquila exceeded all my expectations. The food was heavenly. I cannot wait to go back!

Amazing time at Aquila. I don't understand why some of the bad reviews. We just came back from Aquila and had an amazing experience! It is NOT like a zoo as some people described. The animals live in very large fields and some times it was hard to find them. They are NOT domesticated, the buffalos and rhynos actually chased our jeep. We witnessed a confrontation between the hippopotamus trying to protect their pond from the buffalos and then the rhynos fighting with the buffalos. It was pretty impressive. The lions live in a separate large field, and not enclosed like some people described here. Our ranger, Tammy, was very friendly and knowleageable about the animals. We stayed overnight and took the safari at 5:00PM and then at 6:00AM. I would say that two days is more than enough there. Besides the game drive there is not much to do.I thought the food was good, nothing very fancy, but there were many options in the buffet.For visitors of Cape Town that do not have much time and would like to experience the safari feel, I would most definitely recommend Aquila.

Excellent. Was a bit nervous booking this attraction having read the reviews here... but we thoroughly enjoyed the day in Aquila.From the time we arrived we were made to feel welcome ... our ranger guide, Daniel was excellent, very knowledgeable and full of fun tips. Certainly, the park is a game reserve however with 4500 hectares of land, (over 11,000 acres) the animals have plenty of land to roam.We just managed to see the big 5, the giraffe in the distance !As to the food, it was excellent with many choices in the buffet lunch,the facilities were good with 2 pools and excellent relaxing areas, the bungalow accomodation were fab.Of course this a private game reserve but if you dont have the time to travel to Kruger etc it's an excellent alternative - dont be put off by some of the reviews. I'm glad we weren't !!

Awesome weekend getaway!!!. I disagree with the recent bad reviews. Although we were aware that Aquila was not as massive as the Kruger Park, it surpassed all our expectations. Our guide was very well informed and the food, breakfast and lunch was fantastic! Great experience and will recommend it to anyone looking for a day or weekend away from Cape Town.

Save you money for something better!. We stayed overnight at the reserve and were practically frozen to bits. It was winter and the temperatures dipped real low in the night. The heaters in the room were inadequate. We had to trudge out in the cold to the reception to request for the staff to start up the fire place for us but they never came citing that they could not find the fire starter. After three failed attempts we gave up. It was our honeymoon trip and we didn't enjoy it at all. We did get to experience the big 5 but not exactly the way we'd expected it to be. Nevertheless, the meals were good and hearty. Overrated and not worth the money, will never visit again.

A Wow of a Day!!. We only had four days in Capetown so did not have the time to go on an extended safari....so I did appreciate that Aquila would only give us a glimpse in a short time frame.We were picked up from our hotel early in the morning by a very friendly and knowledeable gentleman. He made the trip rather fun altho I felt the bus could have had a bit of deodorant thru it...We were happy to recieve a glass of champagne upon arrival and a sumptuous buffet spread for breakfast. Nothing fancy but honest wholesome food.I chose to go Horse Riding around the park and my husband went on the Quad Bikes.This proved an excellent choice as I had a guide to myself and there was only one other tourist with my husband. My guide was relatively new and we both had an incredible time viewing all the animals at quite close range. I wonder if he got tired of hearing me go omg omg omg....I had an incredible ride.My husband likewise had wonderful fun on the quads, and we were both able to get a slightly different view of the park than that offered with the jeeps full of whinging tourists (oh yes I heard you all)We came back and my guide offered to take us in a jeep around again to watch the elephants playing in the mud hole - fabulous!! Just me and my husband and two guides to give us a running comentry - we loved it.Came back to a very servicable buffet luncheon had a glass of wine before departing back.We did not expect it to be anything other than what it was - plenty animals wandering around, yes geared towards the tourists but we were happy with our taste of it.Had a great day, wonderful pleasant staff, belly full of decent tucker.We Loved It!!

AQUILA - BIG ZOO - HORRIBLE FOOD. Aquila does good marketing, Only that. It is NOT a Safari, Beware, It is not a Safari. They have a few animals of the Big five, example two male elefants, all caged in a big piece of land and at the end they take you to see a caged Puma and three caged lions that they say they have rescued in Africa. You pay a lot of money to see a Zoo close to a high way and later eat horrible food. NO SAFARI and two hours to get there and two hours to get back to Cape Town and a frustrated day. DON´T GO.

Perfect for a family safari and an introduction to African wildlife. Fantastic surroundings, location, hospitality, accommodation, inifitiy pool, beautiful safari lodges. The resort catered for children under 4, which meant that no-one missed out on seeing the animals at VERY close range. It was amazing to see the animals in natural shrubland and a real treat for the whole family. A real MUST for any family wanting a "tourist" safari.

If you really love this kind of thing, you will love Aquila!. I went here recently with my boyfriend and we had a great day. The day started early (5.15am), and it was about a 2.5hr drive from Cape Town, but once we got on the safari we had a wonderful time and our guide was very good. Afterwards we had lunch then hung about for a bit before heading back to Cape Town. I think a day would be long enough here - to be honest the food wasn't great and there wasn't much else to do so I say go - see the amazing animals - then leave. I wouldn't like to be booked to stay here for a few days having to eat the buffet food 3 times a day (but I am fussy!!). I can see why some people give negative reviews.. if you have been on a "real" safari before then this would probably be a let down. Personally, I have never been on a safari so this was a big step up from Edinburgh zoo for us and we thought it was brilliant! If you're not too fussed about seeing animals then it may not be worth the long drive, but it is great to see them and we got some good pics! If you are only in Cape Town for 1 week and want a safari experience then go for it!!

HONESTY - still the best policy. We recently spent a night at Aquilla - taking advantage of the 2 for 1 special over the Valentine's Day weekend and had a lovely time. The staff were ALL very helpful and pleasant to deal with. I left my jacked behind and after chasing around a bit and speaking to various people, Danvil, Sean and Abigail I eventually tracked it down to your offices in Mouille Point where I gratefully retrieved it. THANK YOU.

A great introduction to Safari close to Cape Town (with a nice pool too!). We stayed one night at Aquila and realy enjoyed the two game drives as well as the facilities. Reading some other reviews it seems that people were somehow expecting a full on private wilderness game reserve just out of Cape Town - if this is what you are after don't bother, spend your money on a trip up to the north east. However, if you want to experience the African countryside and see the Big 5 and you are staying in Cape Town this is a great option. A couple of other points to consider:- the rooms were not great, but they are clean and remember you are paying for the upkeep of the park and the animals not 5 star accommodation- the two pools are fantastic although you need to get a spot early expecially once the day trippers start to return from their morning drive. It is worth planning to arrive early and/or leave late to enjoy the facilities rather than rushing back to Cape Town- the meals were buffet style, of which I am not a big fan at all, however, I would rate the food as close to the best buffet food I have had

Don't waste your time. If you want to enjoy a good swim in the pool and a nice breakfast and lunch for 1925ran go for it. But for a safari you'd better stay home as there is not much to see than a dozen of domestic animals (yes domestic lions, elephants, cheetas...). I was expecting to see the wild life, but finally I went to a zoo ! Don't waste your time and money there.

Brilliant - worth every penny. Quad Bike is the way to go. We drove to the reserve from Cape Town (2 Hours) and after the intial welcome and high standard buffett breakfast went on a 2-3 hour quad bike safari. We were lucky in that we were the only two people who had booked for the quad bikes so had our own guide for the duration. The guide, Tim, was very articulate and well informed. 10 out of 10 for Tim.We managed to see everything within the time period and felt like we were getting just that little extra for free because it was just the two of us. Most people in the larger vehicles were jealous of the freedom of the quads. A brilliant experience that exceeded all expectations.

Glorified zoo, unimpressive rooms -- definitely not recommended. We had read some poor reviews but didn't want to believe them; we should have. It felt as though the animals were placed there for us to drive up and see, and you can see a busy road from most points of the reserve. The lions were in a tiny enclosure (we heard the same story about it only being 'for a few weeks'; but from other reviews its clear its been months, if not more). The cheetah and leopard enclosures were depressingly small, and the crocs looked like they were trying not to invade each other's space in their enclosure. The giraffes were no where to be seen, but there were few trees for them to feed on if they were around; they told us they were 'in the forest'. The ranger offered little information and didn't make himself very available for questions. The rooms felt like motel rooms that had been spruced up to have a safari lodge feel. To add insult to injury, it was our HONEYMOON and they could only offer us two twin beds pushed next to each other. If you want a guaranteed viewing of the big five, then you will find it here, but in our experience, it was an insult to South African safari/game reserves. The scenery is, however, lovely.

An amazing experience. Having read the reviews, we were a bit concerned. Our experience at Aquila was amazing...the reserve was beautiful and although relatively close to Cape Town, we felt we were a wrold apart. Our guide Daniel made the game drive quite interesting and helped us underestand the animals and their habitats. No, this is not a safari, nor is it meant to be. But from what we could observe the animals appeared content in their own natural habitat. At night, you can here the animals as they come into camp and during the day elephants came down to the water hole just outside our room. Plus a babboon or 2 ran past the swimming pool as we relaxed in the sun. Stay the night...this way you participate in the afternoon and monring rides. Quite excellent!
very disapointing. my friend and i visited the aquila game reserve last month it was very expensive when all it really is is a zoo the food wasn,t great either.would not recommend anyone.

A good introduction to a safari. This game reserve is quite a drive from Cape Town, taking approximately 3 and a half hours but it is easy to find and it definately worth it. We opted for the overnight safari so we got there at about 11.30 so that we could chill out an relax by the pool before going on safari. With the overnight package you have two game drives, one at 5pm and the other at 6am (yes you are given a wake up knock on the door by your game driver.) The accommodation is very nice, with the bathroom having a nice big bath and outdoor shower. We went in their summer, but I can imagine that it gets cold there, but the rooms have a fire and hot water bottles are provided. The rest of the lodge is really nice, and you are provided with lunch, dinnner and breakfast. The food is buffet style and there is lots of choice. The safari itself is really good. You are taken out by experienced rangers and you see lots of animals - elephants, rhinos, hippos, lions, giraffes and springbock. The reserve also has a rescue centre which you are taken to on the morning safari. During both safaris you are given drinks and snacks, champagne when for the sunset and hot chocolate for the sun rise. This has given me a good introduction to safaris and can`t wait to do another one!

Stay overnight if possible. Spent 1 night here as part of my holiday in Cape Town. We chose to go because we wanted to have a safari experience whilst in South Africa, but did not have the time to do a 'real' safari from Johannesburg.Aquila Game Reserve did not disappoint! It took just over 2 hours to drive from Cape Town through the beautiful Hex River Valley (even saw wild baboons on the side of the road). We arrived early about 11.30am and were given welcome drinks and invited to sit around the lovely pool area until lunch at 12.30. From the outset all of the staff could not do enough for youand we were given plenty of information.After our buffet style lunch - plenty of food, drinks not included - we checked in and were escorted to our cottage. We stayed in the basic room but it was still lovely. The decoration, including bathroom with outdoor shower, was all in keeping with a safari lodge and very comfortable. We enjoyed an afternoon sunbathing and using the pool before our sunset safari at 5pm.We very much enjoyed the 2 hour safari drive - yes it is obvious that you are on a game reserve but we knew that from the beginning. All of the animals looked relaxed and natural and the area is certainly huge. We saw all of the animals except giraffe on our first drive (and found those on our 2 hour sunrise drive the next morning). Our driver was super friendly and really knowledgeable about the animals. We found out lots of interesting information about the specific animals we saw, Aquila Game Reserve's history & future plans and wild animals generally across South Africa. 8-10pm evening dinner was followed by a fire and traditional drums and when we chose to go back to our room we were escorted by a staff member for extra security. For our early morning (5am) drive we were woken by the staff (as requested) and once again enjoyed seeing all of the animals. A comprehensive breakfast (8-10am)followed before we checked out and drove to back to Cape Town.I would certainly recommend Aquila if you want a safari experience close to Cape Town and appreciate friendly staff members and decent food. The experience was completed for us by the rooms, the chance to relax around the pool and the sunset/sunrise drives. I'm not sure if I would have enjoyed it as much had I gone on the day trip.

Great reserve, can hear the highway from bungalow. Great reserve, excellent staff, food and accommodation.Good reserve if you want to go close to Cape Town. Drive is breathtaking.Keep in mind that this a stocked reserve animals are brought in. As you don't get Giraffe in the Cape.Our only concern is that it is right off the Highway so you can hear the transport trucks at night.We would prefer more quite.

They lied badly about the lions. The accomodation was ok but not worth the money, the staff were lovely but we found that to be the case everywhere in South Africa, the Crocodiles didn't have nearly enough room in that small enclosure, the animals looked healthy although you got the impression they were planted in places for your arrival, but really angered me was the 7 lions that were kept in a small enclosure at the end of the reserve they told us they had only been there a couple of days, because they were repairing the fences, but i had read a review before i went and knew that wasn't the case, the cage was way to small for 7 lions it was disgusting, i understand that the park is not big enough to let the lions roam the whole reserve! the site claims 2 giraffes but apparently one fell and broke it's neck not surprising when you see the height of the food there were not enough trees for them the other one was nowhere to be seen difficult to believe when you see the size of the reserve the buffalo which apparently numbered 5 was also noticibly abscent!you are told when you cross the river to enter the reserve you are not guaranteed to see the animals something we found rather amusing considering the size of it!overall very disappointed and a waste of money you would do alot better at Addo which is fantastic.

Disagree with negative comments on here!. My partner and I had an overnight stay at Aquila, and as others have said, it's not the Kruger (which many friends who have been say is way too expensive), but a smallish private game reserve, that's what you have to keep in mind!We really enjoyed our stay. I agree about the 'sparkling wine', but i think that's being very negative, we didn't expect Bollinger! The check-in was quick and easy, with very pleasant staff all around.Our room was really nice, and very in keeping (in our opinion) with a game reserve. The bed was huge, the bathroom was very clean with a corner tub inside, and a shower outside. Each room has a patio area overlooking the reserve, where you can sit and enjoy the star lit sky, after a very nice evening meal. The food really was nice, breakfast too. We had no dickie tummies!We had two safaris, one at dusk, and one early in the morning. The dusk one was the best, and we saw all the animals that we expected to, and a few extra! There are now 3 giraffes at the reserve. The lion area is 200 hectares. Stopping for refreshments half way through was a welcome way to mix with other guests, and talk to the other guides who were full of knowledge and information about the reserve and the animals. Our main guide held such a wealth of knowledge about all the animals, and the future plans for the reserve, we learnt so much.The reserve is very new, and is still building up its animal stocks, but this was all explained, they don't try to hide the fact that they are a fledgling reserve. There is building work going on there, but it didn't disrupt our stay at all, there are no cranes, just builders.The owner/manager came round to each table during the evening meal to check that all the guest were happy, and not wanting for anything, this was a really nice personal touch.If you are going for an overnight stay, make sure you are there by 4pm, as the dusk safari starts at 4.30pm. The lack of itinery knowledge was the only let down of the reserve, but we asked for one to be emailed to us in advance. It appreared that some guests missed this because they didn't know what time it started.We feel that this was value for money, and are really glad we took the time to stay overnight during our holiday. If you have the time, take the scenic route one-way, going through the mountains rather than the tunnel (from Cape Town).

ABSOLUTE DISAPPOINTMENT -AND I FEEL SORRY FOR THE POOR ANIMALS. APRIL 27th 2009 We Travelled to arrive 0815 by Self Drive from Cape Town-otherwise it wouldve been another 1800ROn arrival we were given Fizzy (Indescribeable) -perhaps an attempt at Adding ValueI requested a receipt for my 2200R -Cash -and was told by the receptionist she couldnt work the Printer -Id get on on return from the 'Safari'Breakfast -was I guess OK ish -but nothing extraordibnary We were then left to mingle with about 20 others until c0930 to board the TrucksWe set off along a rutted track into what Id describe as a Barren wilderness -rocky -stony ground with couch grass and no tree coverage -they mustve paid peanuts for the LandWe stopped to admire 2 small African elephants Further on Widebeast and a very lonely looking solitary Giraffe -we were told the companion had died recently -Im not surprised theres no shelter watsoever and no trees4 Lions -basically in a Cage -an area of rock no bigger than 20x50 mtrsHippos -again young HipposThe Driver stopped half way to give us a mid 'Safari Drink'-again undrinkeable fizzy -I think it was a ploy to string the time out quite franklyWe returned to sit for another 30 minutes -admiring the pool that had the Hippos in and then across the Road to the further 3 Loins (in an even smaller caged area) 2 Cheetas adjacent -but out of viewThen the final piece of 'added value'-return to the Lodge area for lunch -c2.5 hours after We sat around for an hour whilst wating for it to be served -and was it NOT worth waiting for -Grease Grease and more Grease-and to Cap it all I was asked if Id like a drink -I ordered a Beer and a Glass of Wine -at the end I was given a Bill for 45R -no Price list was evident youd think after charging 2200R theyd at least give you a drink?I eventually picked up my receipt -and we leftOn the return to Cape Town we were both Ill and had to make several 'stops'Aquila is Expensive and very very poorly presented -go to a ZOO instead

Worth the money. Okay it's not the Kruger but if you don't want to spend £1000 a night to see nothing but springbok then this is for you!The accommadation was great we had a family luxury lodge which was fine for 1 night.A kingsized bed downstairs and 2 singles on the mezzanine above.It also has a great outside shower which is a nice detail.You get to see all the animals and the guides are very informative,my 16 yr old could tell you alot about the animals now!If you don't want a big safari and just want to see some great animals this is perfect.

Way better than I expected. A nursing baby rhino. Hippos making a big splash at sunset. Lions up close. Most of the springbok and their cousins. Zebra. Water buffalo. Even dassie's hidden in the rock.Definitely stay overnight - the best time to watch any of these animals is at sunset and at dawn. It's really hard to do that on a day trip from Cape Town. The cabins are comfortable and a bit eccentric. Food and wine are all fine.It's not the Kruger Park but it doesn't pretend to be. I've done a Kruger game lodge and it was amazing but figure thousands of extra dollars as an add-on to Cape Town. Allow three hours drive from Cape Town to Aquila to be comfortable. Drive back via Ceres and Tulbagh for some stunning scenery and some of the off-the-beaten track wineries.

Do not waste your money here. This is NOT what most people will expect it to be.It is marketed heavily in Capetown as a Big 5 Safari, closest to C'town, no malaria wilderness safari.Well expect to be let down.Went as a day visitor as time was too short to do some of the big name parks.1 giraffe, 2 elephants, some Rhino's, did not see the lions as we rushed throughthe security gates and into the fenced enclosure but they were were not to be seen.Huge rip off as it it not cheap by any means.The drive up is OK, if you like getting up at 4:30am on holidays.The lepoard and lions are in cages across the road as a captured breeding program.While this in itself is OK, do not market this place as a Big 5 safari because it just a farm with a few animals walking around.Nothing special about it at all, just makes you feel like you have been ripped off and not very good for the overall SA tourism.
Please Avoid it!. Please avoid this "Safari". Save your money(150 Euros per peron) and visit a real Game Reserve!!!

well we had a great time ...march 2009...... After reading the mixed reviews we were not sure about what to expect but after a stunning drive from Cape Town we were warmly welcomed and most impressed with our rooms and lunch, after a few hours of relaxation we were taken on a 5 pm tour of the reserve and saw all the animals.. yes by Africa standards its a small reserve but for 1 night taster of africa and the animals it was perfect.We had dinner and restaurant was quiet as all day trippers had gone. maybe some low key entertainment or live music to pass the evening hours.Dawn ride again we saw all there was to see and enjoyed it tremendously.I think they are doing a good job trying to introduce animals into the area , horse back ride would have been great but it was too hot for our comfort , a great way to see the reserve thoughgood food too.I hope the negative reviews dont put you off... its well worth an overnight trip and take it for what it is and enjoy .. your supposed to be on holiday .... we enjoyed ....

Caged Safari. I took my family to Aquila in Feb 09 and I have to say I was very dissapointed. Having been on many safaris throughout Africa this was not what I would call a real safari. The reserve is very small, with the lions in a caged area, and lion cubs born April 08 in an even smaller caged area. Two cheetahs also in a smal caged area for breeding and will be for quite a while by the sounds of it.We took the two day Safari and drove up from Cape Town early in the morning of day one, knowing that we would just spend the day by the pool before our first safari at 5pm. My two daughters aged 7 & 8 enjoyed the pool and just chilling out. Food was excellent but get to the meals early as it runs out!Our first safari was very poor. The driver just rushed around from one animal to the next, and we spent 50 mins standing around drinking whilst out on a 2.5hr safari! What a waste of time! The safari was so poor that when we returned I complained to the manager. The guide said nothing, the driver hardly ever stopped long enough to allow photo's, and I had to ask several times to go back.The second safari was early the next morning. This was so much better as my complaints were obviously received and handled properly. However the problem with Aquila is the reserve is very small and there is only one giraff, two elephants, a few buffallo. No sign of a lepoard, and the cats are all in caged areas. I realise now that in order to see animals in their natural enviroment you need to go to a bigger park where nature can take its course and allow all the animals to live together as they should. There are other smaller animals, and the only plus side were the Rhino's, really nice to see.I would not recommend Aquila to anyone. Save your money and go to a zoo, because that's all this place really is! Pay a little more and have the experience of your life at a much larger private reserve up north in the Timbavati area next to the Kruger. There were three American girls with us who I know felt the same thing.Plus points: Food very good. Accommodation good. Less than two hours from Cape Town.Minus Points: The animals!

Aquila a great little game reserve. We booked to stay for 1 night 28thJan 2009.After having bookedwe read your reviews& went with great trepidation.We can only assume the other reviewers only like to complain. The standard of the accommodation was excellent,as was the food(dinner,breakfast & lunch) all buffet style,plenty to choose from & piping hot. The 2 game drives showed us a variety of animals,including thebig 5.Our Ranger Jean was extreemely informative & only too happy to answer all our questions. This is a private reserve not a very large national one.Therefore we can only assume that all the complainers expected a Kruger type place.We had 2 friends with us who also agree with our comments.So to anyone who is thinking of booking,go ahead you will have a great stay,the staff are all very friendly & helpful.

Needs to decide what it is. This place really needs to decide what it is and what it is going to market itself as. From the web page and literature we were expecting a game reserve that also had a luxury place to stay attached. The game reserve is a bit disappointing but it is what it says. We knew not to expect a real safari, this is the wrong part of the country for that, but it is sad to see a place that has 1 giraffe all on her own and only two elephants. Having said that the rangers are very helpful and knowledgeable and picked up on our likes very well. My main gripe is that this is not a place to stay for luxury. We paid 14000 Rand for a 2 night stay including transport from Cape Town. This is a HUGE amount of money in South Africa. Its 1000 GBP so is hardly a drop in the ocean for two nights in any currency. The transport to the Aquila was a basic minibus which wasa bit run down. In fact I cut my leg on the seat. There was no room for our luggage despite me having told them in advance and confirmed the day before what we had. On arrival we had to hang around for 6 hours before having anything to do or checking into our room. I appreciate that hotels have check in times, but when they have made you get up at 0430 for your transfer to sit around for such a long time is taking the mickey. Food is OK but you get the same meal at lunch and dinner every day it's a basic buffet which is fine as a day tripper but not for 5 meals in 3 days. There is a pool area but this is open to all the day trippers to use as well. When you have 170 daytrippers arriving and approximately 12 sun loungers there isn't much hope for residents to get one. There was building work going on all around the pool area with a new lounge and what looked like more accomodation being built. Very noisy and quite dirty.We had booked the top type of chalet. It was OK but nothing more. We tried to leave a day early but were told here was no transport available.In summary, I would say go to Aquila for the day, see a few animals and get away, it will give you a view of whether you want to do a real safari. My suggestion to the owners is put in a second area for residents to relax in and offer better food (or at least some choice) to residents in the evening, or reduce the pricing. It's all a bit of a rip off really, I came away with the feeling that I had been fleeced which detracts from some lovely experiences with the animals

Auila Safari. After researching safari opportunites near Cape Town, we decided on Aquila. There seemed to be confusion amongst the desk staff when we arrived at 2PM and despite presenting our confirmation receipt, we were kept waiting more than 40 minutes after arrival, without explanation other than a ranger would take us to our cabin. After being driven to our cabin (the roads to/fro were a mess) we put away our belongings and inspected the premises. It was soon apparent that our cabin was not the luxury accomodations we had paid for and we had no means of getting to main building or contacting them (our cabin had no phone). We had to wait a few hours before we were picked up for the safari at 5PM. Afterwards, it was explained to us by GM Ian, that there had been a deluge some weeks back that had destroyed several of the cabins and weashed out some of the roads and we did see evidence of this. Ian agreed to compensate us for the price difference between standard and luxury accomodations and he bought us a bottle of wine with dinner that evening.Our package included lunch, which (like dinner) is a buffet-style meal. There was a plently to choose from with entrees, desserts and a salad bar. Any wine or bar had to be paid for separately.The evening safari was terrific - it was a beautiful evening and our ranger-guides were attentive and enthusiastic. We saw many animals and we were very satisfied. Our standard cabin was remotely located within the reserve and we had a very pleasant evening listening to the animals and gazing at the star-studded southern sky. The next morning, our safari ride was 20-minutes late with no explanation given. A short ways into the safari, our vehicle had to turn around to pick up people in the cabin adjacent to ours. We did see animals but our sole ranger-guide (one of the same two from the previous evening) seemed unenthusiastic and fairly quiet. There were not as many animals seen on the morning jaunt and it was shorter.The animals congregate in open areas where feed is strewn about so it is easier to see them. Good idea, but it lacks a genuosity to it. Also, the lions and cheetahs were each separately penned from the other animals(understandably so) but in modest enclosures - there was no feeling that we were seeing the cats in the natural habitat.Aquila was OK and they did deliver on the animals but, I'd suggest that visitors wishing for a safari experience consider taking an extra day or two and travel further east to see something more genuine.

feed the staff to the animals. as you can read in most reviews about aquila it is not much more than a zoo. But beside that bummer it is also very bad managed. I allready was a bit disappointed by the way the hospitality gone down after i visited SA about 10 years ago. but at aquila the really had the most unmotivated and unprofessional personel. Also the food is very bad

A Zoo not a safari. Like some of the people on here, we didn't have time to travel outside Cape Town for a real safari experience but thought that Aquila may have provided us with a taster. We also read about it in the Wallpaper guide, which is normally pretty reliable, and the accommodation looked good. We paid for two nights but left after one. The chalet was nice but we'd really come to see the wildlife and one game drive is enough to do this as they have so few animals. We did two game drives and each game drive was scheduled to last 2 hours but at least 30 minutes of this is spent stopping for drinks - cheap sparkling wine or coffee (in the morning). They have two elephants, one giraffe, 5 rhino and 5 lions. It's faintly depressing - almost feels like somewhere that former circus animals go to retire (which would actually make it worthwhile). They feed the animals so always know when and where to find them so the whole experience feels staged. Althought the scenery is pretty spectacular. The worst part were the pair of cheetahs who are kept in a tiny enclosure - really not much bigger than you would expect to see in a zoo. In summary - not worth the 2 1/2 hour drive from Cape Town and definitely not worth the money they charge to stay (food is average and breakfast was cold). Take other people's advice on here and save up for a real safari. Although may be ideal for families - all the kids on the game drives seemed to love it and you're pretty much guaranteed to be up close to the big 5.

Unprofessional & Disappointing. Like the previous review given by another travellor me and my husband travelled 2.5 hours (each way) to Aquila on 18/12/08 for a day safari only to find they were closed due to the flooding. We had received no communication from them. The manager of the reserve, Renier, gave us his mobile number and told us to call him on 25th Nov to check the park would be re-open for us to go on Safari the following week. We phoned Renier on Tuesday and re-arranged a day safari for Thursday 27th November 2008.Once again we travelled 2.5 hours (each way) to Aquila only to find the reserve was still closed. Once again we had received no communication of this.We, like the previous reviewer were told that we would be contacted and compensated. On our return from holiday we contacted Aquila to log a complaint. Our complaint has not been dealt with to our satisfaction so we are now taking our complaint through the tourism board.Although we have not seen the full facilities of Aquila if the organisation of the park is anything like the administration and co-ordination of the bookings I would give this one a miss.

Not good enough. I can't comment on the actual reserve, because we never got to see it - apart from the scruffy entrance area and a glimpse of the unimpressive looking accommodation compound. But I can say something (negative, I'm afraid) about their organisation and communication.When we arrived in Cape Town, 10 days before we were due to visit Aquila, we saw there had been flooding in the Touwsrivier area. We immediately contacted them and were told that, because a lot of their people had been affected by the flooding, the reserve would be closed for a few days, but re-opened in plenty of time for our arrival. So we were somewhat surprised to get there (after a half day journey out of our way) to find it was still closed. Apparently roads and bridges on the reserve had been damaged and still couldn't be used. Which is OK - these things happen - but some forewarning should have been given. Even 24 hours' notice would have allowed us to make alternative plans and accommodation arrangements. We were told we would be getting a full explanation and apology from customer service. But we haven't heard a word. However, judging by the other reviews, we may have been saved from an expensive disappointment.

A bit like a big zoo. We visited Aquila on a whistlestop tour around Cape Town. I checked the trip advisor reviews before hand and new what to expect, but still wouldn't recommend this for any one wanting to see animals in the wild. Aquila is more a conservation programme and a good cause but the park is small and doesn't win the safari title. Its quite expensive for what it is, I'd save my cash up for a real safari.

rather over-rated. After a terrible start to the day because bus was 1.5 hours late collecting us, we finally arrived at Aquila Game Reserve. We were expecting a more lush landscape. It is very barren and rocky. A welcome drink was provided, although we had no time for it because we were rushed through to breakfast. It was terrible. The dining room was over-crowded and no-one told us where to sit. We were moved from 2 tables because they had been allocated to guests who were staying. A total shambles. Queues for food were too long and we managed to gulp down a cold slice of toast before being herded into masses of vehicles waiting outside. On a good point - our guide "Timothy" was absolutely excellent and extremely knowledgeable. We did indeed see the Big 5, however, it felt like a zoo. Only 1 giraffe, 2 elephants, 3 rhino, 2 hippo, a few buffalo and some springbok. The lions are kept in a separate fenced off area and I think there were about 3 or 4. It felt rather like being on the Safari Ride at Disney's Animal Kingdon in Florida. Lunch was served which was of very good quality, but forget using the pool to "relax" afterwards. It is tiny and the place is absolutely teeming with guests - both day and overnight. All in all the day was rather disappointing. Yes you can say you did a safari in Africa, but I would much rather see the animals acting naturally and fending for themselves. This place needs LOADS more animals to start to feel like a true Game Reserve. It was all rather too staged for my liking.

Game Reserve near Cape Town. Juast returned from a trip to Cape Town last night (24 Sept) As we were short of time we booked an overnight stay at Aquila. We were picked up in cape town from our hotel around 6.30am and taken to Aquila - the journey was great with lovely scenery. Even in mid September there was still snow ont he hills and when we arrived at Aquila it was extremely cold and windy. We had breakfast on arrival which was good and then shown to our chalets/lodge. This had an open fire which on first glance looked great. the chalet was on two levels and there were enough beds for 6-8 people in three different rooms. However, the windows and doors do not close properly, no double glazing and with the wind coming directly onto the front of the chalet it was absolutely freezing. We had to use the rear bedroom, keep doors closed and have the heating on full blast.Our first safari was not until very late afternoon and there is absolutely nothing to do at Aquila for the time from breakfast to late pm (apart from lunch). this made it quite boring - Aquila could have had other things on - lectures, videos - anything to keep tourists occupied. it would be fine in the summer when you could laze around the pool but we felt the first day was a complete waste of time and money.The two safari trips we went on were good - it is a small reserve but we saw lots of animals - lions, zebra, sprinbok, hipps (and a baby) , rinos (and baby), ostriches, eland, giraffe, cheetahs, birds etc. The rangers were informative and answered all queries - we were provided with hot or cold drinks on each safari and had plenty of opportunities for photos.Luckily on the second morning after a safari and breakfast our transport arrived early and we made our way back to Cape Town.
