It is a much needed perspective given the abundance of news that focuses only on the corruption, unemployment, violence and other problems in South Africa.

Great insight into Cape Town Culture. Amazing things are happening in Cape Town and Uthando is part of it. Immediately after being picked up, our guide, Xolani, explained that this is not a tour - it's an experience. And he was completely right. This experience highlights the positive achievements being done, rather than focusing on the deficits. We visited four community projects which, as a teacher, was very enlightening and inspiring to me. You get out of it, what you put into it. So, ask questions, interact with the people and check out the webpage so you can "Pack for a Cause". The philosophy behind this organization is beautiful and it was a great way to experience the non-touristy part of Cape Town.

The best thing we did. This tour was the best thing I did in my three weeks travel through middle east and africa. It was phenomenal going through the townships and seeing the amazing and inspiring people that try to make the most out of their current situations. This tour was so moving and inspiring. Great tour for children as well. The guide was informative, honest and engaging. We went to a educare centre, seeing the children so happy was breathe taking. We also went to a women's skill project with a youth choir and lastly an after school care. This should definitely be a must-do in Cape Town so glad we did this tour.

Responsible, eye-opening tourism. South Africa is a country of beauty, history, but also of deep poverty. By touring with Uthando we were able to get a closer look at daily life while also providing support to organizations who battle back against the poverty in Cape Town. It was a moving experience and added important depth and realism to our trip.

Inspiring, thought-provoking experience. The Uthando experience James and Xolani provided for our family was one of the highlights of our visit to South Africa. We were greeted warmly at three of their projects and came away from each visit inspired and hopeful for the future. An extraordinary and informative morning -- highly recommended.

Essential part of the South African Experience!. Our visit included three stops: women who were learning various crafts in order to make money, two pre-school classes, and a senior center. All three were wonderful experiences that should be part of any tourist visit to South Africa because it balances the other components - historic sites such as Robben Island, natural beauty of mountains and waterfalls, and animal safaris. It was the day when I felt most strongly real connection between our two worlds. I recommend this day highly.

Outstanding, informative and moving. My wife and I had the pleaseure of taking this tour in April. We were picked up at our hotel by our very enthusiastic guide Xolani, who gave us a quick round up of what we would be doing that day. He was both informative and passionate about everything to do with this fantastic foundation. We visited the garden project, Ekhaya eKhasi Art and Education Centre, Home from home and an education program for youths. It was a very informative and less intrusive way of seeing the townships and also helps to support these great causes. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

An Essential Component to Any Cape Town Visit. I could not have imagined my trip to Cape Town without this experience. We went on a lot of other fantastic adventures - hiking, spas, wine tasting, etc. but this was by far my favorite day. James and his company do such a wonderful job of immersing you in an authentic experience. He is extremely knowledgable and passionate about his work and it's contagious. I love how engaged he is with the communities - everyone knows and loves him - and he is making a lasting difference in areas that need it most. We got to experience a wide range of different project that the organization supports - dance schools, community gardens, Amy Biehl Foundation, etc. I really couldn't say better things about this program... it is a must do for any visit to Cape Town. I can't wait to go back and the world needs more people like James.

Best Day. I found Uthando on the internet also. Uthando is a nonprofit company that oversees many different community projects in the townships In South Africa. I was interested in going but was a bit concerned. There has recently been criticism about this new kind of tourism where visitors are feeling enriched by going to the townships and gawking at the poor standard of living. Uthando is different. Uthando raises money and awareness for the many projects they fund through these tours. You are driven through very poor areas in the townships directly to these programs. We visited a senior center, a gardening project, dance school and after school programs. We only saw a few of the many programs that Uthando sponsors. It is really important to see how the world lives when you travel and I strongly urge you to spend a half day with Uthando. It was the best day, on a trip of all best days. for more info and photos go to travelwellflysafe.com/2016/05/10/visiting-community-projects-in-the-townships-in-capetown-south-africa-with-uthando/

A powerful and heartwarming experience. James was an amazing tour guide - he took us around to many different community organizations within the townships. He has a personal relationship with every person we met along the way, which provided for very rich conversations. The organizations, themselves, were unbelievable. The level of joy, discipline, commitment, and love showcased by each and every one really left an impression on me. Cape Town is amazingly beautiful and there is so much to do in the city center. But if you are interested in a completely differnt

An incredible experience. This was such a memorable part of my trip to Cape Town. James is incredibly respectful and knowledgeable and the work that he is doing is amazing. I absolutely loved my day with Uthando and cannot recommend it higher. Unforgettable day.

A Cape Town Highlight - Must Do!. The Uthando experience is essential to your Cape Town visit. James has created a program that provides locals + tourists with an opportunity to learn about the townships by visiting existing cultural programs within the communities. The experience was eye opening, authentic + most importantly, did not feel like poverty tourism + instead a very respectful + educational visit to a part of Cape Town that is extremely important to see + understand in the context of your trip to South Africa. We visited a dance school, an arts/crafts center, a community garden + after school arts program at the Amy Biehl Foundation. I highly recommended this tour. James + Uthando are doing amazing work. I will definitely have another Uthando experience on my next visit to Cape Town.

A must when you visit Cape Town. Me and mum did this tour on our last day in Cape Town in March and we loved it and would highly recommend anyone to do this. Such a inspiring and interesting experience.

Inspirational exoerinece. I can highly recommend Uthando as an inspirational experience. The work that this organization is doing is amazing and I found it very moving and uplifting to see the difference that is being made. There are enormous challenges but it is important to know that rather than being overwhelmed by the enormity of the challenge, Uthando makes a difference and each one of us contributes to supporting this amazing effort by choosing to tour with Uthando. Thank you again for enriching our lives by allowing us to share in your work.

Inspiring visits to development projects. Uthando provides a great way to find out something about the Cape Town townships in a positive and non-voyeuristic way. Xolani was an inspiring and passionate guide who gave us fascinating insights into the history of South Africa and the townships but in a positive way which presents great hope for the future. We visited four projects: the first with pre-school children, the next a skills and community development centre, then a farming/horticultural project, and lastly the NOAH seniors day centre. We were able to chat to those running and using the projects, learning both about their great achievements but also future needs. I hope that personally and through our team of churches back in the UK I can find a way to support Uthando's work further.

Wonderful, though-provoking tour. My friend and I did this tour in mid-February and it has left a lasting impression on us. It was a very moving day and we both feel privileged to have had the opportunity to meet and talk to people who are dedicated to rising above the injustices of the past and making a difference in the townships. We visited a womens centre, an organic community garden, day care/school and a day care centre for the elderly.I can't say enough about our fantastic guide, Xolani. His overview of the history of apartheid and the townships is told with passion through facts and personal experience/stories. He is warm and engaging and kept us interested and involved the entire morning .Our lovely hosts at each stop were also wonderful and welcoming and happy to tell us about their organization and what they are doing. Overall an unforgettable, must-do experience.

A must-do in Cape Town. Humbling experience!. My wife and I were on our honeymoon and chose to do this tour to see all aspects of Cape Town and we were not disappointed. Xolani, the tour leader, starts the tour en route to the township and sets up the visit with a great backdrop of South African history, details of the charity, Cape Town and even the pronunciation of his name! He delivers the tour with such joy and enthusiasm that you will come away wanting to help him and this great charity. Every corner of this tour is filled with stories and smiling faces, our favourites were the kid's school and the seniors centre. We won't say any more, do it, you won't regret it!

Fascinating and inspiring insight. We visited 4 different projects on our tour - and each gave a fascinating insight into what was being done to change the lives of the people living in the township. The gumboots dance group was full of joy and enthusiasm - a privilege to see.

Unforgetable. I took this tour with no idea what we would really be going through, you can say that it is a surprise after surprise for every place we go. You will be amazed by the mental strength, will, and creativity of these people to try to improve lives of others who are living in the townships. The last trip to the seniors care centre was most amazing. The interaction with the seniors made you feel so much closer to them! I'll recommend this greatly. Insights to the lives of the people and social/community projects if you are really interested in these.

A sobering way to see how the other half of Capetown lives.. Even before the tour started our guide Xolani seemed thrilled and thankful for us to be there with him and was excited to show us how the money we pay for the tours goes straight back into the community. This was an amazing experience.We made four stops: a school for local kids, community-based garden where young people can hang out and learn to grow stuff, a women’s art center and an old-folks home. The stories on how these places got started is pretty amazing. Loved interacting with all the locals and was touched by their personal stories. This is a must-do while in CT.

Best part of the whole Cape Town visit. For anyone living in Cape Town or just visiting, this experience is a must. Immensely inspiring to meet resourceful, optimistic individuals committed to bringing a better life for their community. A big thanks to the Uthando guys for organizing this tour and supporting the projects.

Unforgettable and inspirational experience. I was hesitant to go on a tour of the Townships as I certainly am not a fan of poverty tourism however this was simply an amazing experience that I cannot recommend highly enough. Our guide was sensational and the projects we saw are a testament to the power of the human spirit. It would be a crime to visit Cape Town and only see the beautiful beaches and fine dining. The people within the communities are an inspiration . Please support this very worthy tour company.

Great testament to the power community development. Anyone who visits South Africa and is both impressed by its beauty and the advanced level of development but is also disturbed by the persistent inequality, which still falls heavily along racial lines, can take some heart through this tour. Uthando is supporting some 45 community development programs in the townships of Capetown, and each one gives you a inspiration from the commitment, ingenuity and enthusiasm of its leaders and members. Uthando doesn't shy away from the challenges its grantees face, ranging from gangs, crime, drugs, teenage pregnancy, and dependency mentality among some community members. But you still leave feeling quite hopeful about these grassroots efforts.
Interesting and insightful tour experience!. This was a great way to explore Cape Town from a different perspective! I would highly recommend it.

Great way to learn about South Africa!. Very interesting trip that gave the whole family a great understanding for South Africas history and life in Cape Town. This was a highlight of our trip! We learnt a lot. We were moved, but we also got very inspired! Caroline from Sweden

Insightful and educational- great 'tour'. Xolani was a great ambassador for the work that Unhand does. He was passionate, informative and a nice guy to send a morning with. Not knowing exactly what to expected, this tour exceeded all of our expectations ( 2 adults and 18 and 16 yr old). we visited a garden project, a women group, a kindergarten and a day centre for Sr citizens- all interesting in their own way. We really got a sense of the struggles that the community faced during apartheid. the challenges that they are facing now and the immense scope of what needs to be achieved in the future. I cannot recommend this 'tour' enough. Many thanks Xolani!!

Unforgettable and authentic. We had our tour today with our lovely Guide Xolani! We visited places like a Kindergarten, a Art and Education Center and were able to get in touch with the people. It was the best experience we made in Cape town and it went under our skin. You will get a deep view about history, life in townships and the work of Uthando. We highly recommend this Township tour to everybody!

Best Township Tour - Worth a Repeat. A very professional outfit. I would recommend this township tour to all groups of travellers - families, couples, young backpackers. you really will not regret it.We enjoyed hearing the history of SA and meeting the various projects the charity supports - they were sensitive towards the groups/places we visited and were also sensitive to what we would want to see/experience as tourists.

The most insightful & moving 'tour' I have ever experienced. This was the best 'tour' I have ever experienced in South Africa, not only did I learn a great deal of the history of SA thanks to our passionate and highly motivated guide Xolani, but this tour opened my eyes to the struggle but also the growth and efforts people are going to, to develop and educate those who in the past did not have these opportunities. This is not a township tour, but rather a heartfelt cultural exploration that gives you an insight into the history of South Africa and the lives people encounter in the townships. Uthando sponsor a large number of projects and underprivileged people, this tour allows you to experience the help Uthando offer as well as see the people empowered in a sustainable way. This half day trip included visits to a community vegetable garden, a day care orphanage and an entrepreneurship & education project. For me the highlight of the day was visiting the senior’s project, meeting and communicating with the 'oldies' and seeing the hope that this project instills in these elders, with a wealth of history and wisdom. Uthando allows you as the 'tourist' to experience and understand the history and the struggle people of the townships have lived and portray in a heartfelt and passionate way can be done to change this.

A Definite Must!. My husband and I visited three community projects on our half day out with Uthando. The Ekhaya eKhasi Art and Education Centre for women, the Thokozani Brothers music program and the Masibathande Seniors Project, also known as the Oldies Kindergarten. We were in awe of the beautiful and powerful voices of the students in the Thokozani choirs, and we had a lot of fun with the oldies. Thembi had us dancing and singing and laughing together. It was a beautiful experience. Many thanks to Uthando for putting together such a meaningful program.

An unusual experience - in theposirive sense of the word. Uthando tours offers a very unusual experience, an encounter with a world and people the usual tourist would probably never meet.Obviously the idea of a township tour is a bit ambivalent, however I think through visiting the projects and the work people are performing it moves from a visit to a zoo, to a meeting between people. I hope the people in the projects perceived it the same way.During our half-day tour we visited four projects, a kindergarten/pre-school, a community gardening project, a women handicraft project and a day-meeting facility for the elderly.We were welcomed everywhere with open arms and open hearts.Meeting with the elderly people was the most intense experience. To start with, I felt very uncomfortable, as we the vistors were put on a kind of panel. Only later did I understand that this was necessary, as without translation support, we couldn't have communicated. Visiting the projects and driving through the area I definately saw a site of Cape Town I wouldn't have had access to. I hope the people we visited also felt comfortable with our presence.

A must do if travelling to SA. When I first heard about township tours, the whole idea felt wrong to me. It felt very voyeuristic to go and see these areas, but after reading others' reviews on Trip Advisor, I decided to book with Uthando. I am so glad that I did. First, the guide, Xolani, was an amazing ambassador for Cape Town and SA. He is extremely knowledgeable about Cape Town and South African politics, history, and current events. The entire trip I felt like a sponge, sucking up all the information he provided to us. He was so friendly and easy going, you felt right at home. We made three stops. Ekhaya eKhasi Art and Education Centre, Masibathande Seniors Project, and Abalimi Bezekhaya (community garden). All were run by inspiring, friendly people, who were pleased to see us and welcomed us warmly. Each provided us with insight into the day to day lives of the people living and working in the townships. At the seniors project, we danced with each of the "oldies" (as Xolani called them), which was so special and a touching moment I won't forget. It was a welcome that would melt anyone's heart.I would like to stress that at none of the places did we once feel pressured to donate or purchase anything. Each place (and Xolani) stressed that just through our tour, we had contributed towards their community and they were grateful for that alone. At the conclusion of the tour, a follow up email is sent if you would like to donate after the tour. Thank you Uthando for opening your communities to the outside world and creating understanding and development through personal contact. Please keep up the amazing work.

Highlight of the entire trip!! MUST DO with Uthando!!. Spent 10 days in Capetown doing a whole host of activities (shark diving, paragliding, seal snorkelling etc.) and this was by far the highlight of the trip! X was a fantastic tour guide and a true asset to the company. My friend and I went to visit the elderly home, the child nurseries and the gardens. Fantastic experiences and ones I will never forget! Encourage anyone to take a tour with Uthando - you can meet the REAL people, hear the REAL stories, and they will stay with you for a lifetime.

Experiences you cannot get on your own .... My family and I enjoyed this tour very much. Our guide provided extensive information about recent South African history as context for our visit to the Cape Flats where we saw four empowerment projects funded partly by Uthando and the fees we paid. Extremely sobering to see how so many South Africans are still living, but at the same time uplifting to see how far many have come since the end of apartheid. If you are really interested in South Africa and her people, this is an opportunity not to be missed.

An amazing, inspirational experience!. This half-day experience in the townships around Cape Town was extraordinary. We were introduced to four amazing grassroots programs in two townships by our extremely capable and friendly guide, Xolani. Were were picked up and dropped off at the flat we rented for our three-day stay in Cape Town. My cousin and I were raised in South Africa and Swaziland. We wanted to expose our families, who are from the USA, to inspirational stories, terrific programs, and the amazing people who are thriving in these communities that once served as virtual prisons in the apartheid era. Xolani lives in one of the townships and seemed to be widely known--certainly at the four programs we visited. He introduced us to several program leaders who are bringing much social and economic change to the townships. This is not a gawking tour, rather your guide safely and kindly escorts visitors to programs in the townships that Uthando supports. Special opportunity. One of the best experiences during our visit to South Africa. Highly recommended!

Fantastic Cape Town Experience!. We spent a lovely morning and afternoon with Xolani and some new friends! We visited 5 different community projects showing a variety of the work being done in the "informal settlements" around Cape Town. We were grateful to see some of the non-touristy side of the community and were inspired by the work being done. It was also nice that a portion of our tour fee went back to the projects we visited. Don't miss this opportunity!

Cape Town Khayelitsha Tour. Went on two tours with Uthando of the massive city of Khayelitsha; one with a wide group of business associates and their partners, and then again with my family. Uthando (which means Love) is helping to support projects in the townships, endeavouring to rebuild South Africa from the bottom up. In places that are, to Western eyes, desperately poor and without hope, Uthando is helping sow seeds of hope and optimism that there is a better future for this great nation. Over our two visits we looked at four different projects: a vegetable garden project where kids are learning about creating gardens and both eating and selling the product; a school where there is a real focus on building better citizens who make better choices; a craft centre where there are a diverse set of people making all sorts of crafts for sale both in South Africa and internationally; and the Amy Biehl Foundation which operates an after school and holiday program featuring music, drama, poetry, dance and so was keeping kids in a safe learning environment while their parents are trying to earn an income. (Incidentally to learn how significant the Truth and Reconciliation Commission was to securing a peaceful transition to democracy in South Africa, look up Amy Biehl's story on the web; it takes forgiveness to break the cycle of revenge and mistrust). All of these projects were full of lovely people in an unlovely situation - but they were inspirational as they work to turn their lives around. If you visit South Africa to visit just the game parks or see the sights, you have missed the best part. If you just think the townships in South Africa are simply locations for crime and corruption, you have missed the point. This tour demonstrates the triumph of the human spirit overcoming some terrible circumstances.This is an amazing tour to do and it will change you view of life and South Africa.

Such a pleasure!. Traveling with Xolani and James was such a pleasure! It was so refreshing to be introduced to people in the townships doing such amazing work to heal their communities, such as the women of eKhaya eKasi. Engaging with the people involved in the various projects Uthando supports was such inspiring experience; I'm still trying to figure out ways in which I can support those projects.On that note, Xolani and James are so charismatic, knowledgable, and engaging! They're also very informed about various events happening in Cape Town and the surrounding area. They told our group about a youth dance performance from the organization Dance for All that was absolutely spectacular!Highly recommend Uthando to anyone traveling in/through Cape Town. I'm only sad that the group I was traveling with didn't have an opportunity to spend more time with Xolani and James.

Don't miss this opportunity . What a wonderful day spent at the veterinary clinic and then at the day care centre. James Fernie was our private guide and showed us the passion he and all the workers have, for these wonderful projects. What a privilege to meet these people who work tirelessly to make South Africa a better place. A proud ex South African. Jenny S.

Take this tour!. Cape Town is a city of luxury, nature, and adventure for your average tourist; it is so easy to get caught up in all of that and forget that there's another side to South Africa. Visiting the townships is something every traveler should do--it will humble you and inspire you. It will fill you with knowledge. It will remind you to give back to your communities and to love and respect your fellow humans and other cultures. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and kind. He explained so much of the current politics to us and, even though I have read extensively on the history of South Africa, particularly during apartheid, I still learned so much from him and from the three groups we visited. In fact, I only wish I could have spent more time in the townships. If you are privileged enough to travel, you should definitely make it a priority to do a tour such as this that gives back in some way and enriches your knowledge and cultural understanding. Each group had a lovely array of crafts for sale as well, and the money went to support some pretty inspiring organizations who are really doing wonderful work with limited resources. I will never ever forget my experience in the townships.

Townships tour. This tour visited four projects, a nursery and after school centre, a creative women's group, a youth project teaching IT to unemployed young people and finally a day centre for the elderly. They were all inspirational but the young woman running the elderly group was something else. She had the group dancing and singing blues music belting out. We had to sing a song! It was a truly memorable experience. Ours wasn't a private tour.

Don't Miss This!. My wife and I went to Cape Town for the hiking, beach going, shark cage diving, and wine drinking time we had heard about from others. We discovered Uthando through this site and we are so happy we did. This tour will humble and inspire you at the same time. The group is fantastic. I mentioned upon signing up that my wife enjoyed singing, so they tailored a trip to visit a choir and dance group. It was more than amazing. I will venture to say that you will not understand the history and culture of South Africa and Cape Town without taking a tour like this. There are other Township tours you can take; Uthando has a vested interest in over 40 (I think it's 40) different projects across a few townships. All ranging from organic farming to after school programs. So each tour is slightly different and as I mentioned above, they are willing to tailor a tour to your specific interest so let them know ahead of time.

A side of Cape Town that every tourist should see . Many tourists will only pass the townships on their way too or from the airport but this is where one quarter of the city's population live. This is not a township tour but a visit to a number of projects supported by Uthando. Our visit consisted of a trip to an inspiring women's workshop and after school centre for kids, a community garden project and finallya centre to teach programming skills to convicts and other disadvantaged children. This was a truly unforgettable experience made all the more interesting by learning about the history of South Africa that James (Uthando's founder) shared with us so passionately, during the afternoon. We would recommend this tour to anyone.

Trusted Company, Wonderful Visit. I went on the Uthando tour with five friends during our time in Cape Town. The staff members here are extremely time efficient and passionate about taking you around to several sites. Great mix of environments -- from the garden to women making jewelry to schoolchildren - you get to see a bit of everything. Worth the money and a great way to see townships outside of Cape Town.

Inspirational Visit. A colleague and I just returned from leading a study abroad course to South Africa for DePaul University students. One of the highights of the trip was visitng three Uthando sites: a community garden; a community center that caters principally to women in the township of Khayelitscha; and a computer workshop run by an ex-con. We were escorted to all three by James Fernie, the founder of Uthando and a passionate advocate for community development in the new democratic South Africa. Along the way we visited memorials to Amy Biehl and the Gugulethu Seven and were provided with an excellent historical introduction to apartheid and its legacy. I cannot recommend too highly a visit to these sites as it will give visitors a true sense of what is going on "on the ground" in South Africa today. If possible, try to set up volunteering oppoortunities for yourself at one of these sites. We certainly will the next time we bring students to South Africa.

Truly special visit that's upbeat and uplifting. This is not just another tour or 'tourist experience; this is truly special and an insight into the other side of life in urban Africa. It was a field trip into a township where you felt safe, but saw how people lived. It was fun, upbeat and revealing. For our little group, the school was a revelation. We were made most welcome and entertained with infectious enthusiasm by the children - in fact some of us ended up singing and dancing with them. At the same time, we learnt about the serious problems faced by the children, teachers and those who live in the townships and the dedication that goes into making the school, and the other projects, such a beacon of light.

Touching & inspiring!
Encountering not visiting.. Must do when in Cape Town and interested in learning about life in townships. Small groups, visiting amazing projects, meeting incredible local people and encountering feelings and stories. Worth your time for sure!

An inspiring and authentic South African experience!. If one genuinely wants to learn about South Africa, its history and current situation, this tour is the best thing you possibly do! Xolani gives an insight in the most engaging way and you just feel so inspired and wanting to give back after visiting the community projects in the “townships” around Cape Town. The positive energy, confidence and perspectives that are rendered to disadvantaged people in those projects are a truly heart-warming and unique experience without having to fear to intrude in their lives and being voyeuristic. Definitely a “Don't miss”!

Fantastic tour to township. Our tour-guide Xolani is wonderful, he is witty and very engaged. He explained history and culture from his personal experiences, very enlightening and entertaining.We saw 4 projects fantastic work, but the best for me were meeting the "oldies" in what Xolani called" the kindergarten for the old people"It is highly recommendable to go on a township tour with Uthando

So enlightening!!. This tour is a first class experience. The tour operators are knowledgeable and friendly. They never bore you. You meet such wonderful people that do so much for themselves with so little resource. Definitely an eye opened and highly recommended

LOVE!. As Xolani (our guide) shared, Uthando means "love." And love sums up the the feeling one is left with after taking this remarkable and humbling tour to learn about the work community based organizations are doing in some of Cape Town's largest Townships. Unlike so many other tours, Uthando ensures Township residents are treated with dignity and their voices are heard. You learn of the hard-won successes residents have made since the dismantling of the brutal apartheid regime as well as the challenges they continue to face. For anyone interested in social justice and community development, this tour is a must.

Very memorable part of our trip. we did this trip with our children aged 10 and 12 and we all found it extremely interesting. Xolani , our guide was completely engaging and kept the kids interested throughout. We saw 3 projects in the townships , all very different and before going on this trip ( having been to Cape Town many time ) I had always driven past the townships and felt pity and despair as to what sort of a life people were living. And this tour made me realise that they have a lot of hope and things are improving with the help of people like Uthando and of course us for going on these trips . I think its a must for anyone visiting Cape Town and its a way of helping, whilst learning and experiencing it with a very experienced guide. Thank you James and Xolani

The name is program!. Excellent tour - not a (unfortunately like the majority of tours) voyeristic tour, so you will not feel like going to a zoo. Cause they show only their supported project and you will directly support them. You will see poverty, but moreover you will encounter inspiring and proud personalities who are willing to change and do an amazong job. Brilliant tour, very recommendable.

A real eye-opener. It's easy to be seduced by the beauty of the Cape and forget that there are still people living there, in sight of exquisite Table Mountain itself, in desperate circumstances. This tour was both enlightening and cheering as we saw how the dedication of committed individuals is bringing about huge improvements in the community. Passionate, informed tour guides and a well-planned excursion. Highly recommended.

The highlight of our visit to South Africa. We spent a morning with Uthando at the Cape Town Flats Townships in late October. A month later, this morning is still the highlight of a six- week trip to Africa and one that we continue to share with friends and family. The work that Uthando is doing in this community is outstanding! Our morning helped us better understand the reality of the legacy of apartheid. We were very moved by the people we met and will never forget Mama Gloria with her precious pre- schoolers or the dignity, joy and resolve of the seniors in their daycare centre. James Fernie was prompt and personal in his replies to our inquiries. After our visit he sent us a reading and movie list so that we could continue our interest in South Africa. Xolani was an outstanding guide, sharing his knowledge with personal stories. We highly recommend a morning with Uthando.

Wow!. I went with 3 travel buyers to see some Uthando projects led by James and Xolani. This was an abbreviated tour and we all left with a distinct sense that these two have created one of the most amazing concepts of responsible tourism. They don't mince words nor fluff things up. This is NOT a tour where it's "us versus them" which is often the case when visiting developing countries. You literally get a chance to see how a little bit of support from tourists can garner some incredible rewards. We visited a educational center that was preparing for a large photography exhibit inspired by a patron from the US, we did aerobics and danced with seniors at one of the centers and we saw a community garden that now sells their produce to a 5* hotel in Cape Town. This is a MUST visit for anyone considering making a difference.

A day of love. Had the experience of spending a day experiencing incredible people and organizations. Filled with hope, inspiration education. James is the real deal. Please don't miss this opportunity.

Heart Warming. Myself and my partner wanted to do a township tour to see the real Cape Town and it's people but also did not want to feel like we were intruding. This tour allowed us to visit 3 different projects that included children, adults and elderly adults. All of the people we met were welcoming and informative. Our favourite project was probably NOAH were we chatted with the elderly via an interpreter, sand and danced as well as hugging to break the barrier. I was overwhelmed by their warmth and friendliness. You will see the real side to how people live in Cape Town if you visit a township and I'm so glad we did this rather than stay in the mainstream area. Our driver/guide was very informative during our drives and provided an excellent service. Thank you Uthando. During my 28 days in Africa, this experience has stuck in our minds more than any other.

Awesome Experience!. #LISA14 had the distinct opportunity to visit the Township with the support of James Fernie. Meeting the Ladies and Children were a highlight of the trip. Such incredible experiences to see first hand the work going on to better the lives of those who live there.They prepared a lunch for us and we had the chance to hear from the ladies who run the Center and also the products that the single moms design and create and are then able to sell in the Shop.Thanks so much for this up close and personal Experience!

A Rare Privilege. Uthando is performing valuable assistance in getting international exposure to the true stories of the townsships and their people. Xolani was an informed and passionate guide into the lives of millions of Africans in SA.I admit that my partner and I had some trepidation before going on the tour. We want to know the real stories of our travel destinations, yet seeing the townships from the air coming into Cape Town was overwhelming and fearful. We're so happy we went forward with this "tour". The quotation marks are an acknowledgement that this is so much more than a tour. Our visit to a few of the projects Uthando is supporting helped us to understand the depth of the issues surrounding poor blacks in SA, and their grassroots efforts to help themselves when there appears to be little political will to provide services for them.Take this tour. Spend time learning the truth from people who will inspire you and warm your hearts.

Don't miss this!. I have taken several tours with Uthando and always return to see what they're doing. They support a wide variety of projects in the Townships, and the tours highlight the positive, creative things going on. It is a different perspective on life here, one that no one should miss. Xolani is a warm, caring guide full of information and a genuinely funny guy. Not your usual tour, and for that, it is spectacular!

I wish the tour had been a full day. We were picked up at our hotel by one of the staff of Uthando. He was African and gave us a first hand view of the projects that Uthando is supporting. Our travel agent joined us. She said that her company often hires the music and dance groups in the township for corporate events. After seeing the dancing and hearing the singing, I can see why. I agree with the other reviewers and won't repeat, but this is self determination at the very best. Please sign up for one of their tours--the residents want you to visit and are proud to show off what they are doing for themselves.

Good to get off the beaten path and experience real life in Cape Town.. Uthando means love in South African and it is a non-profit organization that supports projects throughout Cape Town and its townships. It is not a typical tourist attraction but one that really connects tourists with real people, real concerns, and real hardships and solutions. There are many projects that can be visited. We saw a women's center that helped teach women gardening, cooking, beadwork, provided after school activities for children, and gave women and children a place to go to feel useful and needed. We also went to a community garden that had grown to the point the women there were providing fresh food to local restaurants. And we went to a senior center where the "Oldies" could spend time away from their cares and concerns and be taken care of themselves. Our guide was Xolani and he did a phenomenal job of explaining -- and sharing -- Uthando with us. We learned a lot about him and a great deal about Apartheid as seen throught the eyes of someone who experienced it firsthand -- very moving stories. As someone else said - this is a must do experience in Cape Town -- you won't be disappointed and you will definitely learn a lot.

The best experience ever in Cape Town. This was a powerful, fun , heartwarming experience that I would advise everyone to go on as well! Help out the townships financially while learning about their history and culture!

A Cape Town " Must Do". I was looking for a way to go beyond the typical tourist attractions in Cape Town and connect with some locals. I'm so happy I discovered Uthando Private Tour, a non-profit that supports some truly wonderful projects. I was afraid visiting the townships would be intrusive, but the way this tour is handled is very uplifting. You get to meet people that are really helping their community through education, training, and fellowship.Our guide Xolani was a wealth of information on the recent history and the current situation of South Africa. His positive and straightforward attitude made the tour a real highlight of my trip. If you are thinking of a township tour, this is the company you should go with.

Excellent, interesting, heart warming experience. We are a family of five. Our kids have the age of 19, 17 and 13. We all were very happy we did a private township tour with Uthando. We visited several projects: a gardening project, a dancing for kids project, a choir project, a an elderly home and afterwards we went for lunch (BBQ) at Mzoli's Our guide Xholani was really very good. We learned a lot from him about South Africa, its history in an open interesting way, not the classical tour guide experience.Our Children and we found this the top experience on our trip in South Africa

Fantastic insight. We were worried this would be voyerism. But thanks to the sensitive way it is organised and the chance to participate in the positive impact that Uthando has it was a very uplifting experience. Thanks to Xolani for a truly eye opening experience.

So glad we booked this tour!. My partner and I last visited South Africa in 1995 and did a township tour which felt slightly invasive. This time we visited the country with our two teenage daughters and I felt that it was important for us to see what life is like in the townships and so I looked into different tours. Uthando stood out for me as I liked the fact that it is a NGO working with projects in the townships. We had a great guide- thank you Xolani, and learnt a lot about life in the townships. We visited a craft project for women (and bought some crafts there- we now wish we had bought more!), an amazing organic garden and a project for older people. We were greeted with warmth and were inspired by the work of all the projects. The tour had a lasting impression on us and I am now trying to think of ways in which I can continue to support the work which Uthando does. Please consider booking a tour with Uthando when you visit Cape Town.

An amazing experience for our family. The Uthando tour that we took with Xolani was an inspiring, authentic, uplifting experience for our family. The diversity of programs we saw was a testament to the breadth of Uthando's work. From organic gardening, to a craft cooperative, to a dizzying array of children's programs, Uthando's work is engaging and empowering people who live very differently from the way we do. Hopefully, witnessing the power of grass-roots programs will remind us be committed to such efforts at home, as well. My three teens were enthralled and I am grateful for the opportunity to have participated.

An incredible journey. Our tour with Uthando was a deeply moving experience. Our guide was personable, enthusiastic and provided our family with an excellent overview of South African history and all its complexities. The programs we visited where we met leaders transforming their communities gave us an opportunity to listen to the needs of the people and their hope for the future. Highly recommended. It is a journey that will reach your heart.

Essential Cape Town Experience. You can't come to Cape Town and not visit the townships. Uthando is an incredible and authentic experience where you'll get to meet and interact with the people. I had heard that some township experiences are invasive but Uthando is completely genuine and the people are happy to meet visitors. We visited several projects that Uthando helps fundraise for: a center where women make art and sell it to raise money for their families and the township, a garden where the people are learning to grow vegetables to sustain the people in their communities as well as sell to local restaurants and a couple other great places as well, including the Amy Biehl foundation where we were treated to several wonderful performances by the children. I know some people worry about whether or not visiting the townships are safe but I can tell you that this tour is. It was truly an inspiring day and all the proceeds raised from the tours benefit the communities you visit.

Eye-opening. I had heard about these types of township tours previously but was concerned that they might be exploitive. I didn't want to be an intruder in someone's home. But, I also did want to see both sides of Cape Town...My sister-in-law told me about Uthando and their great work. With her recommendation and after reviewing their website, I decided to go with their organization. I like knowing that they are a non-profit and that the fee for the tour goes to the programs they sponsor - a number of great projects to help the township communities.My two friends and I were taken on the tour by Xolani. Excellent tour guide. Not only did he show us a number of different projects Uthando is involved in, he also gave us some historical perspective regarding the issues of Cape Town/South Africa. He left me wanting to learn more. And, he really loves his job! I also love that Uthando has a 'pack for a cause' project with a wish list so visitors can help out with items that the children and others may need. I only wish I had brought items with me! Or purchased items once in Cape Town to donate - the US dollar goes far.Great experience. Great cause.

An absolute must on any Cape Town trip!. You will no doubt have read about/ been told the top things to do in Cape Town; enjoy the panoramic views from Table Mountain, shop in the V&A, take the ferry and tour of Robben Island, dip your toes in the (icy) sea at Camps Bay beach and enjoy fine dining at many of Cape Town's glamorous establishments.....BUT please don't leave without signing up for a UTHANDO tour with James or Xolani. This was my second tour with UTHANDO, the last time was 4 years ago and am I so pleased to have seen that UTHANDO has remained true to its roots and more importantly that the projects they support have flourished and they are now supporting many more people in the townships and beyond. A highlight as always was the 'Kindergarten for Oldies', the singing, smiles and warm hugs from people who have lived in Cape Town their whole lives and due to the apartheid regime many of them have never been up Table Mountain, visited the V&A, taken the ferry to Robben Island, been on any of the cities' beaches or into any of Cape Town's glamorous establishments. And yet, they remain upbeat and are eager to meet and learn about anyone who takes the time to visit them in their day centre in Khayelitsha. Take a tissue!

An inspiring day. We recently made a half day tour of the Townships near Cape Town, South Africa with James Fernie, founder and Director of a charitable organization called Uthando (South Africa) Social Development Projects. Uthando is the Xhosa and Zulu word for "love," and this was evident in the way James was greeted in each of the projects he took us to visit. First was a women's craft project in which women were taught beading and other crafts. On the roof there was a garden; the women were very proud to show us around. Next was an agricultural project in which a number of ladies developed a farm on which they grow vegetables to be sold to restaurants in Cape Town. Their hard work was a terrific demonstration of the power of determined women! We then visited a preschool which doubles as a chorus school for young people in the afternoons. It was heartwarming to see how happy the children were, and how modern principles of education were followed in a rather difficult setting. We ended up at a dance school ("Dance for Everyone") which reaches out to the townships to teach young boys and girls various forms of dance. When particularly talented individuals are identified they are invited to a live-in intermediate program where the finer points of dance are learned, and many have gone off to careers in dance around the world. What an inspiration that day was for us. Uthando funds these and other projects aimed at developing self-help among the people living in the townships. This visit as really the highlight of our two week trip to South Africa, and we would recommend it to anyone who has the opportunity.

The Highlight of our Trip. Our Uthando 'tour' was the most moving half-day of our entire two week trip. We visited a day care/nursery school in Gugulethu, a cooperative called Ekhaya Ekasi and a senior center both in Kayelitsha. Seeing the organizations in action and meeting the people whose lives are touched by the work of these organizations was heart warming and incredibly meaningful for us. This experience should not be missed!!!We especially enjoyed the visit to the Senior Center in Kayelitsha where we met and embraced over 50 seniors who had experienced the worst days of apartheid. We HIGHLY recommend this experience! Thank you to Xolani for a great day.
Uthando Tour. An outstanding alternative guide experience to Cape Town. Highly recommended. Very informed guide with local knowledge and not patronising. A MUST do on your trip.

Unique and authentic experience. I was dreading the thought of a 'township tour' as I thought it would be patronizing and voyeuristic. This tour was most definitely not like this at all. I would say it is the ONLY way to get a vaguely accurate sense of what life is like in a township. Our guide, James, was knowledgeable and passionate and provided a unique insight into the history of the area and current political situation. We visited a number of community projects and got to meet some amazing people who are working very hard under difficult conditions to make whatever difference they can. The opportunity to donate to the projects also meant that we could make our own small contribution.

Comprehensive without being voyeuristic. If you want to do a tour that really helps you understand the challenges of a life in a township, go with Uthando. You will visit at least three social projects out of the forty supported by the NGO and if you feel compelled to you are invited to donate at the end of the tour. We went to a nursery, a gardening project and a centre for senior citizens, where we were asked a lot of questions and were invited to sing and dance. Uthando offers you a very personal and somewhat overwhelming insight we recommend to everybody who wants to visit a township without being voyeuristic.

Inspirational and genuine - don't miss this opportunity.. My experience visiting four of the Uthando supported projects was the highlight of my Cape Town visit. Xolani took us to visit a community garden where the women grow vegetables that are sold to restaurants in the city. I was fascinated that they use the garden left overs (tops, vines etc) to produce the gas they use to fire the stove. Talk about recycling - this is an amazing project. The Kiddies Educare was an uplifting visit. The director is an amazing and compassionate lady who started the program which now educates pre-school, kindergarten and first graders. The rooms full of smiling, learning youngsters were wonderful to see. Uthando partners with Kiddies Educare and helped them build the school building they now occupy. We also visited a women's center where the ladies develop skills that further their livelihoods. Our last stop with a Sr. Center. The ladies and gentlemen welcomed us with smiles and warm hearts. They wanted to learn about our lives and shared theirs with us. We got to sing and dance together and it felt like we were, for a brief while, a part of their community. This was a heart warming experience. Xolani, thank you sharing your knowledge and passion for the work Uthando is doing in the townships. Also, please thank the adults and children who shared their daily life experiences with us. These visits have made a lasting impression on me and reinforced my belief that when we come together to share about good, we make friends across miles and boundaries of time and nationality.

Inspiration, informative and beneficial to the local community. An amazing trip to enlighten tourists in a positive manor rather than the standard township tours! A way of seeing the truth about South Africa and the positive work being undertaken by inspirational individuals within townships. The children, women and older citizens were all welcoming and their smiles infectious. An emotional yet positive encounter. A special mention to the guides, who are well informed, knowledgable and bring a local view of how Uthando works and it's benefits.

Reality check, inspirational and one of highlights of trip.. Who wouldn't be moved by children growing healthy veg for their families in the township…from little more than sand? This was a fascinating - and unmissable - trip, seeing the day-to-day realities of life in the townships. Uthando helps bring real, philanthropic hope with pragmatic and caring projects that help feed, provide medical care and bring dignity to peoples' lives. People who should be getting more help and finance from the government…Thank you James and [CLICK] Xolani. Will never forget my time with you.

A must do. Our tour with Xolani was one of the highlights of our 2 weeks in Cape Town, it really is a must do for any visitor. Xolani himself was so passionate and knowledgeable, it was an absolute privilege to meet him. On the tour we visited several projects, at each one the people and their warmth and passion was inspiring. There is no begging bowl approach, nor did it feel in anyway voyeuristic (something we were especially concerned about), the whole experience was wrapped in a sense of sharing and enlightening and above all hope. Thank you Uthando.

Fantastic experience. We thoroughly enjoyed our day with Uthando, Xolani made us feel so comfortable in every place we toured, and told the history of South Africa so movingly, particularly the stories of Amy Biehl and the student uprisings. I highly recommend your company.

Amazing experience!!!. Very amazing experience here. Uthando collaborates with close to fifty projects that are changing life in the townships. It was truly inspiring to see all the projects that empowered the community. The tours offer a peak into the humanitarian side of Cape Town and delves into the history and pulse of South Africa. If ever in Cape Town, book a trip with them. Life changing and very very inspiring.

Eye Opening experience. Was an extremely interesting experience seeing the conditions and attitudes of the people in the townships, and the work that Uthando is trying to do to assist. Xolani was incredibly informative and ensured that we were safe at all times. We ended up seeing the arts and crafts centre for women, the self-sufficient garden, and the dancing school aimed at boys to get them off the streets and into crime. It really was an interesting morning, and we ended up being the only ones on the tour so we got to ask Xolani what ever we wanted.

AMAZING!. We loved our experience with Uthando. Xolani and James are so passionate about and committed to their work. They have vetted their partner programs to ensure their clients are supporting programs that are in fact affecting positive change in the township communities. They move from a place of love and respect and it is exhilarating to be part of.

Great experience!. The day I spent with James visiting different projects in the townships of capetown was a highlight of my trip. All the projects from daycare to the organic garden were so inspirational. And the visit to the center for the elderly where we were treated to wonderful singing was so beautiful! James also shared with us his vast knowledge of the history of South Africa. This experience is not to be missed!

Love Uthando. I was able to go with James on several tours with my family. All tours were were an enriching experience. On one of the tours we visited the Hout Bay Music Project; a music school for the children of the nearby township. On another tour, we were able to visit Abalimi Bezekhaya where women from the township grow vegetables. On the same tour, we were able to see a performance from the Thokozani Brothers where both the boys and girls sang beautiful songs.Fantastic experience and great to share with the family.

The back-story of Cape Town, so important to see. This was an exceptional experience. We visited four different non-profits and were able to observe some wonderful work being done in the community. We danced with the elderly, listened to children singing, saw marvelous gardens planted for and by locals and watched beading and other crafts being taught. All these projects contribute to helping bring the townships out of poverty. We owe it to ourselves to go and watch and contribute. Cape Town is a marvelous place for restaurants, museums and scenery, but that's only part of what should be seen.

Township Tour.. I was very impressed with the quality of this Tour.Our tour guide, Xolani was superb. His excellant knowledge of the townships was clearly communicated to us, with his skilled vocal vocabulary. His endless energy kept us regailed the entire Tour. He gave us great incite into the African cultures and his story of his imminent marriage and the Lobola ( payment to his future wifes family) that he was busy with negotiating was fasinating to hear.The Tour gave all of us such a good insite into African life in the townships and it was important that we experienced this side of our community.Recommended for everybody who visites South Africa.

Township tour. We were a little nervous of taking our children (7and 10) on this tour but we are so glad we did - informative, real and truly inspirational I hope it will transform their lives. The projects we visited were diverse and the information we were given on all aspects of life in the townships really opened our eyes to the problems that are faced as well as the amazing optimism with which they are tackled. We visited a community garden and packing shed, kindergarden and an old people's day group all helping to give the communities real help.

We left feeling drunk on song. This tour was recommended by our g adventures rep, and she was right in saying Uthando not only offer fantastic experiences, but help a great cause. The people we met had so much passion and energy. From vegetable growing to a large group of 'oldies' who sang and danced for us, it was all so memorable.

A Day of Song & Real Heart Connections. James was the perfect tour host, knowledgeable & passionate about his connection with all the amazing people at the key township projects his company supports. We were met with joy, warmth, celebration & song with such a diverse range of projects, the abundant Siyazama Garden, a childrens skills school teaching such skills as bricklaying & woodwork & a beautiful lunch at a community centre. The powerful voices of the youth choir brought tears to my eyes, along with the tiny gumboot dancers. But I have to say that the highlight of the day was a visit to a centre for the elderly. This meeting had tears rolling down my cheeks with the sheer love & authenticity of these beautiful, full hearted beings. What an education what a blessing! A huge Thank You to all those folk who greeted us so warmly in the townships & to James who hosted a truly memorable, vibrant experience!

The other side of Capetown. I had concerns about visiting the townships, as I did not want to be seen as a rich tourist "slumming". However, we were met with such enthusiasm by all the residents we encountered, that my trepidations were unfounded. I do not think a visit to S. Africa is complete without touring the conditions under which most S. Africans live, and the Uthando guide took us where we needed to go to see both the history and the future of these people. .

A REAL TOUR. Uthando provides a unique opportunity to escape the usual tourist artificial gloss and to learn, experience and have some human contact with another culture but not at the price of being voyeurs or intrusive. We experienced an intelligent and frank introduction to the history of townships in the context of people's lives and at the same time made a contribution to obviously important and successful community projects. It was also great fun especially the senior citizen community centre. Uthando's township tour will be the highlight of our trip to South Africa.

Great experience. We had a day trip to the Townships with Uthando and this was one of the best memory of Cape Town. Our guide was great. He showed us different projects that are made up to help people living in poor conditions. The best part of all was the visit to a home for old people, they were so friendly with us and we had so much fun singing with them! We loved this tour!

Well worth a half-day or more. We spent a half-day in July 2013 visiting several of the programs Uthando supports in townships just outside Cape Town. Our guide, Xolani, was well-informed of the history of the area, and his optimism about the future of the residents made the day. We visited a community garden and an afterschool program for youth. Our kids, 11 and 13, still talk about the programs we visited. A very educational and worthwhile balance to the more touristy areas of Cape Town.

A must when visiting Cape Town. My Utthando half day tour turned out to be a surprisingly, wonderful thought provoking experience. James made the arrangements and Xolani the tour leader gave us access to projects in the developing townships. It was a social history lesson, that should be a must for any discerning traveller to Cape Town. Take your camera, but ask before taking pictures. I had a chance to visit a senior day centre where they really welcomed me. However, the most moving part of my tour, was seeing how Zoliswa the leader of the Educare day care centre, managed the staff and uncomplaining coped with up to 70 preschoolers. She has sacrificed and given into her community. It challenged me and gave me an opportunity to go back a couple of days later and help in a very practical way.It makes you want to cheer the good being done and makes you want to help fix what needs fixing. Take the tour, you will be challenged!!

This is one day you will never forget!. This voyeuristic, socially-just day at the grassroots projects in the townships outside Cape Town will bring into light the stark reality, the unmeasured courage and tenacity of its battered but brave souls. I took the tour in April, and its images and stories still stay with me today. It was the highlight of my trip to SA, and I'm changed for the better because of the work that UTHANDO does to give back to the community. Book the tour. You will never regret it.

CAPE TOWN HIGHLIGHT. Truly a wonderful eye-opening experience. Travelling with a teenage daughter we were a little hesitant about going into the townships especially not wanting to be voyeuristic. But after speaking to James he was able to organise a morning for us that we will never forget. Our guide Charlene was both knowledgeable and enthusiastic. Visiting the Khumbalani Day Care Centre and meeting Mama Gloria was inpsirational. Since arriving back home we have continued our relationship with Uthando, and if we are ever lucky enough to visit the Mother City again, a tour with them will definitely be one of the first things we organise. We highly recommend it to anyone!!!

The real South Africa. If you want to enjoy the beauty and the ease of Cape Town, you owe it to yourself and your fellow travellers to visit the townships. Uthando gives you the ability to see inside the townships and to experience not just the sadness and the poverty but also the wonderful projects that are trying to make them a better place to live. Xolani our guide gave us information and history lessons which we would never have found ourselves. A must do for every foreigner in South Africa!

Must do in Cape Town. My wife and went on a tour with Xolani this morning - he is a delightfully engaging young man. It is interesting to see at first hand how many in cape town live - it's perfectly safe in the townships and you are in the hands of experts - it was great to see the passion these people have for what they do - the dancing by the young people and children in the sports hall was fabulous these kids perform with such enthusiasm and joy - it was a privilege to share it.I would highly recommend a tour with this group it's a way of showing support for them as well as educational for they tourists Great job guys !

Very interesting and engaging. I traveled on a township tour with Uthando in June 2013. I thoroughly enjoyed James' explanation of South African history on the way out to the townships and he was able to answer all the questions that came up on the ride. We toured two different non-profit organizations working to make improvements in the townships and our hosts at each stop were wonderful. The trip ended with a Youth Day celebration in Khayelitsha which I will never forget. Troupes of children dancing, choirs from girls and boys to local men, and it all ended with the performers and crowd signing the South African national anthem. It was an amazing experience and I would definitely go again when I return to Cape Town.

Inspirational and important: a must-do in Cape Town. My elderly mother and I spent a fascinating and inspirational morning visiting three township projects with our excellent Uthando guide, Xolani. We wanted to understand more about township life today without being voyeuristic and this tour was perfect. Uthando is focused on supporting the many local people who are trying to improve township life through constructive participation in their own communities. The three projects we visited were a craft and music centre; a market garden initiative; and a community centre for elderly folk. Each centre was fascinating, and the enthusiasm and devotion of their staff and participants was truly uplifting. We felt that our visit was an example of tourism helping rather than hurting. Xolani was an exceptional guide, sharing his passion, knowledge and great warmth with us to make this one of our most memorable experiences in South Africa. We came away feeling that despite South Africa's significant social challenges, there is every reason to hope for a brighter future for all.

A true learning experience!. We had an incredible day visiting 3 townships with Uthando. Our guide, Xolani is so bright and knowledgeable with both SA history and present situations. It was an inspirational morning for my husband and I as well as for our three children and so good to see that there are citizens out there who are willing to work hard and educate themselves in order to take care of their families. We are so happy that we incorporated this tour in our short 3 day visit to Capetown. I consider it a "must do".

See the other side of Cape Town in a meaningful way with James Fernie. James Fernie led us on a wonderful trip to some of the townships in the Cape Flats. He explained the history of the area and provided background about the struggles in SA from the early 1940's to the present day. These suburbs contain a hugely disproportionate number of Cape Town citizens and conditions are crowded and poverty and deprivation is a result. The tour took us to several small non-profit organisations so we could meet the people running them and also the people who benefit from them. Uthando supports the non-profits by bringing visitors and funds and helping to raise awareness. The trip was joyful and fascinating; it's not voyeuristic walk - snapping at people as they go about their daily business. It's a respectful yet fun opportunity to see why the people of Cape Flats need assistance and how successful it is when it's available. I highly recommend it!

Genuine, influential township tour company. High recommended professional, knowledgeable township tour company. Fair Trade accredited Uthando support carefully selected viable development projects in Cape Town townships. They add valuable in-depth context to the visit with SA's history and present. A must do for visitors *and locals* alike, providing a fascinating, moving, accessible and contributory path into a world that can feel impenetrable or intimidating. You will be very warmly welcomed by the projects that your visit will financially support.

Great experience. This is an experience you should have when travelling through South AfricaIt makes you realise how rich we are and what little things can doUthando lets you see what projects can do for the townshipsXolani is a great guide with a lot of knowledge to shareThanks for showing us the other side of life

Inspirational. It should be compulsory for all visitors to come on a tour with Uthando to the Townships.For my wife and I it was inspirational and taught us so much both historically and what the future may hold.We visited three projects each one opening our eyes to another world.The work being done by Uthando is fantastic and our guide Xolani was excellent along with Fred.

An Amazing Experience!. Thank you so much Xolani Maseko and Fred for a wonderful visit to the townships of the Cape Town area. Uthando is doing amazing work with non-profit, grassroots organizations, and it is an inspiration to visit with the kind, thoughtful and motivated individuals who are doing such important work in their own communities. It was an absolute privilege to be able to see this side of life in South Africa. Many blessings to you in your continuing work!

Community tour in Cape Town. Our tour with Uthando and James gave us real insight into the day to day lives of many who live in South Africa. It was a wonderful way to spend a day learning about the recent history of this magnificent country. On an otherwise very more touristy trip to this part of Africa, our day learning about the Uthando projects was so fulfilling. We especially liked seeing the Amy Biehl memorial and learning about her history there. Thank you to very knowledgeable James and Sugar. This tour makes a trip to Cape Town a very rich opportunity!

Inspirational. I personally feel it's important to get to know the history of an area that I'm visiting as well as the current issues. I wanted to visit a township, but I didn't want to feel like a lurker. I wanted to visit in a more genuine way where we could learn of the issues and interact. Upon reading reviews on TA, I found Uthando. It seemed like the perfect choice and it was. I had the incredible opportunity to visit the Khayelitsha township with a stop in Guguletu with James of Uthando. James is passionate and encompasses the true meaning of the word Uthando which means Love. He gives us insight into the issues, the history and the work being done. Have to say it was a highlight of my trip to Cape Town. I really enjoyed visiting the places James chose for us. We visited a centre where women are taught arts and crafts for the purpose of business and supporting their families. It was inspiring. We then visited a garden centre where women grow, harvest and sell their goods, wonderful to visit and learn what they are doing. Our final visit was to the Thokozani Brothers. This is a mens and youth singing group. We were treated to an incredible and uplifting performance and was a beautiful way to end our time in Khayelitsha. Thank you James for an inspiring day.

Inspiring tour of community projects. My half day tour with James of three Uthando projects was a highlight of my trip to South Africa. This was arranged for me by my travel agents in NYC who wholeheartedly support the work of Uthando. And I agree, it is one of the best ways to get out of the Cape Town tourist bubble and see how a good portion of Capetonians must live and work. First, James had such a remarkable story to tell about how he came to do this work as we drove out of downtown and into the flats of Cape Town. Then, after seeing the Amy Biehl memorial, we visited three projects, one was related to economic development through art making, one a youth choir and one was a day care center. I had time to at each place to linger and watch what was going on and, most important, to chat with the people who ran the programs. I absolutely loved the music and dance performance by the youth choir. The tour was at times educational, sad, uplifting and motivating. When I bring my family to South Africa, we will definitely spend time with Uthando.

A special interest tour. An opportunity to visit townships and you could never see without a guide. I thought the programme was slick and the tour guide had excellent knowledge. I loved the chance to meet the organisers of the craft project, agriculture project and music project. To visit Cape Town and not do this is a missed opportunity. I hope to remain involved in some way with this organisation.

Great way to step out of the tourist bubble.. When visiting many countries of the world we are often confronted by the unhappy realism of the local's poverty while we are enjoying ourselves holidaying. Many of us wonder how these people live their daily lives but have no way of asking without being intrusive. Tours like Uthando facilitate this interaction by bring holiday makers briefly into the lives of people living in townships and one can experience what their quotidian might be like. This tour was very rewarding for my family and my young children loved it too. My only regret was too not have stayed longer in some place like the Tokozani Brothers where we were greeted so warmly and by so many people.

Community Projects. When I planned our trip to South Africa, I wanted my children to witness the townships without feeling voyeuristic and I am glad I found Uthando. Visiting James' wonderful projects gave us a beautiful insight on how men and women work with their community at heart. The whole trip was very interesting and we really enjoyed learning more about life in the townships and having the opportunity to talk to the project leaders.I am glad our visit helped giving funds to those projects

A trip everyone has to do to get a clear understanding of South Africa. James and Xolani were passionate and compassionate with their explanation of the history and up to date information on South Africa and Cape Town. We visited some wonderful projects and made us realise how complex life is here. If only more people were aware if the hardships of others I am sure it would go a long way to help all. You can rely on our support. Kamila and Mike

An educational tour filled with 'Uthando' (love ;). I found this tour to be incredibly informative - James really knows his South African history/politics. I found parts of the tour a little awkward though (and it may just have been our group's specific time pressure) specifically with regards to the interactions with the locals. There wasn't much time to make 'real' connections with the people that we met. Having said that though, there were a few delightfully spontaneous moments (sing-offs anyone?). I believe that Uthando is onto a good thing and if you are genuinely interested in learning about South Africa's history and current situation, this is a great tour. It really gets you thinking!
Well worth your time. Our time on the Utando cultural field trip-tour was so interesting, thought provoking and well worth the time!

An ethical insight into the otheside of SA. Travelling around Cape Town and surrounds you might be left thinking you are in a wealthy European country. However, other areas of the city and surrounding towns tell a different story. In choosing a township tour company I was concerned that we might become voyeuristic tourists gawping at poverty. Touring with Uthando is nothing like that and it was one of the highlights of our trip to S Africa. James Fernie is an intelligent, passionate and enthusiastic advocate for the many people who live in "informal settlements". We felt truly privileged to be escorted by him around a number of the projects being run by Uthando. It was a great experience, both challenging and touching at times.I believe it would be a good experience and education for everyone to go on one of Uthando's tours. Whilst it may be more expensive than some tours, the many raised helps support projects, so it is well spent and very worthwhile.

Uthando is Making a Difference. We went to Cape Town in August 2012 with our two teenage daughters and adult son. We felt that a township visit was essential to understanding Cape Town’s history, and also wanted to “give back” in some small way. Our travel agent highly recommended James Fermie and the Uthando Tour. On August 27, 2012, James met us at the V&A Waterfront. The group consisted of the five of us and a group of five German tourists. During the trip to Kaylisha Township, James provided some history on apartheid and the townships. It made an impression on all of us. It is very sobering to see tens of thousands of people living in corrugated housing without the electricity and plumbing we take for granted. We were gratified to see some of the newer communities that are being built to replace the township housing, but there is still a long way to go. Thankfully there are organizations like Uthando that are making a difference. Once at Kaylisha, we were introduced to the group leaders for each of the programs. We visited the culinary training, woodworking training, sewing classes, the organic gardens and an after school program. The group leaders explained that each student is required to pay a nominal amount so that they have something invested in the training program. The students are also provided with basic business training, and some students have started baking or sewing businesses. The organic gardens provide fresh vegetables for people in the township and a portion of the produce is also sold outside of the township. The after school program was our favorite.
